Bouché |}} '''''Ficus americana''''', commonly known as the '''West Indian laurel fig''' or '''Jamaican cherry fig''',{{cite web|url=http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=FIAM|title= ''Ficus americana'' Aubl. |accessdate= 2008-07-05 |author= USDA, NRCS |work= The PLANTS Database|publisher= National Plant Data Center, Baton Rouge, LA 70874-4490 USA}} is a tree in the family [[Moraceae]] which is native to the [[Caribbean]], [[Mexico]] in the north, through Central and South America south to southern [[Brazil]]. It is an introduced species in [[Florida]], USA. The species is variable; the five recognised [[subspecies]] were previously placed in a large number of other species. [[File:Ficus2.jpg|thumb|left|''Ficus americana'' at [[Rio de Janeiro Botanical Garden]]]] [[File:Denkschriften der Kaiserlichen Akademie der Wissenschaften - Mathematisch-Naturwissenschaftliche Classe (1858) (20665373299), Ficus americana.jpg|thumb|left|100px|[[Nature printing|Nature printed]] leaf, showing shape and venation]] ==Description== ''Ficus americana'' is a shrub or tree which grows up to 30 m (100 ft) tall.DeWolf, Gordon P., Jr. 1960. Ficus (Tourn.) L. ''In'' Lorin I. Nevling, Jr., [http://www.jstor.org/pss/2394704 Flora of Panama. Part IV. Fascicle II]. ''Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden'', '''47''' (2):81–203 ==Taxonomy== With about 750 species, ''[[Ficus]]'' ([[Moraceae]]) is one of the largest [[angiosperm]] genera (ranked the 31st largest by David Frodin of [[Chelsea Physic Garden]]).{{cite journal | last = Frodin | first = David G. | year = 2004 | title = History and concepts of big plant genera | journal = Taxon | volume = 53 | issue = 3 | pages = 753–76 | url = http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/iapt/tax/2004/00000053/00000003/art00012| doi = 10.2307/4135449 | jstor = 4135449 }} ''Ficus americana'' is classified in the [[subgenus]] ''Urostigma'' (the strangler figs) and the [[section (botany)|section]] ''Americana''. Recent molecular [[Phylogenetics|phylogenies]] have shown that subgenus ''Urostigma'' is [[polyphyletic]], but have strongly supported the validity of section ''Americana'' as a [[clade|discrete group]] (although its exact relationship to section ''Galoglychia'' is unclear).{{cite journal | last = Rønsted | first = N. |author2=Weiblen, G. D. |author3=Clement, W. L. |author4=Zerega, N. J. C. |author5=Savolainen, V. | year = 2008 | title = Reconstructing the phylogeny of figs (Ficus, Moraceae) to reveal the history of the fig pollination mutualism | journal = Symbiosis | volume = 45 | issue = 1–3 | pages = 45–56 | url = http://geo.cbs.umn.edu/RonstedEtAl2008a.pdf }} Both [[Jean Baptiste Christophore Fusée Aublet|Aublet]] and [[Linnaeus]] published descriptions of this species in 1775, basing them on an illustration of [[Charles Plumier]]'s published posthumously in ''Plantarum americanarum, quas olim Carolus Plumierus detexit'' (Amsterdam, 1755–1760). There is uncertainty was to which version was published first; since the first-published description has [[scientific priority|priority]], there was confusion as to which was the proper name for the species—''F. americana'' Aubl. or ''F. perforata'' L. To resolve this, Cornelis Berg proposed in 2003 that Aublet's name be [[conserved name|conserved]] over Linnaeus', since it was more widely used.{{cite journal | last = Berg | first = Cornelis C. |date=May 2003 | title = (1587–1590) Proposals to conserve the names ''Ficus citrifolia'' against ''F. caribaea'', ''F. maxima'' with a conserved type, ''F. aurea'' against ''F. ciliolosa'', and ''F. americana'' against ''F. perforata'' (Moraceae) | journal = Taxon | volume = 52 | issue = 2 | pages = 368–370 | doi = 10.2307/3647421| jstor = 3647421 }} This proposal was accepted "after lengthy discussion".{{cite journal | last = Brummitt | first = R.K. |date=November 2005 | title = Report of the Committee for Spermatophyta: 57 | journal = Taxon | volume = 54 | issue = 4 | pages = 1093–1103 | doi = 10.2307/25065499 | jstor = 25065499 }} Five subspecies are currently recognised: ''F. americana'' Aubl. subsp. ''americana'', ''F. americana'' Aubl. subsp. ''andicola'' (Standl.) C.C. Berg, ''F. americana'' Aubl. subsp. ''greiffiana'' (Dugand) C.C. Berg, ''F. americana'' Aubl. subsp. ''guianensis'' (Desv.) C.C. Berg, and ''F. americana'' Aubl. subsp. ''subapiculata'' (Miq.) C.C. Berg. ==Reproduction== Figs have an obligate [[Mutualism (biology)|mutualism]] with [[fig wasp]] (Agaonidae); figs are only pollinated by fig wasps, and fig wasps can only reproduce in fig flowers. Generally, each fig species depends on a single species of wasp for pollination. The wasps are similarly dependent on their fig species in order to reproduce. Figs in section ''Americana'' of subgenus ''Urostigma'' are pollinated by wasps in the genus ''[[Pegoscapus]]''. ''[[Pegoscapus clusiifolidis]]'' was described from ''Ficus clusiifolia''{{cite journal|last=Schiffler |first=Gustavo |author2=Celso Oliviera Azevedo |author3=Ricardo Kawada |year=2002 |title=Agaonidae (Hymenoptera, Chalcidoidea) associados a sicônios de ''Ficus clusiifolia'' (Moraceae) da restinga de Três Praias, Guarapari, Espírito Santo, Brasil |journal=Boletim do Museu de Biologia Mello Leitao |volume=14 |pages=5–12 |url=http://internt.nhm.ac.uk/resources/research-curation/projects/chalcidoids/pdf/SchiffAzKa2002.pdf }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (a synonym of ''F. americana''). Another study refers to ''[[Pegoscapus insularis|P. insularis]]'' as the pollinator of ''F. perforata'' {{cite journal | last = Molbo | first = Drude |author2=Carlos A. Machado |author3=Jan G. Sevenster |author4=Laurent Keller |author5=Edward Allen Herre | year = 2003 | title = Cryptic species of fig-pollinating wasps: Implications for the evolution of the fig–wasp mutualism, sex allocation, and precision of adaptation | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences USA | volume = 100 | issue = 10 | pages = 5867–72 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0930903100 | pmid = 12714682 | pmc = 156293 }} (another synonym of ''F. americana''). That study also found that ''P. insularis'' represented a [[cryptic species complex]]. ==Distribution== ''Ficus americana'' is found throughout the [[Caribbean]], from the [[Bahamas]] south to [[Trinidad and Tobago]]. It occurs in [[Mexico]], [[Guatemala]], [[Belize]], [[Honduras]], [[Nicaragua]], [[El Salvador]], [[Costa Rica]], [[Panama]], [[Colombia]], [[Venezuela]], [[Guyana]], [[Suriname]], [[Ecuador]], [[Peru]], [[Bolivia]] and [[Brazil]]. It has been introduced to [[Florida]], USA and has escaped from cultivation in [[Miami-Dade County]].{{cite web|url= http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233500646|title= '''Ficus americana''' Aublet, Hist. Pl. Guiane. 952. 1775.|accessdate= 2008-07-05|work= Flora of North America|publisher= eFloras.org}} ==Ecology== Figs are sometimes considered to be potential [[keystone species]] in communities of [[frugivores|fruit-eating animals]]; their [[wikt:asynchrony|asynchronous]] fruiting patterns may cause them to be important fruit sources when other food sources are scarce.{{cite book|last=Terborgh|first=John|editor=[[Michael E. Soulé]] (ed.)|title=Conservation Biology: The Science of Scarcity and Diversity|year=1986|publisher=Sinauer Associates|location=Sunderland, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-87893-795-0|pages=330–344|chapter=Keystone plant resources in the tropical forests}} At Tinigua National Park in [[Colombia]] ''Ficus americana'' was an important fruit producer during periods of fruit scarcity in two of three years. This led Colombian ecologist Pablo Stevens to consider it a potential keystone species at that site.{{cite book|last=Stevenson|first=Pablo|editor=J. Lawrence Dew |editor2=Jean Philippe Boubli (eds.)|title= Tropical Fruits and Frugivores: The Search for Strong Interactors|year=2005|publisher=Springer Netherlands|isbn=978-1-4020-3833-4|doi=10.1007/1-4020-3833-X|pages=37–57|chapter=Potential Keystone Plant Species for the Frugivore Community at Tinigua Park, Colombia}} The interaction between figs and fig wasps is especially well-known (see section on [[Ficus americana#Reproduction|reproduction]], above). In addition to their pollinators, ''Ficus'' species are exploited by a group of non-pollinating [[Chalcid wasp|chalcidoid wasps]] whose larvae develop in its figs. Both pollinating and non-pollinating wasps serve as hosts for [[parasitoid]] wasps.{{cite book|last=Kjellberg|first=Finn |author2=Emmanuelle Jousselin |author3=Martine Hossaert-McKey |author4=Jean-Yves Rasplus|editor=A. Raman |editor2=Carl W. Schaefer |editor3=Toni M. Withers (eds.)|title=Biology, Ecology, and Evolution of Gall-inducing Arthropods|year=2005|publisher=Science publishers, Inc.|location=Enfield (NH) USA, Plymouth, UK|isbn=978-1-57808-262-9|pages=539–572|chapter=Biology, ecology and evolution of fig-pollinating wasps (Chalcidoidea, Agaonidae)|chapterurl=http://www.cefe.cnrs.fr/coev/pdf/fk/Kjellberg2005book.pdf}} In addition to ''Pegoscapus'' pollinators, non-pollinating wasps belonging to the genera ''[[Heterandrium]]'', ''[[Aepocerus]]'' and ''[[Idarnes]]'' were found in ''F. americana'' figs in Brazil. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Ficus|americana]] [[Category:Trees of the Caribbean]] [[Category:Trees of Central America]] [[Category:Trees of Mexico]] [[Category:Plants described in 1775]] [[Category:Trees of South America]] [[Category:Trees of Peru]]
52.title: Ficus americana

53.text:
{{pp-move-indef}}{{italic title}}{{taxobox

'''''Ficus aurea''''', commonly known as the '''Florida strangler fig''' (or simply '''strangler fig'''), '''golden fig''', or '''''higuerón''''',<ref name = Harvey1998/> is a tree in the family [[Moraceae]] that is native to the U.S. state of [[Florida]], the northern and western [[Caribbean]], southern [[Mexico]] and [[Central America]] south to [[Panama]].<ref name = Berg2007>{{cite journal | last = Berg | first = C.C. | year = 2007 | title = Proposals for treating four species complexes in ''Ficus'' subgenus ''Urostigma'' section ''Americanae'' (Moraceae) | journal = Blumea | volume = 52 | issue = 2 | pages = 295–312 | doi = 10.3767/000651907X609034 }}</ref> The specific epithet ''aurea'' was applied by English botanist [[Thomas Nuttall]] who described the species in 1846.

''Ficus aurea'' is a [[strangler fig]]. In [[Ficus|fig]]s of this group, seed germination usually takes place in the canopy of a [[host (biology)|host]] tree with the seedling living as an [[epiphyte]] until its roots establish contact with the ground. After that, it enlarges and strangles its host, eventually becoming a free-standing tree in its own right. Individuals may reach {{convert|30|m|ft|-1|abbr=on}} in height. Like all figs, it has an obligate [[Mutualism (biology)|mutualism]] with [[fig wasp]]s: figs are only pollinated by fig wasps, and fig wasps can only reproduce in fig flowers. The tree provides habitat, food and shelter for a host of tropical lifeforms including epiphytes in [[cloud forests]] and [[bird]]s, [[mammal]]s, [[reptile]]s and [[invertebrate]]s. ''F. aurea'' is used in [[traditional medicine]], for [[Hedge#Live fencing|live fencing]], as an [[Ornamental plant|ornamental]] and as a [[bonsai]].

==Description==
[[File:Ficus aurea01.jpg|thumb|left|200px|''Ficus aurea'' sapling showing elliptic leaf shape at [[Long Key]], [[Florida]]]]
''Ficus aurea'' is a tree which may reach heights of {{convert|30|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}.<ref name = FloraNicarag>[http://mobot.mobot.org/cgi-bin/search_vast?FLNIONDAD=21300459 Flora de Nicaragua] database. Tropicos. {{es icon}} Retrieved on 2008-07-02</ref> It is [[Plant sexuality|monoecious]]: each tree bears functional male and female flowers.<ref name=B&P1992a/> The size and shape of the leaves is variable. Some plants have leaves that are usually less than 10 cm (4 in) long while others have leaves that are larger. The [[Leaf shape|shape of the leaves]] and of the [[Leaf#Base of the leaf|leaf base]] also varies—some plants have leaves that are oblong or elliptic with a wedge-shaped to rounded base, while others have heart-shaped or ovate leaves with [[cordate]] to rounded bases. ''F. aurea'' has paired figs<ref name = Berg2007/> which are green when unripe, turning yellow as they ripen.<ref name = IFAS>{{cite web |last=Gilman |first=Edward F. |author2=Watson, Dennis G. |date=December 2006 |title=''Ficus aurea'': Strangler Fig |publisher=Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences (ENH409) |url=http://edis.ifas.ufl.edu/ST250 |accessdate=2008-06-10}}</ref> They differ in size (0.6–0.8 cm [0.2–0.3 in], about 1 cm [0.4 in], or 1.0–1.2 cm [0.4–0.5 in] in diameter); figs are generally [[Sessility (botany)|sessile]], but in parts of northern [[Mesoamerica]] figs are borne on short stalks known as [[peduncle (botany)|peduncles]].<ref name = Berg2007/>

==Taxonomy==
With about 750 species, ''[[Ficus]]'' ([[Moraceae]]) is one of the largest [[angiosperm]] genera (David Frodin of [[Chelsea Physic Garden]] ranked it as the 31st largest genus).<ref name = Frodin1994>{{cite journal | last = Frodin | first = David G. | year = 2004| title = History and concepts of big plant genera | journal = Taxon | volume = 53 | issue = 3 | pages = 753–776 | doi = 10.2307/4135449 | jstor = 4135449}}</ref> ''Ficus aurea'' is classified in the [[subgenus]] ''Urostigma'' (the strangler figs) and the [[section (botany)|section]] ''Americana''.<ref name = Berg2007/> Recent molecular [[Phylogenetics|phylogenies]] have shown that subgenus ''Urostigma'' is [[polyphyletic]], but have strongly supported the validity of section ''Americana'' as a [[clade|discrete group]] (although its exact relationship to section ''Galoglychia'' is unclear).<ref name="Rønsted">{{cite journal | last = Rønsted | first = N. | author2 = Weiblen, G. D.| author3 = Clement, W. L.| author4 = Zerega, N. J. C.| author5 = Savolainen, V. | year = 2008 | title = Reconstructing the phylogeny of figs (Ficus, Moraceae) to reveal the history of the fig pollination mutualism | journal = Symbiosis | volume = 45 | issue = 1–3 | pages = 45–56 | url = http://geo.cbs.umn.edu/RonstedEtAl2008a.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref>

[[File:Ficusindicamaxima.jpg|thumb|left|Engraving of ''Ficus maxima indica'' after a drawing by Hans Sloane, the earliest published illustration of ''Ficus aurea'' and the basis of Thomas Miller's ''[[Ficus maxima]]''. The unpaired figs in the illustration led to confusion as to the identity of the species described by Miller.]]
[[Thomas Nuttall]] described the species in the second volume of the his 1846 work ''The North American Sylva''<ref name = Berg2003/> with specific epithet ''aurea'' ('golden' in [[Latin]]).<ref>{{cite book|author = Simpson DP| title = Cassell's Latin Dictionary | publisher = Cassell Ltd| year = 1979|edition = 5|location = London|page = 883| isbn=0-304-52257-0}}</ref> In 1768, Scottish botanist [[Philip Miller]] described ''[[Ficus maxima]]'', citing [[Carl Linnaeus]]' ''[[Hortus Cliffortianus]]'' (1738) and [[Hans Sloane]]'s ''Catalogus plantarum quæ in insula Jamaica'' (1696). Sloane's illustration of the species, published in 1725, depicted it with figs borne singly, a characteristic of the ''Ficus'' subgenus ''[[Pharmacosycea]]''.<ref>{{cite book| last =Sloane | first =Hans | authorlink = Hans Sloane | title =A voyage to the islands Madera, Barbados, Nieves, S. Christophers and Jamaica | publisher =B.M | year =1725 | url = }}</ref> As a member of the subgenus ''[[Urostigma]]'', ''F. aurea'' has paired figs. However, a closer examination of Sloane's description led Cornelis Berg to conclude that the illustration depicted a member of the subgenus ''Urostigma'' (since it had other diagnostic of that subgenus), almost certainly ''F. aurea'', and that the illustration of singly borne figs was probably [[artistic license]]. Berg located the plant collection upon which Sloane's illustration was based and concluded that Miller's ''F. maxima'' was, in fact, ''F. aurea''.<ref name = Berg2003>{{cite journal | last = Berg | first = Cornelis C. |date=May 2003 | title = (1587–1590) Proposals to conserve the names ''Ficus citrifolia'' against ''F. caribaea'', ''F. maxima'' with a conserved type, ''F. aurea'' against ''F. ciliolosa'', and ''F. americana'' against ''F. perforata'' (Moraceae) | journal = Taxon | volume = 52 | issue = 2 | pages = 368–370 | doi = 10.2307/3647421 | jstor = 3647421 }}</ref> In his description of ''F. aurea'', which was based on plant material collected in Florida, Thomas Nuttall considered the possibility that his plants belonged to the species that Sloane had described, but came to the conclusion that it was a new species.<ref name = Berg2003/> Under the rules of [[botanical nomenclature]], the name ''F. maxima'' has priority over ''F. aurea'' since Miller's description was published in 1768, while Nuttall's description was published in 1846.

In their 1914 ''Flora of Jamaica'', [[William Fawcett (botanist)|William Fawcett]] and [[Alfred Barton Rendle]] linked Sloane's illustration to the tree species that was then known as ''Ficus suffocans'', a name that had been assigned to it in [[August Grisebach]]'s ''Flora of the British West Indian Islands''.<ref name = Griseb>{{cite book|last=Grisebach|first=August |authorlink=August Grisebach|title=Flora of the British West Indian Islands|url=http://www.botanicus.org/bibliography/b11788513|accessdate=2008-07-02|volume=1|publisher=L. Reeve & Co|location=London|year=1859}}</ref> Gordon DeWolf agreed with their conclusion and used the name ''F. maxima'' for that species in the 1960 ''Flora of Panama''.<ref name=DeWolf>DeWolf, Gordon P., Jr. "Ficus (Tourn.) L." in {{cite journal|author=Nevling, Lorin I., Jr.|year=1960 |jstor=2394704 |title=Flora of Panama. Part IV. Fascicle II|journal=Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden|volume=47|issue=2|pages=81–203|doi=10.2307/2394704}}</ref> Since this use has become widespread, Berg proposed that the name ''Ficus maxima'' be [[Conserved name|conserved]] in the way DeWolf had used it,<ref name = Berg2003/> a proposal that was accepted by the nomenclatural committee.<ref name = Brummitt2005>{{cite journal | last = Brummitt | first = R.K. | year = 2005 | title = Report of the Committee for Spermatophyta: 56 | journal = Taxon | volume = 54 | issue = 2 | pages = 527–536 | doi = 10.2307/25065389 | jstor = 25065389}}</ref>

Reassigning the name ''Ficus maxima'' did not leave ''F. aurea'' as the oldest name for this species, as German naturalist [[Johann Heinrich Friedrich Link]] had described ''Ficus ciliolosa'' in 1822. Berg concluded that the species Link described was actually ''F. aurea'', and since Link's description predated Nuttall's by 24 years, priority should have been given to the name ''F. ciliolosa''. Since the former name was widely used and the name ''F. ciliolosa'' had not been, Berg proposed that the name ''F. aurea'' be conserved.<ref name = Berg2003/> In response to this, the nomenclatural committee ruled that rather than conserving ''F. aurea'', that it would be better to reject ''F. ciliolosa''. Conserving ''F. aurea'' would mean that precedence would be given to that name over all others. By simply rejecting ''F. ciliolosa'', the committee left open the possibility that the name ''F. aurea'' could be supplanted by another older name, if one were to be discovered.<ref name = Brummitt2005/>

===Synonyms===
In 1920, American botanist [[Paul Carpenter Standley|Paul C. Standley]] described three new species based on collections from Panama and Costa Rica—''Ficus tuerckheimii'', ''F. isophlebia'' and ''F. jimenezii''.<ref name = Standl>{{cite journal |last=Standley |first=Paul C. |authorlink= Paul Carpenter Standley |year=1920 |title=The Mexican and Central American Species of Ficus |journal=Contributions from the United States National Herbarium |volume=20 |issue=1 |pages=1–35 |url=http://www.botanicus.org/page/373799}}</ref> DeWolf concluded that they were all the same species,<ref name=DeWolf/> and Berg synonymised them with ''F. aurea''.<ref name = Berg2007/> These names have been used widely for Mexican and Central American populations, and continue to be used by some authors. Berg suspected that ''Ficus rzedowskiana'' Carvajal and Cuevas-Figueroa may also belong to this species, but he had not examined the original material upon which this species was based.<ref name = Berg2007/>

Berg considered ''F. aurea'' to be a species with at least four [[Polymorphism (biology)|morphs]]. "None of the morphs", he wrote, "can be related to certain habitats or altitudes."<ref name = Berg2007/> Thirty years earlier, William Burger had come to a very different conclusion with respect to ''Ficus tuerckheimii'', ''F. isophlebia'' and ''F. jimenezii''—he rejected DeWolf's synonymisation of these three species as based on incomplete evidence. Burger noted that the three taxa occupied different habitats which could be separated in terms of rainfall and elevation.<ref name = Burger1974>{{cite journal | last= Burger |first= William C. |title= Ecological Differentiation in Some Congeneric Species of Costa Rican Flowering Plants |journal= Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden |volume= 61 |issue= 2 |pages= 297–306 |doi = 10.2307/2395057 |year = 1974 |jstor = 2395057}}</ref>

==Reproduction and growth==
Figs have an obligate [[Mutualism (biology)|mutualism]] with [[fig wasp]]s, (Agaonidae); figs are only pollinated by fig wasps, and fig wasps can only reproduce in fig flowers. Generally, each fig species depends on a single species of wasp for pollination. The wasps are similarly dependent on their fig species in order to reproduce. ''Ficus aurea'' is pollinated by ''[[Pegoscapus mexicanus]]'' ([[William Harris Ashmead|Ashmead]]).<ref name = Jousselin2001>{{cite journal | last = Jousselin| first = Emmanuelle | author2 = Hossaert-Mckey, Martine| author3 = Vernet, Didier| author4 = Kjellberg, Finn | year = 2001 | title = Egg deposition patterns of fig pollinating wasps: implications for studies on the stability of the mutualism | journal = Ecological Entomology | volume = 26 | issue = 6 | pages = 602–608 | doi = 10.1046/j.1365-2311.2001.00368.x }}</ref>

Figs have complicated [[inflorescence]]s called [[syconium|syconia]]. Flowers are entirely contained within an enclosed structure. Their only connection with the outside is through a small pore called [[ostiole]]. [[Monoecious]] figs like ''F. aurea'' have both male and female flowers within the syconium.<ref name = Janzen1979>{{cite journal | last = Janzen | first = Daniel H. | authorlink = Daniel Janzen | year = 1979 | title = How to be a fig | journal = Annual Review of Ecology and Systematics | volume = 10 | pages = 13–51 | doi = 10.1146/annurev.es.10.110179.000305 }}</ref> Female flowers mature first. Once mature, they produce a [[Volatility (chemistry)|volatile]] chemical attractant.<ref name = Bronstein1995>{{cite journal | last = Bronstein | first = Judith L. |author2=Hossaert-McKey, Martine | year = 1995 | title = Hurricane Andrew and a Florida Fig Pollination Mutualism: Resilience of an Obligate Interaction | journal = Biotropica | volume = 27 | issue = 3 | pages = 373–381 | doi = 10.2307/2388922 | jstor = 2388922 }}</ref> Female wasps squeeze their way through the ostiole into the interior of the syconium. Inside the syconium, they pollinate the flowers, lay their eggs in some of them, and die. The eggs hatch and the larvae parasitise the flowers in which they were laid. After four to seven weeks (in ''F. aurea''), adult wasps emerge. Males emerge first, mate with the females, and cut exit holes through the walls of the fig. The male flowers mature around the same time as the female wasps emerge. The newly emerged female wasps actively pack their bodies with pollen from the male flowers before leaving through the exit holes the males have cut and fly off to find a syconium in which to lay their eggs. Over the next one to five days, figs ripen.<ref name = Bronstein1995/> The ripe figs are eaten by various mammals and birds which [[seed dispersal|disperse]] the seeds.

===Phenology===
Figs flower and fruit asynchronously.<ref name=B&P1992a>{{cite journal | last = Bronstein | first = Judith L. |author2=Patel, Aviva | year = 1992 | title = Causes and Consequences of Within-Tree Phenological Patterns in the Florida Strangling Fig, Ficus aurea (Moraceae) | journal = [[American Journal of Botany]] | volume = 79 | issue = 1 | pages = 41–48 | doi = 10.2307/2445195 | jstor = 2445195 }}</ref> Flowering and fruiting is staggered throughout the population. This fact is important for fig wasps—female wasps need to find a syconium in which to lay their eggs within a few days of emergence, something that would not be possible if all the trees in a population flowered and fruited at the same time. This also makes figs important food resources for [[frugivore]]s (animals that feed nearly exclusively on fruit); figs are one of the few fruit available at times of the year when fruit are scarce.

Although figs flower asynchronously as a population, in most species flowering is synchronised within an individual. Newly emerged female wasps must move away from their natal tree in order to find figs in which to lay their eggs. This is to the advantage of the fig, since it prevents [[self-pollination]].<ref name = Janzen1979/> In Florida, individual ''F. aurea'' trees flower and fruit asynchronously.<ref name=B&P1992a/> Within-tree asynchrony in flowering is likely to raise the probability of self-pollination, but it may be an adaptation that allows the species to maintain an adequate population of wasps at low population densities or in strongly seasonal climates.<ref name=B&P1992a/>

{| width=100% class="wikitable" style="margin:auto;"
|colspan="3" align="center" style="background-color: #D3D3A4;"|'''Flowering phenology in ''Ficus aurea'''''
|-
!width=15% | Phase<ref name = Bronstein1995/>
!width=65% | Description<ref name = Bronstein1995/>
!width=20% | Duration in ''F. aurea''<ref name = Bronstein1995/>
|-
|A (pre-female)
|Immature flowers
|2 days to >9 months
|-
|B (female)
|Female flowers are receptive to pollination; female wasps lay eggs and pollinate flowers
|1 day to 3 weeks
|-
|C (interfloral)
|Fig seeds and wasp larvae develop
|4 to 7 weeks
|-
|D (male)
|Male flowers mature; wasps emerge, mate and female wasps disperse
|1 to 2 days
|-
|E (post-floral)
|Fruits ripen
|1 to 5 days
|-
|}

Flowering [[phenology]] in ''Ficus'' has been characterised into five phases. In most figs, phase A is followed almost immediately by phase B. However, in ''F. aurea'' immature inflorescences can remain dormant for more than nine months.<ref name=B&P1992a/>

[[File:Ficus aurea.JPG|thumb|right|200px|A Florida strangler fig with abundant [[adventitious root]]s at [[Villa Vizcaya]], [[Miami, Florida|Miami]]]]

===Growth===
''Ficus aurea'' is a fast-growing tree.<ref name = enviroscaping>{{cite web |last=Broschat |first= Timothy K. |author2=Alan W. Meerow |author3=Robert J. Black  |date=February 2007 |title=Enviroscaping to Conserve Energy: Trees for South Florida |publisher=Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences (Circular EES-42) |url=http://edis.ifas.ufl.edu/EH142 |accessdate=2008-06-10}}</ref> As a [[hemiepiphyte]] it [[Germination|germinates]] in the [[Canopy (forest)|canopy]] of a host tree and begin life as an [[epiphyte]] before growing roots down to the ground. ''F. aurea'' is also a [[strangler fig]] (not all hemiepiphytic figs are stranglers)—the roots [[anastomosis|fuse]] and encircle the host tree. This usually results in the death of the host tree, since it effectively [[girdling|girdles]] the tree. [[Arecaceae|Palms]], which lack [[secondary growth]], are not affected by this, but they can still be harmed by competition for light, water and nutrients.<ref name = Putz1989>{{cite journal | last = Putz | first = Francis E. |author2=N. Michele Holbrook | year = 1989 | title = Strangler Fig Rooting Habits and Nutrient Relations in the Llanos of Venezuela | journal = American Journal of Botany | volume = 76 | issue = 6 | pages = 781–788 | doi = 10.2307/2444534 | jstor = 2444534 }}</ref> Following [[Hurricane Andrew]] in 1992, ''F. aurea'' trees regenerated from [[Basal shoot|root suckers]] and standing trees.<ref name = Horvitz1998>{{cite journal | last = Horvitz | first = Carol C. | author2 = Pascarella, John B.| author3 = McMann, Stephen| author4 = Freedman, Andrea| author5 = Hofstetter, Ronald H. | year = 1988 | title = Functional Roles of Invasive Non-Indigenous Plants in Hurricane-Affected Subtropical Hardwood Forests | journal = Ecological Applications | volume = 8 | issue = 4 | pages = 947–974 |doi = 10.1890/1051-0761(1998)008[0947:FROINI]2.0.CO;2 | issn = 1051-0761}}</ref>

==Distribution==
''Ficus aurea'' ranges from Florida, across the northern Caribbean to Mexico, and south across Central America. It is present in central and southern Florida and the [[Florida Keys]],<ref name=Little>{{cite book |last=Little |first=Elbert L., Jr. |year=1978 |title=Atlas of United States Trees, Volume 5: Florida |location=Washington, D.C. |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |oclc=241660}} <!--this might be best done using {{tl|cite encyclopedia}}--></ref> The Bahamas, the Caicos Islands, Hispaniola, Cuba, Jamaica, the Cayman Islands, [[Archipelago of San Andrés, Providencia and Santa Catalina|San Andrés]] (a Colombian possession in the western Caribbean),<ref name = Berg2007/> southern Mexico,<ref name=Serrato2004>{{cite journal | last = Serrato | first = Alejandra | author2 = Ibarra-Manríquez, Guillermo| author3 = Oyama, Ken |date=March 2004 | title = Biogeography and conservation of the genus ''Ficus'' (Moraceae) in Mexico | journal = [[Journal of Biogeography]] | volume = 31 | issue = 3 | pages = 475–485 | url = http://www.blackwell-synergy.com/doi/abs/10.1046/j.0305-0270.2003.01039.x | doi = 10.1046/j.0305-0270.2003.01039.x }} <!--non-working doi removed temporarily: 10.1046/j.0305-0270.2003.01039.x--></ref> Belize, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, El Salvador, Costa Rica and Panama.<ref name = FloraMesoamericana>[http://www.tropicos.org/MobotProjects.aspx?project=flmaname&nameid=21300459 Ficus aurea Nutt.] Flora Mesoamericana: Lista Anotada. {{es icon}} Retrieved on 2008-07-02</ref> It grows from sea level up to 1,800 m (5,500 ft) [[above sea level]],<ref name = Berg2007/> in habitats ranging from [[Bahamian dry forests]],<ref name=Swagel/> to [[cloud forest]] in Costa Rica.<ref name=Sillett1995>{{cite journal | last = Sillett | first = Stephen C. | author2 = Gradstein, S. Rob| author3 = Griffin, Dana, III | year = 1995 | title = Bryophyte Diversity of Ficus Tree Crowns from Cloud Forest and Pasture in Costa Rica | journal = [[The Bryologist]] | volume = 98 | issue = 2 | pages = 251–260 | doi = 10.2307/3243312| jstor = 3243312 }}</ref>

''Ficus aurea'' is found in central and southern Florida as far north as [[Volusia County, Florida|Volusia County]];<ref>{{cite web |title=''Ficus aurea'': Distribution Map |url=http://www.plantatlas.usf.edu/maps.asp?plantID=2466 |work=Atlas of Florida Vascular Plants |publisher=Institute for Systematic Botany, University of South Florid |accessdate=2008-06-10}}</ref> it is one of only two native fig species in Florida.<ref name = Bessey1908/> The species is present in a range of south Florida ecosystems, including coastal hardwood [[hammock (ecology)|hammocks]], [[Sabal palmetto|cabbage palm]] hammocks,
[[tropical hardwood hammocks]] and shrublands, temperate hardwood hammocks and shrublands<ref>{{cite web |author=Ken Rutchey |url=http://sofia.usgs.gov/publications/ofr/2006-1240/ |title=Vegetation Classification for South Florida Natural Areas |year=2006 |publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]] |accessdate=2008-06-10 |display-authors=etal}} Open-File Report 2006-1240. <!--this needs to cite the specific page, otherwise it is useless as a web citation --></ref> and along watercourses.<ref name = Bronstein1995/> In The Bahamas, ''F. aurea'' is found in [[Bahamian dry forests|tropical dry forests]] on [[North Andros]],<ref name = Smith1992>{{cite journal | last = Smith | first = Inge K. |author2=Vankat, John L. | year = 1992 | title = Dry Evergreen Forest (Coppice) Communities of North Andros Island, Bahamas | journal = Bulletin of the Torrey Botanical Club | volume = 119 | issue = 2 | pages = 181–191 | doi = 10.2307/2997030 | jstor = 2997030 }}</ref> [[Great Exuma]]<ref name=Swagel/> and [[Bimini]].<ref>{{cite journal | last = Howard | first = Richard A. | year = 1950 | title = Vegetation of the Bimini Island Group: Bahamas, B. W. I | journal = Ecological Monographs | volume = 20 | issue = 4 | pages = 317–349 | doi = 10.2307/1943569 | jstor = 1943569 }}</ref> ''F. aurea'' occurs in 10 [[Administrative divisions of Mexico#States|states]] in Mexico, primarily in the south, but extending as far north as [[Jalisco]].<ref name=Serrato2004/> It is found in tropical deciduous forest, tropical semi-evergreen forest, tropical evergreen forest, cloud forest and in aquatic or subaquatic habitats.<ref name=Serrato2004/>

==Ecology==
[[File:Rubber, or Banyan Tree, on Banana River, Florida.jpg|thumb|right|200px|''Rubber, or Banyan Tree, on [[Banana River (Florida)|Banana River, Florida]]''—an 1893 photograph of what is now known as a Florida strangler fig]]
''Ficus aurea'' is a strangler fig—it tends to establish on a host tree which it gradually encircles and "strangles", eventually taking the place of that tree in the forest canopy. While this makes ''F. aurea'' an agent in the mortality of other trees, there is little to indicate that its choice of hosts is species specific. However, in [[Bahamian dry forests|dry forests]] on [[Great Exuma]] in The Bahamas, ''F. aurea'' establishes exclusively on [[Arecaceae|palms]], in spite of the presence of several other large trees that should provide suitable hosts. Eric Swagel and colleagues attributed this to the fact that [[humus]] accumulates on the leaf bases of these palms and provides a relatively moist [[microclimate]] in a dry environment, facilitating seedling survival.<ref name=Swagel>{{cite journal | last = Swagel | first = Eric N. | author2 = Bernhard, A. Van H.| author3 = Ellmore, George S. | year = 1997 | title = Substrate water potential constraints on germination of the strangler fig ''Ficus aurea'' (Moraceae) | journal = American Journal of Botany | volume = 84 | issue = 5 | pages = 716–722 | url = http://www.amjbot.org/cgi/content/abstract/84/5/716 | doi = 10.2307/2445908 | jstor = 2445908 }}</ref>

Figs are sometimes considered to be potential [[keystone species]] in communities of [[frugivore|fruit-eating animals]] because of their [[wikt:asynchrony|asynchronous]] fruiting patterns.<ref name=Terborgh1986>{{cite book|last=Terborgh|first=John|editor=[[Michael E. Soulé]] (ed.)|title=Conservation Biology: The Science of Scarcity and Diversity|year=1986|publisher=Sinauer Associates|location=Sunderland, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-87893-795-0|pages=330–344|chapter=Keystone plant resources in the tropical forests}}</ref> Nathaniel Wheelwright reports that [[emerald toucanet]]s fed on unripe ''F. aurea'' fruit at times of fruit scarcity in [[Monteverde]], [[Costa Rica]].<ref>{{cite journal | last = Wheelwright | first = Nathaniel T. |date=June 1985 | title = Competition for dispersers, and the timing of flowering and fruiting in a guild of tropical trees | journal = [[Oikos (journal)|Oikos]] | volume = 44 | pages = 465–477 | url = http://www.bowdoin.edu/faculty/n/nwheelwr/pdf/Compfordisp.pdf |format=PDF| doi = 10.2307/3565788 | issue = 3 | jstor = 3565788}}</ref> Wheelwright listed the species as a year-round food source for the [[resplendent quetzal]] at the same site.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Wheelwright | first = Nathaniel T. | year = 1983 | title = Fruits and the Ecology of Resplendent Quetzals | journal = [[The Auk]] | volume = 100 | issue = 2 | pages = 286–301 | url = http://sora.unm.edu/sites/default/files/journals/auk/v100n02/p0286-p0301.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref> In the [[Florida Keys]], ''F. aurea'' is one of five fruit species that dominate the diet fed by [[white-crowned pigeon]]s to their nestlings.<ref name = Bancroft1994>{{cite journal | last = Bancroft | first = G. Thomas |author2=Reed Bowman | year = 1994 | title = Temporal Patterns in Diet of Nestling White-Crowned Pigeons: Implications for Conservation of Frugivorous Columbids | journal = The Auk | volume = 111 | issue = 4 | pages = 844–52 | url = http://sora.unm.edu/sites/default/files/journals/auk/v111n04/p0844-p0852.pdf |format=PDF | doi = 10.2307/4088816}}</ref> ''F. aurea'' is also important in the diet of mammalian frugivores—both fruit and young leaves are consumed by [[Guatemalan Black Howler|black howler monkeys]] in Belize.<ref name = Silver1999>{{cite journal | last = Silver | first = S. C. | author2 = L. E. T. Ostro| author3 = C. P. Yeager| author4 = R. Horwich | year = 1999 | title = Feeding ecology of the black howler monkey (''Alouatta pigra'') in Northern Belize | journal = American Journal of Primatology | volume = 45 | issue = 3 | pages = 263–279 |url=http://www.communityconservation.org/publications/feedeco98.pdf |format=PDF|pmid=9651649 | doi = 10.1002/(SICI)1098-2345(1998)45:3<263::AID-AJP3>3.0.CO;2-U }}</ref>

The interaction between figs and [[fig wasp]]s is especially well-known (see section on [[Ficus aurea#Reproduction and growth|reproduction]], above). In addition to its pollinators (''Pegoscapus mexicanus''), ''F. aurea'' is exploited by a group of non-pollinating [[Chalcid wasp|chalcidoid wasps]] whose larvae develop in its figs. These include [[gall]]ers, [[inquiline]]s and [[kleptoparasite]]s as well as [[parasitoid]]s of both the pollinating and non-pollinating wasps.<ref name = Bronstein1999>{{cite journal | last = Bronstein | first = Judith L. | year = 1999 | title = Natural History of ''Anidarnes bicolor'' (Hymenoptera: Agaonidae), a Galler of the Florida Strangling Fig (''Ficus aurea'') | journal = Florida Entomologist | volume = 82 | issue = 3 | pages = 454–461 | url = http://www.fcla.edu/FlaEnt/fe82p454.pdf |format=PDF | doi = 10.2307/3496871 | jstor = 3496871}}</ref>

The invertebrates within ''F. aurea'' syconia in southern Florida include a pollinating wasp, ''P. mexicanus'', up to eight or more species of non-pollinating wasps, a plant-parasitic nematode transported by the pollinator, mites, and a predatory rove beetle whose adults and larvae eat fig wasps.<ref name = Nadel1992>{{cite journal | last = Nadel | first = Hannah | author2 = Frank, J. Howard| author3 = Knight, R. J., Jr. |date=March 1992 | title = Escapees and Accomplices: The Naturalization of Exotic ''Ficus'' and Their Associated Faunas in Florida | journal = Florida Entomologist | volume = 75 | issue = 1 | pages = 29–38 | doi = 10.2307/3495478 | jstor = 3495478 }}</ref>
Nematodes: ''Schistonchus aureus'' (Aphelenchoididae) is a plant-parasitic nematode associated with the pollinator ''Pegoscapus mexicanus'' and syconia of  ''F. aurea''.<ref name = Decrappeo2001>{{cite journal  | last = Decrappeo |  first = N. |author2=Giblin-Davis, R. M. | year = 2001 | title = ''Schistonchus aureus'' n. sp. and ''S. laevigatus'' n. sp. (Aphelenchoididae): Associates of native Floridian ''Ficus'' spp. and their ''Pegoscapus'' pollinators (Agaonidae) |  journal = Journal of Nematology | volume = 33 |  pages =  91–103 | pmid = 19266003  | issue = 2–3  | pmc = 2638131 }}</ref> 
Mites: belonging to the family Tarsonemidae (Acarina) have been recognized in the syconia of ''F. aurea'' and ''F. citrifolia'', but they have not been identified even to genus, and their behavior is undescribed.<ref name="Nadel1992" />
Rove beetles: ''Charoxus spinifer'' is a rove beetle (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae) whose adults enter late-stage syconia of ''F. aurea'' and ''F. citrifolia''.<ref name ="  Frank1997">{{cite journal | last = Frank | first = J. H. |author2=Thomas, M. C. | year = 1997 | title = A new species of  ''Charoxus'' (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae) from native figs (''Ficus'' spp.) in Florida |  journal = Journal of the New York Entomological Society | volume = 104 | pages = 70–78 }}</ref> Adults eat fig wasps; larvae develop within the syconia and prey on fig wasps, then pupate in the ground.<ref name ="  Frank2012">{{cite journal | last = Frank | first = J. H. |author2=Nadel, Hannah | year = 2012 | title = Life cycle and behaviour of Charoxus spinifer and Charoxus major (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Aleocharinae), predators of fig wasps (Hymenoptera: Agaonidae) | journal = Journal of Natural History | volume = 46 |  pages =  621–635 |  doi = 10.1080/00222933.2011.651641 | issue = 9–10 }}</ref>

As a large tree, ''F. aurea'' can be an important host for [[epiphyte]]s. In Costa Rican cloud forests, where ''F. aurea'' is "the most conspicuous component" of intact forest,<ref name=Sillett1995/> trees in forest patches supported richer communities of epiphytic [[bryophyte]]s, while isolated trees supported greater [[lichen]] cover.<ref name=Sillett1995/>

[[Florida International University]] ecologist Suzanne Koptur reported the presence of [[Nectar#Extrafloral nectaries|extrafloral nectaries]] on ''F. aurea'' figs in the Florida [[Everglades]].<ref name = Koptur1992>{{cite journal | last = Koptur | first = Suzanne | year = 1992 | title = Plants with Extrafloral Nectaries and Ants in Everglades Habitats | journal = Florida Entomologist | volume = 75 | issue = 1 | pages = 38–50 | url = http://www.fiu.edu/%7Ekopturs/pubs/SK92FlaEnt.pdf|format=PDF| doi = 10.2307/3495479 | jstor = 3495479}}</ref> Extrafloral nectaries are structures which produce [[nectar]] but are not associated with flowers. They are usually interpreted as defensive structure and are often produced in response to attack by insect [[herbivore]]s.<ref name = Heil2007>{{cite journal | last = Heil | first = Martin | year = 2007 | title = Indirect defence via tritrophic interactions | journal = New Phytologist | volume = 178 | issue = 1 | pages = 41–61 | url = http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/119394700/abstract | doi = 10.1111/j.1469-8137.2007.02330.x | pmid = 18086230 }}</ref> They attract insects, primarily [[ant]]s, which defend the nectaries, thus protecting the plant against herbivores.<ref name = Bronstein2006>{{cite journal | last = Bronstein | first = Judith L.| author2 = Alarcón, Ruben| author3 = Geber, Monica| year = 2006 | title = The evolution of plant–insect mutualisms | journal = New Phytologist | volume = 172 | issue = 3 | pages = 412–428 | url = http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/118627369/abstract?CRETRY=1&SRETRY=0 | doi = 10.1111/j.1469-8137.2006.01864.x | pmid = 17083673 }}</ref>

==Uses==
The fruit of ''Ficus aurea'' is edible and was used for food by the indigenous people and early settlers in Florida; it is still eaten occasionally as a backyard source of native fruit. The latex was used to make a chewing gum, and aerial roots may have been used to make lashings, arrows, bowstrings and fishing lines. The fruit was used to make a rose-coloured dye.<ref name = FLEthnobot>{{cite web |last=Allen |first=Ginger M. |author2=Bond, Michael D. |author3=Main, Martin B.  |date=December 2002 |title=50 Common Native Plants Important In Florida's Ethnobotanical History |publisher=[[Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences]] (Circular 1439) |url=http://edis.ifas.ufl.edu/UW152 |accessdate=2008-06-10}}</ref> ''F. aurea'' was also used in [[traditional medicine]] in The Bahamas<ref>{{cite journal | last = Eldridge | first = Joan |date=October 1975 | title = Bush medicine in the Exumas and Long Island, Bahamas. A field study | journal = Economic Botany | volume = 29 | issue = 4 | pages = 307–332 | doi =10.1007/BF02862180 | url = http://www.springerlink.com/content/a52r873318238180/}}</ref> and Florida.<ref name = FLEthnobot/> Allison Adonizio and colleagues screened ''F. aurea'' for anti-[[quorum sensing]] activity (as a possible means of anti-bacterial action), but found no such activity.<ref name = Adonizio2006>{{cite journal | last = Adonizio | first = Allison L. | author2 = Downum, Kelsey| author3 = Bennett, Bradley C.| author4 = Mathee, Kalai | year = 2006 | title = Anti-quorum sensing activity of medicinal plants in southern Florida | journal = Journal of Ethnopharmacology | volume = 105 | issue = 3 | pages = 427–435 | doi = 10.1016/j.jep.2005.11.025 | pmid = 16406418 }}</ref>

Individual ''F. aurea'' trees are common on dairy farms in La Cruz, Cañitas and [[Santa Elena, Costa Rica|Santa Elena]] in Costa Rica, since they are often spared when forest is converted to [[pasture]]. In interviews, farmers identified the species as useful for fence posts, [[Hedge#Live fencing|live fencing]] and firewood, and as a food species for wild birds and mammals.<ref name = Harvey1998>{{cite journal | last = Harvey | first = C. A. |author2=Haber, W. A. | year = 1998 | title = Remnant trees and the conservation of biodiversity in Costa Rican pastures | journal = Agroforestry Systems | volume = 44 | issue = 1 | pages = 37–68 | doi = 10.1023/A:1006122211692 | url = }}</ref>

''Ficus aurea'' is used as an [[Ornamental plant|ornamental tree]], an [[Houseplant|indoor tree]] and as a [[bonsai]].<ref name="IFAS"/> Like other figs, it tends to invade built structures and foundations, and need to be removed to prevent structural damage.<ref name="Nadel1992" /> Although young trees are described as "rather ornamental",<ref name = Bessey1908>{{cite journal | last = Bessey | first = Ernst A. | authorlink = Ernst Bessey | year = 1908 | title = The Florida Strangling Figs | journal = Missouri Botanical Garden Annual Report | volume = 1908 | pages = 25–33 | doi = 10.2307/2400063 | jstor = 2400063 }}</ref> older trees are considered to be difficult to maintain (because of the [[adventitious roots]] that develop off branches) and are not recommended for small areas.<ref name = IFAS/> However, it was considered a useful tree for "enviroscaping" to conserve energy in south Florida, since it is "not as aggressive as many exotic fig species," although it must be given enough space.<ref name = enviroscaping/>

''Ficus anthelmintica'' [[Carl Friedrich Philipp von Martius|Mart.]]
''Ficus crassiuscula'' [[Otto Warburg (botanist)|Warb.]] ex [[Paul Carpenter Standley|Standl.]]
''Ficus glabrata'' [[Carl Sigismund Kunth|Kunth]]
''Ficus mexicana'' ([[Friedrich Anton Wilhelm Miquel|Miq.]]) Miq.
''Ficus radulina'' [[Sereno Watson|S.Watson]]
''Ficus segoviae'' Miq.
''Ficus werckleana'' Rossberg
''Pharmacosycea angustifolia'' [[Frederik Michael Liebmann|Liebm.]] |}} '''''Ficus insipida''''' is a tropical tree in the [[Ficus|fig genus]] of the [[family (biology)|family]] [[Moraceae]]. It ranges from [[Mexico]] to [[South America]], and is commonly found in [[cloud forest]] above 1,550 meters [[Above mean sea level|ASL]].Haber (2000), MBG [2008a] __NOTOC__ ==Description and ecology== This is a tree with [[buttress root]]s which ranges from {{convert|8|–|40|m|ft|abbr=on}} tall. Although it is a freestanding tree when mature, ''F. insipida'' begins its growth as a climbing vine. It clings to a mature tree, eventually strangling it. Its favored hosts are ''[[Guarea tuisana]]'' and ''[[Sapium pachystachys]]'', and it is also frequently found on already-dead trees.DeWolf (1960), Daniels (1991) Leaves vary shape from narrow to ellipse-shaped; they range from {{convert|5|–|25|cm|in|abbr=on}} long and from {{convert|2|–|11|cm|in|abbr=on}} wide.DeWolf (1960) It flowers February to April and bears warty, yellow-green fruit 4–6 cm in diameter. Though they are edible like most figs, as the [[scientific name]] (literally "insipid fig") implies they are of unremarkable taste. Monkeys feed on fruits still on the tree, and fallen fruits are eaten by [[peccary|peccaries]]. Two [[subspecies]] can be distinguished: * ''Ficus insipida'' ssp. ''insipida'' Willd. * ''Ficus insipida'' ssp. ''scabra'' C.C.Berg ==Use by humans== The wood is soft, but it is used for construction purposes where durability is not important. ''Ficus insipida'' is used by ''wajacas'' ([[shaman]]s) of the [[Craós]] ([[Krahós]], [[Krahô]]) tribe in Brazil as a [[memory enhancer]].Rodrigues & Carlini (2006) Its [[latex]] is also employed in South American [[folk medicine]] as the [[anthelmintic]] called '''''ojé''''', but as it is toxic it must be used with care.Hansson ''et al.'' (2005) [[Maya codices]] (singular codex) are folding books stemming from the pre-Columbian [[Maya civilization]], written in Maya hieroglyphic script on Mesoamerican bark cloth, [[Amatl]], made from the inner bark of certain trees, the main being the wild fig tree or Amate (Ficus glabrata; a synonym of the Ficus insipida). ==Footnotes== {{Reflist}} ==References== * {{aut|Daniels, James D.}} (1991): Habitat and Host Preferences of ''Ficus crassiuscula'', A Neotropical Strangling Fig of the Lower-Montane Rain Forest. ''[[Journal of Ecology|J. Ecol.]]'' '''79'''(1): 129–141. * {{aut|DeWolf, Gordon P. Jr.}} (1960): ''Ficus'' (Tourn.) L.. ''In:'' {{aut|Nevling, Lorin I. Jr.}}: Flora of Panama. Part IV. Fascicle II. ''[[Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden|Ann. MO Bot. Gard.]]'' '''47'''(2): 81–203. [http://www.jstor.org/pss/2394704 First page image] * {{aut|Haber, William}} (2000): ''An Introduction to Cloud Forest Trees''. Mountain Gem Publications, Monteverde de Puntarenas, Costa Rica. ISBN 9977-12-418-3 * {{aut|Hansson, Anders; Zelada, Julio C. & Noriega, Hugo P.}} (2005): Reevaluation of risks with the use of ''Ficus insipida'' latex as a traditional anthelmintic remedy in the Amazon. ''Journal of Ethnopharmacology'' '''98'''(3): 251–257. {{doi|10.1016/j.jep.2004.12.029}} (HTML abstract) * {{aut|[[Missouri Botanical Garden]] (MBG)}} [2008a]: Flora de Nicaragua – [http://mobot.mobot.org/cgi-bin/search_vast?FLNIONDAD=21300606 ''Ficus insipida''] [in Spanish]. Retrieved 2008-NOV-01. * {{aut|[[Missouri Botanical Garden]] (MBG)}} [2008b]: Tropicos.org – [http://www.tropicos.org/NameSynonyms.aspx?nameid=21300606 ''Ficus insipida'' synonyms]. Retrieved 2008-JUN-29. * {{aut|Rodrigues, Eliana & Carlini, E.A.}} (2006): Plants with possible psychoactive effects used by the Krahô Indians, Brazil. ''Revista Brasileira de Psiquiatria'' '''28'''(4): 277–282. ''Urostigma protensum'' Griseb.{{cite web|url= http://www.tropicos.org/NameSynonyms.aspx?nameid=21300608|title= ''Ficus maxima'' Mill. Synonyms|accessdate= 2008-06-27|work= Tropicos.org|publisher= [[Missouri Botanical Garden]]}} |}} '''''Ficus maxima''''' is a [[ficus|fig]] tree which is native to [[Mexico]], [[Central America]], the [[Caribbean]] and [[South America]] south to [[Paraguay]]. Figs belong to the family [[Moraceae]]. The specific epithet ''maxima'' was coined by Scottish botanist [[Philip Miller]] in 1768; Miller's name was applied to this species in the ''Flora of Jamaica'', but it was later determined that Miller's description was actually of the species now known as ''[[Ficus aurea]]''. To avoid confusion, Cornelis Berg proposed that the name should be conserved for this species. Berg's proposal was accepted in 2005. Individuals may reach heights of {{convert|30|m|ft|abbr=on}}. Like all figs it has an obligate [[Mutualism (biology)|mutualism]] with [[fig wasp]]s; ''F. maxima'' is only pollinated by the fig wasp ''[[Tetrapus americanus]]'', and ''T. americanus'' only reproduces in its flowers. ''F. maxima'' fruit and leaves are important food resources for a variety of birds and mammals. It is used in a number of [[herbal medicines]] across its range. ==Description== ''Ficus maxima'' is a tree which ranges from {{convert|5|–|30|m|ft|abbr=on}} tall. Leaves vary in shape from long and narrow to more oval, and range from 6–24 (cm) (2–9 in) long and from {{convert|2.5|–|12|cm|in|abbr=on}} wide.DeWolf, Gordon P., Jr. 1960. Ficus (Tourn.) L. ''In'' Lorin I. Nevling, Jr., [http://www.jstor.org/pss/2394704 Flora of Panama. Part IV. Fascicle II]. ''Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden'', '''47''' (2):81–203 ''F. maxima'' is [[Plant sexuality|monoecious]]; each tree bears functional male and female flowers.{{cite journal| last = Jousselin | first = Emmanuelle |author2=Finn Kjellberg |author3=Edward Allen Herre | year = 2004 | title = Flower specialization in a passively pollinated monoecious fig: A question of style and stigma? | journal = [[International Journal of Plant Sciences]] | volume = 165 | issue = 4 | pages = 587–593 | doi = 10.1086/386558 | url = http://www.cefe.cnrs.fr/coev/pdf/fk/Jousellin2004%20Int%20J%20Plant%20S.pdf |format=PDF}} The figs are borne singly and are {{convert|1|–|2|cm|in|abbr=on}} in diameter (sometimes up to 2.5 cm [1 in]).[http://mobot.mobot.org/cgi-bin/search_vast?FLNIONDAD=21300608 Flora de Nicaragua] database. Tropicos. {{es icon}} Retrieved on 2008-07-05. ==Taxonomy== With about 750 species, ''[[Ficus]]'' ([[Moraceae]]) is one of the largest [[angiosperm]] genera. (Frodin ranked it as the 31st largest.){{cite journal | last = Frodin | first = David G. | authorlink = | year = 2004 | title = History and concepts of big plant genera | journal = Taxon | volume = 53 | issue = 3 | pages = 753–776 | url = http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/iapt/tax/2004/00000053/00000003/art00012| doi = 10.2307/4135449 | jstor = 4135449 | publisher = Taxon, Vol. 53, No. 3 }} ''Ficus maxima'' is classified in subgenus ''[[Pharmacosycea]]'',{{cite journal | last = Berg | first = Cornelis C. |date=May 2003 | title = (1587–1590) Proposals to conserve the names ''Ficus citrifolia'' against ''F. caribaea'', ''F. maxima'' with a conserved type, ''F. aurea'' against ''F. ciliolosa'', and ''F. americana'' against ''F. perforata'' (Moraceae) | journal = Taxon | volume = 52 | issue = 2 | pages = 368–370 | doi = 10.2307/3647421| jstor = 3647421 | publisher = Taxon, Vol. 52, No. 2 }} section ''Pharmacosycea'', subsection ''Petenenses''.{{cite journal | last = Berg | first = C. C. | year = 2006 | title = The subdivision of ''Ficus'' subgenus ''Pharmacosycea'' Section ''Pharmacosycea'' (Moraceae) | journal = Blumea | volume = 51 | issue = 1 | pages = 147–151 | url = http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/nhn/blumea/2006/00000051/00000001/art00007?token=004216c88d56ff405847447b23562f2d4042423574794c583375686f230eb84d56 | doi=10.3767/000651906x622409}} Although recent work suggests that subgenus ''Pharmacosycea'' is [[polyphyletic]], section ''Pharmacosycea'' appears to be [[clade|monophyletic]] and is a [[Cladistics#Subtrees are clades|sister group]] to the rest of the genus ''Ficus''.{{cite journal | last = Rønsted | first = N. | authorlink = |author2=G.D. Weiblen |author3=W.L. Clement |author4=N.J.C. Zerega |author5=V. Savolainen | year = 2008 | title = Reconstructing the phylogeny of figs (Ficus, Moraceae) to reveal the history of the fig pollination mutualism | journal = Symbiosis | volume = 45 | issue = 1–3 | pages = 45–56 | url = http://geo.cbs.umn.edu/RonstedEtAl2008a.pdf |format=PDF}} [[File:Ficusindicamaxima.jpg|thumb|left|Hans Sloane's original illustration of ''Ficus maxima indica'', the earliest illustration of ''[[Ficus aurea]]'' and the basis of Thomas Miller's ''Ficus maxima''. The unpaired figs in the illustration led to confusion as to the identity of the species described by Miller.]]In 1768, [[Scottish people|Scottish]] botanist [[Philip Miller]] described ''Ficus maxima'',{{cite book|last=Miller|first=Philip |authorlink=Philip Miller|title=The Gardeners Dictionary: Containing the Best and Newest Methods of Cultivating and Improving The Kitchen, Fruit, Flower Garden, and Nursery; As also for Performing The Practical Parts of Agriculture: Including the Management of Vineyards, With The Methods of Making and Preserving Wine, According to the present Practice of The most skilful Vignerons in the several Wine Countries in ''Europe''. Together With Directions for Propagating and Improving, From Real Practice and Experience, All Sorts of Timber Trees|url=http://www.botanicus.org/title/b12066618|edition=Eighth|year=1768|publisher=Printed for the Author|location=London}} citing [[Carl Linnaeus|Linnaeus]]' ''[[Hortus Cliffortianus]]'' (1738) and [[Hans Sloane]]'s ''Catalogus plantarum quæ in insula Jamaica'' (1696). Sloane's illustration of this plant (published in his 1725 '' A voyage to the islands Madera, Barbados, Nieves, S. Christophers and Jamaica'') depicted it with figs borne singly, a characteristic of the ''Ficus'' subgenus ''Pharmacosycea''. A closer examination of Sloane's description led Cornelis Berg to conclude that the illustration depicted a member of the subgenus ''[[Urostigma]]'', almost certainly ''[[Ficus aurea|F. aurea]]'', and that the illustration of singly borne figs was probably [[artistic license]]. Berg located the plant collection upon which Sloane's illustration was based and concluded that Miller's ''F. maxima'' was, in fact, ''F. aurea''. In 1806 the name ''Ficus radula'' was applied to material belonging to this species. The description, based on material collected in [[Venezuela]] by [[Germans|German]] naturalist [[Alexander von Humboldt]] and [[French people|French]] botanist [[Aimé Bonpland]], was published in [[Carl Ludwig Willdenow]]'s fourth edition of Linnaeus' ''[[Species Plantarum]]''. This is the oldest description that can unequivocally be applied to this species. In 1847 [[Danish people|Danish]] botanist [[Frederik Michael Liebmann]] applied the name ''Pharmacosycea glaucescens'' to Mexican material belonging to this species. (It was transferred to the genus ''Ficus'' by [[Dutch (ethnic group)|Dutch]] botanist [[Friedrich Anton Wilhelm Miquel]] in 1867.) In 1849 the name ''Ficus suffocans'' was applied to Jamaican material belonging to this species in [[August Grisebach]]'s ''Flora of the British West Indian Islands''.{{cite book|last=Grisebach|first=August |authorlink=August Grisebach|title=Flora of the British West Indian Islands|url=http://www.botanicus.org/bibliography/b11788513|accessdate=2008-07-02|volume=1|publisher=L. Reeve & Co|location=London|year=1859}} In their 1914 ''Flora of Jamaica'', [[William Fawcett (botanist)|William Fawcett]] and [[Alfred Barton Rendle]] linked Sloane's illustration to ''F. suffocans''. Gordon DeWolf agreed with their conclusion and used the name ''F. maxima'' for that species in the 1960 ''Flora of Panama'', supplanting ''F. radula'' and ''F. glaucescens''. Since this use has become widespread, Berg proposed that the name ''Ficus maxima'' be [[Conserved name|conserved]] in the way DeWolf had used it with a new [[Biological type|type]] (Krukoff's 1934 collection from [[Amazonas (Brazilian state)|Amazonas]], [[Brazil]]). This proposal was accepted by the nomenclatural committee in 2005.{{cite journal | last = Brummitt | first = R.K. | authorlink = |date=May 2005 | title = Report of the Committee for Spermatophyta: 56 | journal = Taxon | volume = 54 | issue = 2 | pages = 527–536 | url = http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/iapt/tax/2005/00000054/00000002/art00036 | doi = 10.2307/25065389 | jstor = 25065389 | publisher = Taxon, Vol. 54, No. 2 }} ===Common names=== ''Ficus maxima'' ranges from the northern Caribbean to southern South America, in countries where English, Spanish, [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] and a variety of indigenous languages are spoken. Across this range, it is known by a variety of common names. {| width=50% class="wikitable" style="margin:auto;" |colspan="50%" align="center"|'''Common names of ''Ficus maxima''''' |- !width=20% | Common name !width=30% | Usage |- |''Amäk wäm'' |[[Lacandon people|Lacandon Maya]] in [[Chiapas]], [[Mexico]] |- |''Amate'' |[[Mexico]]{{cite journal|last=Kashanipour |first=Ryan Amir |authorlink= |author2=R. Jon McGee |year=2004 |title=Northern Lacandon Maya Medicinal Plant Use in the Communities of Lacanja Chan Sayab and Naha’, Chiapas, Mexico |journal=Journal of Ecological Anthropology |volume=8 |issue= |pages=47–66 |doi=10.5038/2162-4593.8.1.3 |url=http://shell.cas.usf.edu/~jea/PDFs/kashanipour.pdf |format=PDF }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} |- |''Caxinguba'' |[[Brazil]] |- |Hicatee Fig |[[Belize]]{{cite journal | last = Mars | first = Laura K. |author2=Bette A. Loiselle | year = 2003 | title = Recruitment of Black Howler Fruit Trees in Fragmented Forests of Northern Belize | journal = International Journal of Primatology | volume = 24 | issue = 1 | pages = 65–86 | doi = 10.1023/A:1021446512364 | url = http://www.springerlink.com/content/k870703wvj634185/ }} |- |''Higillo'' |[[Honduras]] |- |''Higueron'' |[[Ecuador]] |- |''Maja'' |[[Tacana]] of [[Bolivia]]{{cite journal | last = Bourdy | first = G. | authorlink = |author2=S. J. DeWalt |author3=L. R. Chávez de Michel |author4=A. Roca |author5=E. Deharo |author6=V. Muñoz |author7=L. Balderrama |author8=C. Quenevo |author9= A. Gimenez | year = 2000 | title = Medicinal plants uses of the Tacana, an Amazonian Bolivian ethnic group | journal = Journal of Ethnopharmacology | volume = 70 | issue = 2 | pages = 87–109 | doi = 10.1016/S0378-8741(99)00158-0 | url = | pmid = 10771199 }} |- |Matapal |[[Trinidad and Tobago]]{{cite journal | last = Homer | first = Floyd | authorlink = |author2=Kishore Lal |author3=Winston Johnson | year = 1998 | title = Forest species regeneration and management options in the Melajo Nature Reserve, Trinidad and Tobago | journal = Environmental Conservation | volume = 25 | issue = | pages = 53–64 | doi = 10.1017/S0376892998000095| url = http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=38273 }} |- |''Sàhàshá'' |[[Pech people|Paya]] of [[Honduras]] |- |White fig |[[Jamaica]]{{cite journal|last=Pregill |first=Gregory K. |authorlink= |author2=Ronald I. Crombie |author3=David W. Steadman |author4=Linda A. Gordon |author5=Frank W. Davis |author6=William B. Hilgartner |date=July 1991 |title=Living and late Holocene fossil vertebrates and the vegetation of the Cockpit Country, Jamaica |journal=Atoll Research Bulletin |volume=353 |pages=1–19 |url=http://www.botany.hawaii.edu/faculty/duffy/arb/348-354/353.pdf |format=PDF |doi=10.5479/si.00775630.353.1 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090919181449/http://www.botany.hawaii.edu/faculty/duffy/arb/348-354/353.pdf |archivedate=2009-09-19 |df= }} |- |} ==Reproduction== Figs have an obligate [[Mutualism (biology)|mutualism]] with [[fig wasp]]s (Agaonidae); figs are only pollinated by fig wasps, and fig wasps are only able to reproduce in fig flowers. Generally, each fig species depends on a single species of fig wasp for pollination, and each species of fig wasp can only reproduce in the flowers of a single species of fig tree. ''Ficus maxima'' is pollinated by ''[[Tetrapus americanus]]'', although recent work suggests that the species known as ''T. americanus'' is a [[cryptic species complex]] of at least two species, which are not [[Cladistics#Subtrees are clades|sister taxa]].{{cite journal | last = Molbo | first = Drude |author2=Carlos A. Machado |author3=Jan G. Sevenster |author4=Laurent Keller |author5=Edward Allen Herre | year = 2003 | title = Cryptic species of fig-pollinating wasps: Implications for the evolution of the fig–wasp mutualism, sex allocation, and precision of adaptation | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences USA | volume = 100 | issue = 10 | pages = 5867–72 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0930903100 | pmid = 12714682 | pmc = 156293 }} Figs have complicated [[inflorescence]]s called [[syconium|syconia]]. Flowers are entirely contained within an enclosed structure. Their only connection with the outside is through a small pore called [[ostiole]]. [[Monoecious]] figs like ''F. maxima'' have both male and female flowers within the syconium.{{cite journal | last = Janzen | first = Daniel H. | authorlink = Daniel Janzen | year = 1979 | title = How to be a fig | journal = Annual Review of Ecology and Systematics | volume = 10 | pages = 13–51 | issn = 0066-4162 | doi = 10.1146/annurev.es.10.110179.000305 }} Female flowers mature first. Once mature, they produce a [[Volatility (chemistry)|volatile]] chemical attractant which is recognised by female wasps belonging to the species ''Tetrapus americanus''. Female wasps of this species are about {{convert|2|mm|in|abbr=on}} long and are capable of producing about 190 offspring. Female fig wasps arrive carrying pollen from their natal tree and squeeze their way through the ostiole into the interior of the syconium. The syncomium bears 500–600 female flowers arranged in multiple layers - those that are closer to the outer wall of the fig have short [[Pedicel (botany)|pedicel]]s and long [[Gynoecium#Carpel anatomy|styles]], while those that are located closer to the interior of the chamber have long pedicels and short styles. Female wasps generally [[oviposition|lay their eggs]] in the short-styled flowers, while longer-styled flowers were more likely to be pollinated. The eggs hatch and the larvae parasitise the flowers in which they were laid. Pollinated flowers which have not been parasitised give rise to seeds. Male wasps mature and emerge before the females. They mate with the females, which have not yet emerged from their [[gall]]s. Males cut exit holes in the outer wall of the syconium, through which the females exit the fig.{{cite book|last=Kjellberg|first=Finn |author2=Emmanuelle Jousselin |author3=Martine Hossaert-McKey |author4=Jean-Yves Rasplus|editor=A. Raman |editor2=Carl W. Schaefer |editor3=Toni M. Withers (eds.)|title=Biology, Ecology, and Evolution of Gall-inducing Arthropods|year=2005|publisher=Science publishers, Inc.|location=Enfield (NH) USA, Plymouth, UK|isbn=978-1-57808-262-9|pages=539–572|chapter=Biology, ecology and evolution of fig-pollinating wasps (Chalcidoidea, Agaonidae)|chapterurl=http://www.cefe.cnrs.fr/coev/pdf/fk/Kjellberg2005book.pdf}} The male flowers mature around the same time as the female wasps emerge and shed their pollen on the newly emerged females; like about one third of figs, ''F. maxima'' is passively pollinated. The newly emerged female wasps leave through the exit holes the males have cut and fly off to find a syconium in which to lay their eggs. The figs then ripen. The ripe figs are eaten by a variety of mammals and birds which [[seed dispersal|disperse]] the seeds. ==Distribution== ''Ficus maxima'' ranges from [[Paraguay]] and [[Bolivia]] in the south to [[Mexico]] in the north, where it is widespread and common. It is found in fourteen [[Administrative divisions of Mexico#The states|states]] across the southern and central portion of the country. It occurs in tropical deciduous forest, tropical semi-evergreen forest, tropical evergreen forest, oak forest and in aquatic or subaquatic habitats.{{cite journal | last = Serrato | first = Alejandra | authorlink = |author2=Guillermo Ibarra-Manríquez |author3=Ken Oyama |date=March 2004 | title = Biogeography and conservation of the genus ''Ficus'' (Moraceae) in Mexico | journal = [[Journal of Biogeography]] | volume = 31 | issue = 3 | pages = 475–85 | issn = | url = http://www.blackwell-synergy.com/doi/abs/10.1046/j.0305-0270.2003.01039.x | doi = 10.1046/j.0305-0270.2003.01039.x }} It is found throughout [[Central America]] - in [[Guatemala]], [[Belize]], [[Honduras]], [[Nicaragua]], [[El Salvador]], [[Costa Rica]] and [[Panama]]. It is present in [[Cuba]] and [[Jamaica]] in the [[Greater Antilles]], and [[Trinidad and Tobago]] in the southern [[Caribbean]]. In [[South America]] it ranges through [[Colombia]], [[Venezuela]], [[Guyana]], [[Suriname]], [[French Guiana]], [[Ecuador]], [[Peru]], Bolivia, Paraguay and in the [[Brazil]]ian states of [[Amapá]], [[Amazonas (Brazilian state)|Amazonas]], [[Mato Grosso]], [[Minas Gerais]], [[Pará]].{{cite web |url= http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?403471 |title=''Ficus maxima'' Mill. |accessdate= 2008-06-28 |work=U.S. National Plant Germplasm System |publisher=National Germplasm Resources Laboratory |location=Beltsville, Maryland}} ==Ecology== Figs are sometimes considered to be potential [[keystone species]] for communities of [[frugivores|fruit-eating animals]]; their [[wikt:asynchrony|asynchronous]] fruiting patterns may cause them to be important fruit sources when other food sources are scarce.{{cite book|last=Terborgh|first=John|editor=[[Michael E. Soulé]] (ed.)|title=Conservation Biology: The Science of Scarcity and Diversity|year=1986|publisher=Sinauer Associates|location=Sunderland, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-87893-795-0|pages=330–44|chapter=Keystone plant resources in the tropical forests}} At Tinigua National Park in [[Colombia]] ''Ficus maxima'' was an important fruit producer during periods of fruit scarcity in one of three years. This led Colombian ecologist Pablo Stevens to consider it a possible keystone species, but he decided against including it in his final list of potential keystone species at the site.{{cite book|last=Stevenson|first=Pablo|editor=J. Lawrence Dew |editor2=Jean Philippe Boubli (eds.)|title= Tropical Fruits and Frugivores: The Search for Strong Interactors|year=2005|publisher=Springer Netherlands|isbn=978-1-4020-3833-4|doi=10.1007/1-4020-3833-X|pages=37–57|chapter=Potential Keystone Plant Species for the Frugivore Community at Tinigua Park, Colombia}} ''Ficus maxima'' fruit are consumed by birds and mammals. These animals act as [[seed dispersal|seed dispersers]] when the defaecate or regurgitate intact seeds, or when they drop fruit below the parent tree.{{cite journal | first = Matthew B. | last = Jones | title = Secondary Seed Removal by Ants, Beetles, and Rodents in a Neotropical Moist Forest | version = M.S. Thesis | publisher = University of Florida | date = April 1994 | url = http://www.nceas.ucsb.edu/~jones/thesis/abstract.htm | accessdate = 2008-07-03}} In Panama, ''F. maxima'' fruit were reported to have relatively high levels of [[protein]] and low levels of water-soluble [[carbohydrates]] in a study of ''Ficus'' fruit consumed by [[bat]]s.{{cite journal | last = Wendeln | first = Marcia C. |author2=James R. Runkle |author3=Elisabeth K. V. Kalko | year = 2000 | title = Nutritional Values of 14 Fig Species and Bat Feeding Preferences in Panama | journal = Biotropica | volume = 32 | issue = 3 | pages = 489–501 | doi = 10.1646/0006-3606(2000)032[0489:NVOFSA]2.0.CO;2 | url = http://si-pddr.si.edu/dspace/bitstream/10088/1307/1/Wendeln_Runkle_and_Kalko_2000.pdf |format=PDF | issn = 0006-3606}} [[Guatemalan Black Howler|Black howler monkey]]s in Belize consume fruit and young and mature leaves of ''F. maxima''.{{cite journal | last = Silver | first = S. C. |author2=L. E. T. Ostro |author3=C. P. Yeager |author4=R. Horwich | year = 1999 | title = Feeding ecology of the black howler monkey (''Alouatta pigra'') in Northern Belize | journal = American Journal of Primatology | volume = 45 | issue = 3 | pages = 263–79 |url=http://www.communityconservation.org/publications/feedeco98.pdf |format=PDF|pmid=9651649 | doi = 10.1002/(SICI)1098-2345(1998)45:3<263::AID-AJP3>3.0.CO;2-U }} In southern [[Veracruz]], Mexico, ''F. maxima'' was the third most important food source for a studied population of [[Mexican howler monkey]]s; they consumed young leaves, mature leaves, mature fruit and [[Petiole (botany)|petioles]].{{cite journal | last = Serio-Silva | first = Juan Carlos |author2=Victor Rico-Gray |author3=Laura Teresa Hernández-Salazar |author4=Rene Espinosa-Gómez | year = 2002 | title = The role of ''Ficus'' (Moraceae) in the diet and nutrition of a troop of Mexican howler monkeys, ''Alouatta palliata mexicana'', released on an island in southern Veracruz, Mexico | journal = Journal of Tropical Ecology | volume = 18 | issue = 6 | pages = 913–28 | doi = 10.1017/S0266467402002596 }} [[Venezuelan red howler]]s were observed feeding ''F. maxima'' fruit in [[Colombia]].{{cite journal | last = Stevenson | first = Pablo R. |author2=Maria Clara Castellanos |author3=Juan Carlos Pizarro |author4=Mariaximena Garavito | year = 2002 | title = Effects of Seed Dispersal by Three Ateline Monkey Species on Seed Germination at Tinigua National Park, Colombia | journal = International Journal of Primatology | volume = 23 | issue = 6 | pages = 1187–1204 | doi = 10.1023/A:1021118618936 }} The interaction between figs and fig wasps is especially well-known (see section on [[Ficus maxima#Reproduction|reproduction]], above). In addition to their pollinators, ''Ficus'' species are exploited by a group of non-pollinating [[Chalcid wasp|chalcidoid wasps]] whose larvae develop in its figs. Both pollinating and non-pollinating wasps serve as hosts for [[parasitoid]] wasps. In addition to ''T. americanus'', ''F. maxima'' figs from Brazil were found to contain non-pollinating wasps belonging to the genus ''[[Critogaster]]'', mites, ants, beetles, and [[diptera]]n and [[lepidoptera]]n larvae.{{cite journal | last = Nazareno | first = Alison G. |author2=Ranyse B. Querino da Silva II |author3=Rodrigo A. S. Pereira |year=2007 |title=Fauna de Hymenoptera em ''Ficus'' spp. (Moraceae) na Amazônia Central, Brasil |journal=Iheringia. Série Zoologia, Porto Alegre |volume=97 |issue=4 |pages=441–46 |doi=10.1590/S0073-47212007000400013 |url=http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S0073-47212007000400013&lng=pt&nrm=iso |language=pt}} Norwegian biologist Frode Ødegaard recorded a total of 78 phytophagous (plant-eating) insect species on a single ''F. maxima'' tree in [[Panama]]nian [[tropical and subtropical dry broadleaf forests|dry forest]]—59 wood eating insects, 12 which fed on green plant parts, and 7 flower visitors. It supported the fourth most specialised phytophagous insect fauna and the second largest wood-feeding insect fauna among the 24 tree species sampled.{{cite journal | last = Ødegaard | first = Frode | year = 2000 | title = The relative importance of trees versus lianas as hosts for phytophagous beetles (Coleoptera) in tropical forests | journal = Journal of Biogeography | volume = 27 | issue = 2 | pages = 283–96 | doi = 10.1046/j.1365-2699.2000.00404.x }} ==Uses== ''Ficus maxima'' is used by the [[Lacandon people|Lacandon Maya]] to treat [[snakebite]]. Leaves are moistened by chewing and applied to the bite. In the provinces of [[Loja Province, Ecuador|Loja]] and [[Zamora-Chinchipe Province, Ecuador|Zamora-Chinchipe]] in [[Ecuador]], a leaf infusion is used to treat internal inflammations.{{cite journal | last = Tene | first = Vicente | authorlink = |author2=Omar Malagón |author3=Paola Vita Finzi |author4=Giovanni Vidari |author5=Chabaco Armijos |author6= Tomás Zaragoza | year = 2007 | title = An ethnobotanical survey of medicinal plants used in Loja and Zamora-Chinchipe, Ecuador | journal = Journal of Ethnopharmacology | volume = 111 | issue = 1 | pages = 63–81 | doi = 10.1016/j.jep.2006.10.032 | url = | pmid = 17137737 }} The [[Pech people|Paya]] of [[Honduras]] use the species for firewood, and to treat [[gingivitis]].{{cite journal | last = Lentz | first = David L. | year = 1993 | title = Medicinal and other economic plants of the Paya of Honduras | journal = Economic Botany | volume = 47 | issue = 4 | pages = 358–70 | doi = 10.1007/BF02907349 | url = http://www.springerlink.com/content/f372533484553p27/ }} The [[Tacana]] of [[Bolivia]] use the latex to treat [[intestinal parasite]]s, as do people in [[Guatemala]]'s [[Petén Department]].{{cite journal | last = Mutchnick | first = Patrice A. |author2=Brian C. McCarthy | year = 1997 | title = An ethnobotanical analysis of the tree species common to the subtropical moist forests of the Petén, Guatemala | journal = Economic Botany | volume = 52 | issue = 1 | pages = 158–83 | doi = 10.1007/BF02893110 }} In [[Brazil]] it is used as an [[anthelmintic]], [[antirheumatic]], [[anemia|anti-anaemic]] and [[antipyretic]].{{cite journal | last = Diaz M. | first = Gaspar | authorlink = |author2=Alberto C. Arruda |author3=Mara S. P. Arruda |author4=Adolfo H. Müller | year = 1997 | title = Methoxyflavones from ''Ficus maxima'' | journal = [[Phytochemistry (journal)|Phytochemistry]] | volume = 45 | issue = 8 | pages = 1697–99 | doi = 10.1016/S0031-9422(96)00729-7 | url = }} The latex is also used to bind limestone soils to produce [[calcium hydroxide|cal]], an [[adobe]] cement. Gaspar Diaz M. and colleagues isolated four [[flavones|methoxyflavones]] from ''F. maxima'' leaves. David Lentz and colleagues observed [[antimicrobial]] activity in ''Ficus maxima'' extracts.{{cite journal | last = Lentz | first = David L. |author2=Alice M. Clark |author3=Charles D. Hufford |author4=Barbara Meurer-Grimes |author5=Claus M. Passreiter |author6=Javier Cordero |author7=Omar Ibrahimi |author8=Adewole L. Okunade |year=1998 |title=Antimicrobial properties of Honduran medicinal plants |journal=Journal of Ethnopharmacology |volume=63 |issue=3 |pages=253–63 |doi=10.1016/S0378-8741(98)00100-7 |pmid=10030730}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://ctfs.si.edu/webatlas/findinfo.php?specid=3064&leng=english ''Ficus maxima'' Mill.] Trees, Shrubs, and Palms of Panama, Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute Center for Tropical Forest Science. 55.title: Ficus maxima

56.text:
{{taxobox
|status = LC
|status_system = IUCN2.3
|status_ref = <ref>Pereira, J.P. ''et al.'' 1998.  [http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/34495/all ''Ficus trigonata''].   [http://www.iucnredlist.org 2006 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org |date=June 27, 2014 }}  Downloaded on 21 August 2007.</ref>
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Rosales]]
|familia = [[Moraceae]]
|genus = ''[[Ficus]]''
|species = '''''F. trigonata'''''a
|binomial = ''Ficus trigonata''
|binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]
|}}
'''''Ficus trigonata''''' ('''jaguey blanco''') is a species of [[plant]] in the family [[Moraceae]].  It is found from [[Mexico]] and the [[Caribbean]], through [[Central America]] into northern [[South America]].<ref name = FloraNicarag>[http://mobot.mobot.org/cgi-bin/search_vast?FLNIONDAD=21300466 Flora de Nicaragua] database. Tropicos. {{es icon}} Retrieved on 2008-07-05.</ref>
