Downloaded on 13 July 2013. | regnum = [[Plant]]ae | divisio = [[Pinophyta]] | classis = [[Pinopsida]] | ordo = [[Pinales]] | familia = [[Pinaceae]] | subfamilia = [[Pinoideae]] | genus = ''[[Pine|Pinus]]'' | subgenus = (''[[Pinus classification|Pinus]]'') | species = '''''P. radiata''''' | binomial = ''Pinus radiata'' | binomial_authority = [[David Don|D.Don]] | range_map = Pinus radiata range map 2.png | range_map_caption = Natural range of ''Pinus radiata'' | range_map2 = Pinus radiata radiata range map.png | range_map2_caption = … of ''Pinus radiata'' var. ''radiata'' | range_map3 = Pinus radiata binata range map.png | range_map3_caption = … of ''Pinus radiata'' var. ''binata'' }} '''''Pinus radiata''''', family [[Pinaceae]], the '''Monterey pine''',{{cite web |title=BSBI List 2007 |publisher=Botanical Society of Britain and Ireland |url=http://www.bsbi.org.uk/BSBIList2007.xls |format=xls |archive-url=http://www.webcitation.org/6VqJ46atN |archive-date=2015-02-25 |accessdate=2014-10-17}} '''insignis pine'''{{cite book |author1=Moore, Gerry |author2=Kershner, Bruce |author3=Craig Tufts |author4=Daniel Mathews |author5=Gil Nelson |author6=Spellenberg, Richard |author7=Thieret, John W. |author8=Terry Purinton |author9=Block, Andrew |title=National Wildlife Federation Field Guide to Trees of North America |publisher=Sterling |location=New York |year=2008 |page=84 |isbn=1-4027-3875-7}} or '''radiata pine''', is a [[species]] of pine native to the Central Coast of California and Mexico ([[Guadalupe Island]] and [[Cedros island]]). ''Pinus radiata'' is a versatile, fast-growing, medium-density softwood, suitable for a wide range of uses.{{cite book|last=Mead|first=D|title=Sustainable management of Pinus radiata|year=2013|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations|location=Rome|isbn=978-92-5-107634-7|url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/018/i3274e/i3274e00.htm}} Its [[silviculture]] is highly developed, and is built on a firm foundation of over a century of research, observation and practice. Radiata pine is often considered a model for growers of other plantation species. It is the most widely [[Plantation|planted]] pine in the world, valued for rapid growth and desirable [[lumber]] and [[Pulp (paper)|pulp]] qualities. Although ''Pinus radiata'' is extensively cultivated as a plantation timber in many [[temperateness|temperate]] parts of the world,[http://www.conifers.org/pi/pin/radiata.htm Pinus radiata (D. Don 1836)], Gymnosperm Database it faces serious threats in its natural range.[http://www.1hope.org/NativeMontereyPineStatus.pdf "Status of Native Monterey Pine (Pinus radiata) Ecosystems"] ==Distribution== It is native to three very limited areas located in Santa Cruz, Monterey Peninsula, and San Luis Obispo Counties. It is also found as the [[variety (botany)|variety]] ''Pinus radiata'' var. ''binata'' or '''Guadalupe pine''' on Guadalupe Island, and a possibly separable ''P. radiata'' var./[[subspecies|subsp.]] ''cedrosensis'' on Cedros Island, both in the Pacific Ocean off the west coast of the northern Baja California Peninsula in Mexico. In Australia, New Zealand, and Spain it is the leading introduced treeScott, C. W. 1960. Pinus radiata. Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, Forestry and Forest Products Study 14. Rome, Italy. 328 p. cited in {{Silvics |volume=1 |genus=Pinus |species=radiata |first1=Philip M. |last1=McDonald |first2=Robert |last2=J. Laacke |accessdate=2013-09-14}} and in Argentina, Chile, Uruguay, Kenya, and South Africa it is a major plantation species. It is also an [[Sandy Point, Tristan da Cunha|introduced tree]] on the world's most remote inhabited island, [[Tristan da Cunha]]. ==Description== ''Pinus radiata'' is a [[pinophyta|coniferous]] [[evergreen]] tree growing to between {{convert|15|-|30|m|abbr=on}} in height in the wild, but up to {{convert|60|m|abbr=on}} in cultivation in optimum conditions, with upward pointing branches and a rounded top. The [[leaf|leaves]] ('needles') are bright green, in clusters of three (two in var. ''binata''), slender, {{convert|8|-|15|cm|abbr=on}} long and with a blunt tip. The [[conifer cone|cones]] are {{convert|7|-|17|cm|in|abbr=on}} long, brown, ovoid (egg-shaped), and usually set asymmetrically on a branch, attached at an oblique angle. The [[bark]] is fissured and dark grey to brown. It is closely related to [[bishop pine]] and [[knobcone pine]], hybridizing readily with both species; it is distinguished from the former by needles in threes (not pairs), and from both by the cones not having a sharp spine on the scales. The modern tree is vastly different from the native tree of Monterey. In plantations the tree is commonly planted at 4m x 4m spacing on a wide variety of landscapes from flat to moderately steep hills. Because of selective breeding and more recently the extensive use of Growth Factor seedlings,{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} forests planted since the 1990s are of superior wood with very straight tall trunks without the problem of twin leaders. The trees are pruned in 3 lifts so that the lower 2/3 of a mature tree is branch- ( and hence knot-) free. In its natural state, the wood is poor quality: twisted, knotty and full of sap/resin only really suitable for firewood, but the modern product is very different. ==Ecology== Monterey pine is a species adapted to cope with stand-killing fire disturbance. Its cones are serotinous, i.e. they remain closed until opened by the heat of a forest fire; the abundant seeds are then discharged to regenerate on the burned forest floor. The cones may also burst open in hot weather.[Little, Elbert L. Jr. 1980. The Audubon Society field guide to North American trees. New York: Alfred A. Knopf.] In its native range, Monterey pine is associated with a characteristic flora and fauna. It is the co-dominant canopy tree together with ''[[Cupressus macrocarpa]]'' which naturally occurs only in coastal [[Monterey County]].{{cite web |url=http://www.globaltwitcher.com/artspec_information.asp?thingid=62524 |title=Monterey Cypress (''Cupressus macrocarpa'') |last1=Hogan |first1=C. Michael |last2=Frankis |first2=Michael P. |year=2009 |publisher=GlobalTwitcher.com |accessdate=14 January 2011}} Furthermore, one of the pine forests in [[Monterey, California]], was the discovery site for [[Hickman's potentilla]], an endangered species. ''[[Piperia yadonii]]'', a rare species of [[orchid]] is endemic to the same pine forest adjacent to [[Pebble Beach, California|Pebble Beach]]. In its native range, Monterey pine is a principal host for the dwarf [[mistletoe]] ''[[Arceuthobium]] littorum''.[http://www.rmrs.nau.edu/publications/ah_709/index.html Hawksworth, F.G. and D. Wiens. 1996. Dwarf mistletoes: Biology, pathology and systematics. Agriculture Handbook 709. Washington, DC: U.S.D.A. Forest Service.] A remnant Monterey pine stand in [[Pacific Grove, California|Pacific Grove]] is a prime wintering habitat of the [[monarch butterfly]].[http://www.pgmuseum.org/Monarchs.htm Monarch Grove Sanctuary] In South Africa, the tree is a threat to already scarce water resources.{{Cite book|title = WIld Hope|last = Balmford|first = Andrew|publisher = University of Chicago Press|year = 2012|isbn = |location = |pages = }} The tree has remarkable roots. Monterey pine roots will reach downward as far as physically permitted by subterranean conditions. Roots have been discovered up to 12 meters long.{{Cite web|url = http://www.na.fs.fed.us/pubs/silvics_manual/Volume_1/pinus/radiata.htm|title = USDA Forest Service|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = }} Efforts to remove large quantities of the non-native tree in areas of South Africa have resulted in significant increases in accessible water. ==Conservation status== ===Fungal disease=== The three remaining wild stands of var. ''radiata'' (Monterey pine proper) are infected and under threat of [[Local extinction|extirpation]] from pine pitch [[canker]] caused by ''[[Fusarium circinatum]]'', a fungal disease native to the southeast United States and found (in 1986) to have been introduced to California. When trees begin to die of the disease, they attract bark beetles which provide a pathway for infection of other trees. In some stands, 80–90% of trees are infected. If the disease is introduced in agroforestry areas dependent upon Monterey pine, such as New Zealand, it could have catastrophic effects in those countries as well. [[Sphaeropsis blight]] (''Diplodia pinea'') infects ''P.radiata'' in California and causes serious damage to plantations of the species in New Zealand, Australia and South Africa,http://www.na.fs.fed.us/spfo/pubs/fidls/diplodia/diplodiafidl.htm especially after hail damage to growing tips. ===Baja California=== On Guadalupe Island, var. ''binata'' is [[critically endangered]]. Most of the population was destroyed as tens of thousands of [[feral]] [[goat]]s ate ''binata'' seedlings and caused soil erosion from the mid-19th century until just a few years ago. The older trees gradually died off until by 2001–2002 the population stood at only one hundred. With a program to remove the goats essentially complete by 2005, hundreds of young Guadalupe pines have started to grow up in habitat fenced after 2001, the first significant new growth in about 150 years. Possible accidental introduction of pine pitch canker is considered the biggest threat at present to the survival of the Guadalupe Island pine population.Junak, S.; Keitt, B.; Tershy, B.; Croll, D. & Sánchez, J.A. (2003). ''Recent conservation efforts and current status of the flora of Guadalupe Island, Baja California, Mexico''. Presentation at ''Taller sobre la Restauración y Conservación de Isla Guadalupe'' ["Workshop on restoration and conservation of Guadalupe Island"]. Instituto Nacional de Ecología, 13–14 November 2003. [http://www.ine.gob.mx/ueajei/publicaciones/libros/477/abstracts.html HTML abstract] The [[University of California]]'s Russell Reservation forestry research station hosts an orchard planted with 73 ''Pinus radiata'' seedlings from Guadalupe Island and plays an important role in conserving the ''binata'' variety.{{cite web|last=Rogers|first=Deborah L.|title=Status of Conservation of Monterey Pine|url=http://www.grcp.ucdavis.edu/publications/doc26/Chapt4.pdf|publisher=University of California Division of Agriculture and Natural Resources, Genetic Resources Conservation Program|accessdate=17 March 2012}} ==Cultivation== ===Australia=== [[File:CSIRO ScienceImage 10753 CSIRO researchers of the Juvenile Wood Initiative sampling the increment growth core of radiata pines.jpg|thumb|[[Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation|CSIRO]] researchers of the Juvenile Wood Initiative sampling the increment growth core of radiata pines]] ''P. radiata'' is "the dominant tree species in the Australian plantation estate";[https://rirdc.infoservices.com.au/downloads/05-128.pdf "Fauna conservation in Australian plantation forests: a review"], May 2007, D.B. Lindenmayer and R.J. Hobbs so much so that many Australians are concerned by the resulting loss of native wildlife habitat, and in the Blue Mountains (NSW), the species is regarded as a weed and its removal is encouraged. [http://www.bmcc.nsw.gov.au/sustainableliving/weedmanagement/factsheets Blue Mountains City Council – Fact Sheets [Retrieved 1 August 2015]] [http://www.weedsbluemountains.org.au/radiata_pine.php Radiata Pine – Weeds of Blue Mountains Bushland [Retrieved 1 August 2015]] ===Chile=== ''P. radiata'' has greatly replaced the [[Valdivian temperate rain forests]], where vast plantations have been planted for timber, again displacing the native forests.[http://botany.si.edu/projects/cpd/sa/sa45.htm "TEMPERATE RAIN FOREST of Chile "] In 2001, this species produced 5,580,724 cubic meters of lumber, or 95% of Chile's total lumber production.http://repositoriodigital.corfo.cl/bitstream/handle/11373/3075/00C7FT-09%20_Anex_5.pdf?sequence=10 ===New Zealand=== The Monterey pine (always called ''Pinus radiata'' in New Zealand) was first introduced into New Zealand in 1859[http://www.friendswbg.org.nz/downhill5a.htm ''"...he first NZ introduction of British seedlings in 1859..."''][http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/radiata-pine "Radiata pine"], Te Ara and today 89% of the country's plantation forests are of this species.{{cite web |url=http://www.maf.govt.nz/mafnet/rural-nz/statistics-and-forecasts/sonzaf/archive/sonzaf-2007.pdf |title=Situation and outlook for New Zealand agriculture and forestry |publisher=NZ Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry |year=2007 |format=PDF |accessdate=2010-10-19}} This includes the [[Kaingaroa Forest]] on the central plateau of the North Island which is the largest planted forest in the world. Mass plantings became common from 1900 in the Rotorua area where prison labour was used. In some areas it is considered an [[invasive species]] (termed a [[wilding conifer]] or more commonly [[wilding pine]]) where it has escaped from plantations. It is the most extensively used wood in New Zealand. Use of pine in construction did not become widespread until forced by wartime shortages. It had been used in [[Southland, New Zealand|Southland]] from about 1920,{{Cite web|url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/BPB19451218.2.19|title=PINUS RADIATA (Bay of Plenty Beacon, 1945-12-18)|last=|first=|date=|website=paperspast.natlib.govt.nz National Library of New Zealand|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-05-05}} but doubts were being expressed about it as late as 1945,{{Cite web|url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/AS19451215.2.60|title=FOR HOUSE BUILDING - PINUS RADIATA CONDEMNED (Auckland Star, 1945-12-15)|last=|first=|date=|website=paperspast.natlib.govt.nz National Library of New Zealand|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-05-05}} when at least one MP considered it only suitable for interior studding.{{Cite web|url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZH19450707.2.66|title=PARLIAMENT IN SESSION (New Zealand Herald, 1945-07-07)|last=|first=|date=|website=paperspast.natlib.govt.nz National Library of New Zealand|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-05-05}} Experiments in [[Wood preservation#Pressure processes|pressure treatment]] with water-soluble preservatives were made from 1943.{{Cite web|url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/parliamentary/AJHR1945-I.2.2.5.37|title=DEPARTMENT OF SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH (NINETEENTH ANNUAL REPORT OF THE) (Appendix to the Journals of the House of Representatives, 1945-01-01)|last=|first=|date=|website=paperspast.natlib.govt.nz National Library of New Zealand|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-05-05}} ===Spain=== In the [[Iberian Peninsula]] since the [[nineteenth century]] they have been introduced mainly in the north area in order to take advantage of their wood for the manufacture of paper pulp and for shoring work in [[coal mine]]s. It is found in low altitude areas of the Autonomous Communities of [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]], [[Asturias]], [[Cantabria]], the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque Country]], and in the north of the [[Canary Islands]]. The Monterey pine forests have a negative effect on local ecology. In its plantations there are usually no other tree species, while its shady undergrowth does not allow the existence of a rich stratum of scrub. 13% of the wood cut annually in Spain comes from this pine.[http://www.mapama.gob.es/es/desarrollo-rural/temas/politica-forestal/pradiata_tcm7-386705.pdf Los pinares de pino radiata Los pinares de pino radiata] Ministerio de Medio Ambiente. Gobierno de España. ===United States=== The Monterey pine is widely used in private gardens and public landscapes in temperate California, and similar climates around the world. It is a fast-growing [[tree]], adaptable to a broad range of soil types and climates, though it does not tolerate temperatures below about {{convert|-15|C}}. Its fast growth makes it ideal for landscapes and forestry; in a good situation, ''P. radiata'' can reach its full height in 40 years or so. == Uses == As timber radiata is suitable for a wide variety of uses,[http://www.dpi.qld.gov.au/26_5424.htm "Radiata pine"], Primary Industries and Fisheries, QLD and has a resinous fragrance while being worked.http://www.wood-database.com/lumber-identification/softwoods/radiata-pine/ It holds screws and nails well and takes paint and stain without difficulty - and modern kiln dried timber is very easy to work.[http://web.archive.org/web/20150126184040/http://www.nzwood.co.nz/learning-centre/radiata-pine/ "Radiata pine"], nzwood.co.nz It is about 1/3 heavier than dried [[western red cedar]]. It is brittle when bent, so does not have the same load-bearing features as Oregon pine ([[Douglas fir]], ''Pseudotsuga''). Radiata is used in house construction as weatherboards, posts, beams or plywood, in fencing, retaining walls, for concrete formers. It is also used to a limited extent in boat building where untreated ply is sometimes used, but must be encased in epoxy resin to exclude moisture. The wood is normally kiln dried to 12% moisture in 6 m long, clear lengths. It is available treated with a range of chemical salts, or untreated. Chemical salt treatment is well proven and such timber is frequently used in the ground as posts and poles as part of structures such as retaining walls and pole houses. The name applied to this treatment is tanalized wood. H1 and H2 treatment is suited to indoor use. H3 is the standard house timber and this grade is used for fence palings. H4 and H5 are the standard for inground use. In New Zealand a 1995 change to no longer require [[Wood preservation#Borate preservatives|boron treatment]] in house framing timber,{{cite web|url=http://www.parliament.nz/NR/rdonlyres/464AB9F9-B197-4B53-BE9F-4F411CB67877/360/0210LeakyBuildings1.pdf|title=Background note: Information briefing for members of Parliament:Leaky buildings|date=6 November 2002|publisher=NZ Parliamentary Library}} was a key factor in the [[leaky homes crisis]],{{cite news|title=Leaky homes will cost $11.3b to fix - report|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10617051|accessdate=26 February 2012|newspaper=The New Zealand Herald|date=22 December 2009}} but since 2003 a series of changes have now improved the regulations.[http://www.dbh.govt.nz/biaupdate-20 "Changes to Acceptable Solution B2/AS1 - Timber Durability 23 Dec 2003"], ''archived entry'', dbh.govt.nz Lower grade timber is converted to pulp to make newsprint.[http://www.norskeskog.com/Business-units/Australasia/Norske-Skog-Tasman.aspx ''"Annual paper production is now over 300,000 tonnes."''], Norske Skog Tasman Higher grade timber is used in house construction. Radiata is used chipped to make particle board sheets, commonly used in flooring. Other sheet products are hardboard, softboard and ply. Most ply is structural and available in 7–22 mm sizes. A small amount of higher grade ply is used to produce thinner (4 and 7 mm) ply suitable for furniture, cabinet work and boat building. This is knot and crack free and glued with [[Resorcinol glue|resorcinol waterproof glue]]. Since the 1990s finger jointed joinery-grade wood has become available in up to 6 m lengths in a wide range of profiles. In 1958, New Zealand boat designer [[Des Townson]] started building 186 eleven-foot, cold-moulded [[Zephyr (dinghy)|Zephyr-class dinghies]], using ''Pinus radiata''. In 2011 these hand-built boats fetched very high prices and were generally in excellent condition. The bark is also used as a substrate for potting and re-potting orchids. ''Pinus radiata'' is the most common species of Christmas tree in Australia and New Zealand. Image:Pine bark.jpg|Detail of bark on a ''Pinus radiata'' tree image:Pinus Radiata detail.jpg|Needles and spikes on a branch Image:Pine cone edit.jpg|''Pinus radiata'' pine cone on forest floor Image:Pine tree forest02.jpg|Monterey pine plantation, Australia ==See also== {{Portal|Trees}} *[[Point Lobos Ranch]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * {{IUCN2006|assessor=Conifer Specialist Group|year=1998|id=42408|title=Pinus radiata|downloaded=11 May 2006}} * León de la Luz, José Luis; Rebman, Jon P. & Oberbauer, Thomas (2003). On the urgency of conservation on Guadalupe Island, Mexico: is it a lost paradise? ''Biodiversity and Conservation'' '''12'''(5): 1073–1082. {{doi|10.1023/A:1022854211166}} (HTML abstract) ==External links== * [https://www.calflora.org/cgi-bin/species_query.cgi?where-calrecnum=6523 Calflora Database: ''Pinus radiata'' (Monterey pine)] * [http://herbaria4.herb.berkeley.edu/eflora_display.php?tid=38300 Jepson Manual eFlora (TJM2) treatment of ''Pinus radiata''] * [http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=PIRA2 USDA Plants profile for ''Pinus radiata'' (Monterey pine)] * [http://www.conifers.org/pi/pin/radiata.htm Conifers.org - ''Pinus radiata''] * [http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/tree/pinrad/all.html US Forest Service] *[http://calphotos.berkeley.edu/cgi-bin/img_query?rel-taxon=begins+with&where-taxon=Pinus+radiata UC CalPhotos gallery — ''Pinus radiata''] {{commons category|position=left|Pinus radiata}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pinus Radiata}} [[Category:Pinus|radiata]] [[Category:Flora of California]] [[Category:Flora of Baja California]] [[Category:Trees of Mexico]] [[Category:Trees of the Southwestern United States]] [[Category:Trees of Mediterranean climate]] [[Category:Trees of mild maritime climate]] [[Category:Natural history of the California chaparral and woodlands]] [[Category:Natural history of Monterey County, California]] [[Category:Endangered flora of California]] [[Category:Endangered biota of Mexico]] [[Category:Invasive plant species]] [[Category:Invasive plant species in Australia]] [[Category:Invasive plant species in New Zealand]] [[Category:Garden plants of North America]] [[Category:Ornamental trees]]

'''''Pinus tecunumanii''''' ([[syn.]] ''Pinus oocarpa'' [[var.]] ''ochoterenae'' Martínez; ''Pinus patula'' Schiede & Deppe spp. ''tecunumanii'' Eguiluz & Perry) is a timber tree native to [[Mexico]] and [[Central America]].<ref name="IUCN"/> It grows from the highlands of [[Chiapas]] and [[Oaxaca]] through [[Guatemala]], [[Belize]], [[El Salvador]], [[Honduras]]  to [[Nicaragua]] (17° to 14° North latitude). It occurs in two separated populations in their native habitats. High altitude group grows at 1500–2900 m and low altitude group from 500–1500 m.

It has been cultivated in several subtropical parts of the world for [[pulp and paper industry|paper industry]]. Cultivation trials have shown that high elevation sources are the most productive. It grows well in [[Colombia]], [[Venezuela]], [[Brazil]] and [[South Africa]].

Wood: Yellowish color.
Formerly classified as a subspecies of [[Pinus patula]], DNA analysis has shown that is a different species and that is closer to [[Pinus oocarpa]].
It is also used in [[paper]] production.

'''''Pinus teocote''''' ('''Teocote''') is a species of [[conifer]] in the [[Pinaceae]] family.
It is [[endemism|endemic]] to [[Mexico]]. 20–30 m tall and 75 cm diameter. Straight trunk and dense top. It grows at 1500–3200 mm. Most of the rainfall in its habitat occurs in summer.

Wood: white-yellowish, moderate in quality, the resin is used to produce turpentine

Benth. |work=Germplasm Resources Information Network |publisher=United States Department of Agriculture |date=1994-08-23 |accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref>
|}}

'''''Pithecellobium dulce''''' is a species of [[flowering plant]] in the [[pea]] family, [[Fabaceae]], that is native to the Pacific Coast and adjacent highlands of [[Mexico]], [[Central America]], and northern [[South America]].<ref name="GRIN"/> It is an [[Introduced species]] and extensively naturalised in the [[Caribbean]], [[Florida]], [[Guam]], [[India]], [[Bangladesh]] and the [[Philippines]]. It is considered an [[invasive species]] in [[Hawaii]].

== Description ==

''Pithecellobium dulce'' is a [[tree]] that reaches a height of about {{convert|10|to|15|m|ft|abbr=on}}. Its trunk is spiny and its leaves are [[Pinnate|bipinnate]]. Each pinna has a single pair of ovate-oblong [[leaflet (botany)|leaflets]] that are about {{convert|2|to|4|cm|in|abbr=on}} long. The [[flower]]s are greenish-white, fragrant, sessile and reach about {{convert|12|cm|in|abbr=on}} in length, though appear shorter due to coiling. The flowers produce a [[Legume|pod]], which turns pink when ripe and opens to expose an edible pulp. The pulp contains black shiny seeds that are circular and flat.

The seed is [[Seed dispersal#By animals|dispersed]] via birds that feed on the sweet pulp. The tree is [[Drought tolerance|drought resistant]] and can survive in dry lands from sea level to an elevation of {{convert|1500|m|ft|abbr=on}}, making it suitable for cultivation as a street tree.

== Vernacular names ==

Depending on the region of its occurrence, ''Pithecellobium dulce'' is known by different names. In its native [[Mexico]], the tree is known as huamuche, guamuche / huamúchil/ guamúchil / cuamúchil / deriving from its [[Nahuatl]] name ''cuauhmochitl''. In the wider region it is also called  "pinzán"', or 'guamá americano'' ([[Puerto Rico]]).

It is called "seema chintakaya" (సీమ చింతకాయ) in Telugu. '''Monkeypod''' is as English name,<ref>{{PLANTS|id=PIDU|taxon=Pithecellobium dulce|accessdate=6 October 2015}}</ref> but is also used for several other plants, including ''[[Albizia saman]]''. Other names include blackbead, sweet Inga,<ref name="GRIN"/> ផ្លែអំពិលទឹក (Plaeh umpel tek) ([[Khmer language|Khmer]]), ''Makham thet'' ({{lang-th|มะขามเทศ}}), ''{{okina}}opiuma'' ([[Hawaiian language|Hawaiian]]), ''kamunsil'' ([[Hiligaynon language |Hiligaynon]]), ''damortis'' or ''kamantiris'' ([[Ilokano language|Ilokano]]), ''kamachile'' ([[Tagalog language|Tagalog]]),<ref name="Elsevier">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yjc5ZYWtkNAC |title=Elsevier's Dictionary of Trees: With Names in Latin, English, French, Spanish and Other Languages |first=Miroslav M. |last=Grandtner |volume=1 |publisher=Elsevier |year=2005 |isbn=978-0-444-51784-5 |pages=670–671}}</ref> கொர்கலிக்காய்/ கோணக்காய்/ கோன புளியங்கா/ கொடுக்காப்புளி ''kodukkappuli'' ([[Tamil language|Tamil]]), ದೊರ ಹುಣಸೆ/ಸೀಮೆ ಹುಣಸೆ/ಇಲಾಚಿ ಕಾಯಿ/ಇಲಾಚ್-ಹುಂಚಿ ಕಾಯಿ  ''dora hunase or seeme hunase or ilaichi kai or ilach-hunchi kai'' ([[Kannada language|Kannada]]), '''વિલાયતી આંબલી''' i.e. ''Foreign Tamarind'' - "બખાઇ આમ્બલી" i.e. "Bakhai Ambli" [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]]), '''जलेबी''' i.e. [[Jalebi]] like or '''गंगा इमली''' i.e. ''Ganges Tamarind'' or "'Singri"' i.e. "सिंगड़ी" ([[Hindi]]), '''জিলাপি''' i.e. ''Jilapi'' meaning ''Jalebi'' ([[Bengali language|Bengali]]), ''seeme hunase'' ([[Kannada language|Kannada]]), '' चिंच बुलाई'' or '''विलायती चिंच''' i.e. ''Foreign Tamarind'' ([[Marathi language|Marathi]]), చింత ''chinta'' ([[Telugu language|Telugu]]). and 
"Achhi gidamiri"  [Sindhi]. In odisha it is called Seema Kaiyan(Odia).

In India it goes by the name "Madras thorn", although it is not native to [[Madras]]. The name "Manila tamarind" is also misleading, since it is neither closely related to [[tamarind]], nor native to [[Manila]].

In Kuwait it has the same name as in India but in Arabic "Showkat Madras". Showkat meaning "thorn" and that would mean Madras Thorn. It appears to have been introduced in Kuwait in the 60's or 70's and maybe introduced by Indians. One can still see the remains of the tree or living trees in the public parks established during the 60's up until the 1980's in Kuwait City. The tree is rarely sold in commercial nurseries but the old gardeners seem to know it.

== Uses ==

=== As food ===

The seed pods contain a sweet and sour pulp that which in Mexico is eaten raw as an accompaniment to various meat dishes and used as a base for drinks with sugar and water (''agua de huamúchil''). The seeds are also edible and refined to extract oil, which amounts to 10% of their weight. They also contain 28% protein.<ref name="conabio.gob.mx">Commission for the Knowledge and Use of Biodiversity: ''Pithecellobium Dulce'': http://www.conabio.gob.mx/conocimiento/info_especies/arboles/doctos/45-legum38m.pdf</ref>

=== As medicine ===
The bark and pulp are [[astringent]] and [[hemostatic]].{{medcn|date=October 2015}} The [[indigenous peoples]] of [[Mesoamerica]] use the pulp and bark against gum ailments, [[toothache]] and [[hemorrhages]] in general.{{cn|date=October 2015}} A bark extract is also used against [[dysentery]], chronic [[diarrhea]] and [[tuberculosis]].{{medcn|date=October 2015}} An extract of the leaves is used for gall ailments and to prevent [[miscarriage]].{{medcn|date=October 2015}} The ground seed is used to clean [[ulcers]].<ref name="conabio.gob.mx"/>

== Ecology ==

''Pithecellobium dulce'' is a host plant for the [[caterpillar]]s of the red-bordered pixie (''[[Melanis pixe]]''), three-spot grass yellow (''[[Eurema blanda]]'') and many other moths.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.butterfliesandmoths.org/species?l=1646 |title=Red-bordered Pixie ''Melanis pixe'' (Boisduval, 1836) |publisher=Butterflies and Moths of North America |accessdate=2010-09-19}}</ref>

'''''Plumeria rubra''''' is a [[deciduous]] plant species belonging to the genus ''[[Plumeria]]''.<ref name="Botanica 691">"Botanica. The Illustrated AZ of over 10000 garden plants and how to cultivate them", p. 691. Könemann, 2004. ISBN 3-8331-1253-0</ref> Originally native to Mexico, Central America, Colombia and Venezuela, it has been widely cultivated in subtropical and tropical climates worldwide and is a popular garden and park plant, as well as being used in temples and cemeteries. It grows as a spreading tree to {{convert|7|–|8|m|ft|abbr=on}} high and wide, and is flushed with fragrant flowers of shades of pink, white and yellow over the summer and autumn. Its common names include '''frangipani''',<ref name="GRIN"/> '''red paucipan''',<ref name="GRIN"/> '''red-jasmine''',<ref name="GRIN"/> '''red frangipani''', '''common frangipani,''' '''temple tree''',<ref name="GRIN"/> or simply '''plumeria'''.

==Taxonomy==
''Plumeria rubra'' was one of the many species first described by the father of taxonomy [[Carl Linnaeus]], and appeared in the 1753 edition of ''[[Species Plantarum]]''. Its specific epithet is derived from the [[Latin]] ''ruber'' "red". The epithets ''acuminata'', ''acutifolia'', and ''lutea'' are seen, but these are invalid.

==Common Names==
In Mexico the common name is Cacaloxochitl or Suchitl. The name comes from nahuatl and means Crow's flower.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.medicinatradicionalmexicana.unam.mx/monografia.php?l=3&t=&id=7302 |title=Biblioteca |publisher=Medicinatradicionalmexicana.unam.mx |date= |accessdate=2013-07-12}}</ref>
The common name in Australia is 'frangipani', although 'plumeria' is used in the United States. Other common names are 'red frangipani', 'common frangipani', 'temple tree', or simply 'plumeria'. The term ''melia'' is a Hawaiian one.<ref name="ctahr">{{cite web|url=http://www.ctahr.hawaii.edu/oc/freepubs/pdf/OF-24.pdf|title=Ornamentals and Flowers OF-24: Plumeria|last=Criley, Richard A|date=February 1998|work=Cooperative Extension Service, C/T/A/H/R|publisher=Department of Horticulture, College of Tropical Agriculture & Human Resources, University of hawaii at Manoa|accessdate=31 January 2010}}</ref> The common name 'frangipani' comes from an [[Italy|Italian]] [[Frangipani family|noblefamily]], a sixteenth-century [[marquess]] of which invented a plumeria-scented [[perfume]]. In the Cook Islands, it is known as Tipani. It is grown extensively in southern and western parts of India, where it is named ''champa'' or a derivative thereof such as ''chaaphaa'', ''champige'' etc. In Cambodia it is given the names ''châmpéi krahâ:m'' (also romanised as ''krahom'', meaning 'red'), or ''châmpéi slük sruëch'', while the French terms for the species is ''frangipanier à fleurs rouges''<ref name=dyphon>Dy Phon Pauline, 2000, ''Plants Used In Cambodia'', printed by Imprimerie Olympic, Phnom Penh</ref>

==Gallery==
<gallery mode=packed>

Fleurs de Frangipanier (Île de la Réunion) (4125134278).jpg|Close-up on flowers of a white variant
Plumeria rubra Madagaskar 2006.jpg|Close-up on flowers of a white variant

File:Plumeria rubra (83).jpg|Plumeria rubra in [[China]]
File:Frangipani rust (caused by Coleosporium plumeriae) on Plumeria rubra.jpg|Frangipani rust (caused by the fungus ''[[Coleosporium plumeriae]]'')
</gallery>

==Description==
''Plumeria rubra'' grows as a spreading shrub or small tree to a height of {{convert|2|–|8|m|ft|round=5|abbr=on}} and similar width. It has a thick succulent trunk and sausage-like blunt branches covered with a thin grey bark. The branches are somewhat brittle and when broken, ooze a white latex that can be irritating to the skin and mucous membranes. The large green leaves can reach {{convert|30|to|50|cm|in|abbr=on}} long and are arranged alternately and clustered at the end of the branches. They are deciduous, falling in the cooler months of the year. The flowers are terminal, appearing at the ends of branches over the summer. Often profuse and very prominent, they are strongly fragrant, and have five petals. The colours range from the common pink to white with shades of yellow in the centre of the flower.<ref name="Botanica 691"/><ref name="UFL">{{cite web|url=http://hort.ifas.ufl.edu/database/documents/pdf/tree_fact_sheets/pluruba.pdf|title=Fact Sheet ST-491 ''Plumeria rubra'' Frangipani|author1=Gilman, Edward F. |author2=Watson, Dennis G. |date=October 1994|work=Environmental Horticulture website|publisher=University of Florida|accessdate=22 July 2013|location=Gainesville, FL}}</ref> Initially tubular before opening out, the flowers are {{convert|5|-|7.5|cm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} in diameter, and only rarely go on to produce seed - 20-60 winged seeds are contained in a {{convert|17.5|cm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} pod.<ref name="ctahr"/>

Some forms in cultivation are hybrids between this species and ''[[Plumeria obtusa]]''; these have rounded rather than pointed leaves and are less likely to be deciduous.<ref name="ctahr"/> The white and yellow cultivar "Singapore" flowers all year round in Hawaii.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6MvFZ1P71GQC&pg=PA65&lpg=PA65&dq=Hawaii+plumeria+%22all+year%22&source=bl&ots=uFSO0_0sxD&sig=ir2wQUciu5Py9bKoQ-K9-PeTYYE&hl=en&ei=r2xrS4CUFoT2sQOCpOilAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CDUQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=Hawaii%20plumeria%20%22all%20year%22&f=false|title=Plants and Animals of Hawaii |last=Scott|first=Susan|year=1991|publisher=Bess Press|page=65|isbn=0-935848-93-2|accessdate=5 February 2010}}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
Its native range extends from central [[Mexico]] south through [[Central America]] to [[Colombia]] and [[Venezuela]] in [[South America]]. It is cultivated in the tropical regions of the world, and is perhaps naturalised in some parts of India<ref name="GRIN" />

==Cultivation==
The species is cultivated around the world in subtropical and tropical climates. In Australia, it is widely seen in cultivation in Sydney and Perth and warmer frost free climates northwards.<ref name="ABC">{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/gardening/stories/s1653931.htm|title=Fact Sheet: Frangipani|last=Campbell, Colin|date=June 3, 2006|work=Gardening Australia Website|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=31 January 2010}}</ref> In the mainland United States, it tolerates USDA Hardiness zones 10B to 11 (southern coastal California and the southern tip of Florida).<ref name="UFL"/> It is also grown in Hawaii to an altitude of 2000 m.<ref name="ctahr"/> They tolerate a wide variety of soils, from acid to alkaline and sandy to clay.<ref name="UFL"/> Widely available in nurseries, frangipanis are readily propagated by cuttings of branches taken in cooler months and left to dry for a week or more.<ref name="ABC"/> As well as gardens and street- and park planting, frangipanis are planted in temples and cemeteries.<ref name="ctahr"/>

''Plumeria rubra'' is an important crop in Hawaii, with over 14 million flowers were sold to be used in [[Lei (Hawaii)|leis]] there in 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.actahort.org/members/showpdf?booknrarnr=813_23 |title=Plumeria Rubra: An Old Ornamental, A New Crop |publisher=Actahort.org |date= |accessdate=2013-07-12}}</ref>

No weed potential has been recorded in the United States.<ref name="UFL"/>

''[[Coleosporium plumeriae]]'', known as plumeria rust or frangipani rust, is a fungus which attacks young leaves of ''P. rubra''. It causes a brownish or orange powdery coating or blistering of leaves. It has been recorded from Hawaii and the east coast of Australia.<ref name="ctahr"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.burkesbackyard.com.au/2001/archives/2001_archives/in_the_garden/weeds_and_garden_pests/frangipani_rust|title=Weeds and Garden Pests: Frangipani Rust|last=Burke|first=Don|year=2001|work=Burke's Backyard website|publisher=CTC Productions|accessdate=4 February 2010|location=Sydney, Australia}}</ref> It was first recognised by the French mycologist [[Narcisse Théophile Patouillard]] on [[Guadeloupe]] Island in the eastern Caribbean in 1902, and had reached Taiwan by 2005.<ref>{{cite web|author=S J Roberts |url=http://www.bspp.org.uk/publications/new-disease-reports/ndr.php?id=011016 |title=The first report of Plumeria (Frangipani) rust disease caused by Coleosporium plumeriae in Taiwan |publisher=Bspp.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-07-12}}</ref>

==Uses==
In Cambodia, as with other [[Plumeria]] species, ''P. rubra'' flowers is used to necklaces as offerings to deities or as decoration for coffins. The leaves of this species are used in the care of sores and made into soothing infusions<ref name=dyphon />
Also the flowers and bark of it are used in traditional Chinese medicine(TCM) in the treatment of fever, bacillary dysentery, pertussis and so on<ref>{{cite web|last1=Plumeria rubra|title=Plumeria rubra|url=http://www.flowersview.com/Plumeria%20rubra/Plumeria+rubra+%2883%29.jpg.html|website=Flower View}}</ref>

| genus              = ''[[Populus]]''
| sectio             = ''[[Populus sect. Aigeiros|Aigeiros]]''
| species            = '''''P. deltoides'''''
| binomial           = ''Populus deltoides''
| binomial_authority = [[W.Bartram]] ex [[Humphry Marshall]]
| range_map          = Populus deltoides range map 2.png
| range_map_caption  = Native range
}}

'''''Populus deltoides''''', the '''eastern cottonwood'''<ref name="PLANTS">{{PLANTS|id=PODE3|taxon=Populus deltoides|accessdate=31 January 2016}}</ref> or '''necklace poplar''',<ref name=BSBI07>{{cite web |title=BSBI List 2007 |publisher=Botanical Society of Britain and Ireland |url=http://www.bsbi.org.uk/BSBIList2007.xls |format=xls |archive-url=http://www.webcitation.org/6VqJ46atN |archive-date=2015-02-25 |accessdate=2014-10-17}}</ref> is a [[Populus sect. Aigeiros|cottonwood]] [[Populus|poplar]] native to [[North America]], growing throughout the eastern, central, and southwestern [[United States]], the southernmost part of eastern [[Canada]], and northeastern [[Mexico]].<ref name=grin>{{GRIN|id=29382|name=Populus deltoides}}</ref> It is a [[eudicot]].<ref name="PLANTS" />

== Description ==
[[File:Peuplier deltoïde feuillage.jpg|thumb|Foliage]]
''Populus deltoides'' is a large [[tree]] growing to {{convert|20|–|40|m|ft|m|round=5|abbr=on}} tall and with a trunk up to {{convert|1.8|m|ftin|abbr=on}} diameter, one of the largest North American [[hardwood]] trees. The [[bark]] is silvery-white, smooth or lightly fissured when young, becoming dark gray and deeply fissured on old trees. The twigs are grayish-yellow and stout, with large triangular leaf scars. The winter buds are slender, pointed, {{convert|1|–|2|cm|in|frac=4}} long, yellowish brown, and resinous. It is one of the fastest growing trees in North America. In Mississippi River bottoms, height growth of {{convert|10|–|15|ft|m|round=5}} per year for a few years have been seen. Sustained height growth of {{convert|5|ft|m|abbr=off|adj=on|sp=us}} height growth and {{convert|1|in|cm|abbr=off|adj=on|sp=us}} diameter growth per year for 25 years is common.

The [[leaf|leaves]] are large, deltoid (triangular), {{convert|4|–|10|cm|in|frac=4|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|4|–|11|cm|in|frac=4|abbr=on}} broad with a truncated (flattened) base and a petiole {{convert|3|–|12|cm|in|frac=4|abbr=on}} long. The leaf is very coarsely toothed, the teeth are curved and gland tipped, and the petiole is flat; they are dark green in the summer and turn yellow in the fall (but many cottonwoods in dry locations drop their leaves early from the combination of drought and leaf rust, making their fall color dull or absent). Due to the flat stem of the leaf, the leaf has the tendency to shake from even the slightest breeze. This is one of the identifying characteristics.<ref>Barnes and Wagner, Michigan Trees, University of Michigan Press, 2004</ref>

It is [[plant sexuality|dioecious]], with the [[flower]]s ([[catkin]]s) produced on single-sex trees in early spring. The male (pollen) catkins are reddish-purple and {{convert|8|–|10|cm|in|frac=4|abbr=on}} long; the female catkins are green, {{convert|7|–|13|cm|in|frac=4|abbr=on}} long at pollination, maturing {{convert|15|–|20|cm|in|frac=4|abbr=on}} long with several {{convert|6|to|15|mm|in|frac=16|abbr=off|adj=on|sp=us}} seed capsules in early summer, which split open to release the numerous small [[seeds]] attached to [[cotton]]-like strands.<ref name=usgs>USGS Aquatic and Wetland Vascular Plants of the Northern Great Plains: A successful, simple, reproducible, high frequency micropropagation protocol has been described by Yadav Rakesh et al., 2009 [http://www.springerlink.com/content/553472252334p7kq/fulltext.pdf] [http://www.npwrc.usgs.gov/resource/plants/vascplnt/species/popu.htm ''Populus deltoides'']</ref><ref name=vplants>v-Plants (Chicago Herbarium): [http://www.vplants.org/plants/species/species.jsp?gid=32313 ''Populus deltoides'']</ref><ref name=silvics>{{Silvics |first=David F. |last=Van Haverbeke |volume=2 |genus=Populus |species=deltoides}}</ref>

== Variation ==
The species is divided into three [[subspecies]]<ref name=grin /><ref name=Eckenwal>{{cite journal|author=Eckenwalder, J.E. |year=1977 |title= North American cottonwoods (Populus, Salicaceae) of sections Abaso and Aigeiros |journal=Journal of the Arnold Arboretum |volume=58 |issue=3 |pages=193–208}}</ref> or up to five [[Variety (botany)|varieties]].<ref name=plantlist>{{citation|title= The Plant List: A working list of all plant species |publisher=Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew and Missouri Botanical Garden |url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl/record/tro-50295598}}</ref> The subspecies classification is as follows:
*'''''Populus deltoides'' subsp. ''deltoides''''',  '''eastern cottonwood''' is found in southeastern Canada (the south of [[Ontario]] and [[Quebec]]) and the eastern United States (throughout, west to [[North Dakota]] to [[Texas]]).
*'''''P. d. monilifera''''' (Aiton) Eckenw., the '''plains cottonwood''' (syn. ''P. deltoides'' var. ''occidentalis'' Rydb.; ''P. sargentii'' Dode) ranges from southcentral Canada (southern [[Alberta]], [[Saskatchewan]], and [[Manitoba]]) to the central United States and south to northern [[New Mexico]] and [[Texas]].
*'''''P. d. wislizeni''''' (S.Watson) Eckenw., the '''Rio Grande cottonwood''' (syn. ''P. wislizeni'' (S.Watson) Sarg.; ''P. fremontii'' var. ''wislizeni'' S.Watson) grows from southern [[Colorado]] south through [[Texas]] to northeastern Mexico ([[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], [[San Luis Potosi]]), and west to [[Arizona]] (presence in [[California]], listed by GRIN,<ref name=grin /> is doubtful, not included in the Jepson ''Flora of California''<ref name=jeps>Jepson Flora: [http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/cgi-bin/get_JM_treatment.pl?Populus ''Populus'']; clicking 'next taxon' through the genus shows no entry for this taxon)</ref>). (Note: Some sources mistakenly spell the epithet "''wislizenii''." Correct spelling is with one "i," per ICN article 60C.2.<ref>J. McMeill et al. (eds). 2012. International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants. Regnum Vegetabile 154. Koeltz Scientific Books. ISBN 978-3-87429-425-6</ref>)

== Ecology ==
It needs bare soil and full sun for successful germination and establishment; in natural conditions, it usually grows near [[river]]s, with mud banks left after [[flood]]s providing ideal conditions for seedling germination; human soil cultivation has allowed it to increase its range away from such habitats.<ref name=silvics />

The leaves serve as food for [[caterpillar]]s of various [[Lepidoptera]] ([[List of Lepidoptera that feed on poplars]]).

== Oldest and largest ==
[[File:Cottonwood 20090521 083459 1.jpg|thumbnail|Seeds and seed hairs from an eastern cottonwood]]
Eastern cottonwoods typically live 70 to 100 years, but they have the potential to live 200 to 400 years if they have a good growing environment.

The [[Balmville Tree]] (cut in 2015) was the oldest eastern cottonwood in the United States.

<!-- The following information's citations are not available and the widths quoted are not for diameter at breast height--they represent crown spread. -->
*The US national champion ''Populus deltoides'' var. ''deltoides'' is located in [[Beatrice, Nebraska]] and measures {{convert|88|ft|m|abbr=on}} tall, {{convert|108|ft|m|abbr=on}} wide.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.americanforests.org/bigtree/eastern-cottonwood-populus-deltoides-ssp-deltoides-3/ |title=Eastern Cottonwood (Populus deltoides ssp. deltoides)
 |author=American Forests |year=2013 |accessdate=July 14, 2016}}</ref>
*The US national champion ''Populus deltoides'' var. ''monilifera'' is located in [[Ravalli County, Montana]] and measures {{convert|112|ft|m|abbr=on}} tall, {{convert|94|ft|m|abbr=on}} wide.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.americanforests.org/bigtree/plains-cottonwood-populus-deltoides-ssp-monilifera-3/ |title=Plains Cottonwood (''Populus deltoides'' ssp. ''monilifera'') |author=American Forests |year=2012 |accessdate=July 14, 2016}}</ref>
*The US national champion ''Populus deltoides'' var. ''wislizeni'' is located in [[Bernalillo County, New Mexico]] and measures {{convert|84|ft|m|abbr=on}} tall, {{convert|83|ft|m|abbr=on}} wide.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.americanforests.org/bigtree/rio-grande-cottonwood-populus-deltoides-ssp-wislizeni-3/ |title=Rio grande Cottonwood (''Populus deltoides'' ssp. ''wislizeni'') |author=American Forests |year=2012 |accessdate=July 14, 2016}}</ref>

The largest recorded cottonwood tree in the world is the Frimley Park tree located in Hastings, New Zealand.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://register.notabletrees.org.nz/tree/view/210 | work = The Zealand Tree Register | title = Tree Information | accessdate = 12 May 2012}}</ref>

There is an unregistered Cottonwood tree in West Central Oklahoma that until recently had a circumference at breast height of {{convert|56|ft|2|in|m}}.  It was split in half and that remaining standing is now {{convert|32|ft|8|in|m}}.{{clarify|reason=in circumference? What species of "cottonwood" is it?|date=January 2016}}{{citation needed|date=January 2016}}

== Symbolism ==
Calling the cottonwood tree "the pioneer of the prairie", the Kansas state legislature designated the cottonwood the official state tree of [[Kansas]] in 1937.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Q_lOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WEwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5320%2C4181963 | title=Tidbits | work=Ludington Daily News | date=Aug 4, 2001 | accessdate=15 October 2015 | pages=33}}</ref>

126.text:
{{taxobox
|image = Cottonwood at Zion Lodge.jpg
|image_caption = Fremont Cottonwood at Zion Lodge, [[Zion National Park]], [[Utah]]
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Malpighiales]]
|familia = [[Salicaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Populus]]''
|sectio = ''[[Populus sect. Aigeiros|Aigeiros]]''
|species = '''''P. fremontii'''''
|binomial = ''Populus fremontii''
|binomial_authority = [[Sereno Watson|S. Watson]]
|range_map =  Populus fremontii range map 2.png
|range_map_caption = Natural range of ''P. fremontii''
|}}

'''''Populus fremontii''''', commonly known as '''Fremont's cottonwood''' or the '''Alamo cottonwood''', is a [[Populus sect. Aigeiros|cottonwood]] (and thus a [[Populus|poplar]]) native to [[riparian zones]] of the [[Southwestern United States]] and northern through central [[Mexico]].<ref name=grin>{{cite web|url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?404966|title=''Populus fremontii''|publisher=NPGS/GRIN}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://plants.usda.gov/core/profile?symbol=POFR2|work=USDA Plants Profile|title=''Populus fremontii'' (Fremont's cottonwood)}}</ref><ref name="ucjeps">{{cite book|chapterurl=http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/eflora/eflora_display.php?tid=52463|title=Jepson Manual|chapter=''Populus fremontii'' subsp. ''fremontii''|publisher=University of California Press|year=1993}}</ref> It is one of three species in ''Populus'' sect.'' Aigeiros''.

==Distribution==
The tree is native to the Southwestern United States and Mexico.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.calflora.org/cgi-bin/species_query.cgi?where-taxon=Populus+fremontii|work=Calflora Database|title=''Populus fremontii'' (Fremont cottonwood)}}</ref> In the United States, the species can be found in [[California]], [[Nevada]], [[Utah]], [[Arizona]], [[New Mexico]], [[Texas]], and [[Colorado]]. In Mexico, it can be found in [[Baja California]], [[Baja California Sur]], [[Sonora]] , [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], [[Coahuila]], [[Nuevo León]], [[Mexico State]], and [[Puebla]].<ref name=grin/>

The riparian tree grows near streams, rivers, [[Spring (hydrosphere)|spring]]s, [[Seep (hydrology)|seep]]s, [[wetlands]], and well-watered [[alluvium|alluvial]] bottomlands at elevations below {{convert|2000|m|ft|abbr=on}} elevation.<ref name="ucjeps"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://plants.usda.gov/factsheet/pdf/fs_pofr2.pdf|publisher=United States Department of Agriculture|accessdate=February 5, 2002|title=USDA Plant Fact Sheet}}</ref>

==Description==
[[File:Populus fremontii ssp. fremontii 001.jpg|thumb|Leaf: ''Populus fremontii'' ssp.'' fremontii'']]
''P. fremontii'' is a large tree growing from {{convert|12|-|35|m|ft|abbr=on}} in height with a wide crown, with a trunk up to {{convert|1.5|m|ft|abbr=on}} in diameter. The [[bark]] is smooth when young, becoming deeply fissured with whitish cracked bark on old trees.

The {{convert|3|-|7|cm|in|abbr=on}} long [[leaves]], are [[cordate]] (''heart-shaped'') with an elongate tip, with white veins and coarse [[crenate|crenate teeth]] along the sides, glabrous to hairy, and often stained with milky resin.<ref name="ucjeps"/> Autumn colors occur from October–November, mainly a bright yellow, also orange, rarely red.<ref name="ucjeps"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://extension.usu.edu/rangeplants/htm/fremont-cottonwood|publisher=Utah State University|title=Range Plants of Utah}}</ref>

The [[inflorescence]] consists of a long drooping [[catkin]], which blooms from March to April. The [[fruit]] is a [[Biological dispersal|wind dispersed]] [[achene]], that appears to look like patches of [[cotton]] hanging from limbs, thus the name cottonwood.

The largest known ''P. fremontii'' tree in the United States grows in Skull Valley, Arizona. In 2012, it had a measured circumference of {{convert|557|in|cm ft|abbr=on}}, height of {{convert|102|ft|m|abbr=on}}, and a spread of {{convert|149.5|ft|m |abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americanforests.org/bigtree/fremont-cottonwood-populus-fremontii-ssp-fremontii-3/|title=''Populus fremontii'' ssp. ''fremontii''|publisher=American Forests}}</ref>

=== Subspecies or varieties===
Two subspecies are currently recognized. Some confusion due to hybridization with a Rio Grande subspecies of [[Populus deltoides|''Populus deltoides'' subsp. ''wislizeni'']] had originally placed this [[Populus deltoides|eastern cottonwood]] subspecies as a ''P. fremontii'' subspecies, but it was removed in 1977.<ref name=Eckenwal>{{cite journal|author=Eckenwalder, J.E. |year=1977 |title= North American cottonwoods (''Populus'', Salicaceae) of sections ''Abaso'' and ''Aigeiros'' |journal=Journal of the Arnold Arboretum |volume=58 |issue=3 |pages=193–208}}</ref>
* ''P. f.'' subsp. ''fremontii'', with synonyms ''P. f.'' var. ''arizonica'' - [[Charles Sprague Sargent|Sarg.]] and ''P. f. ''var.'' macdougalii'' - ([[Joseph Nelson Rose|Rose]]) [[Willis Linn Jepson|Jeps.]] from California and west of the [[Continental Divide of the Americas|Continental Divide]]<ref name=Eckenwal/>
* ''P. f.'' subsp. ''metesae'' - Eckenwal., of arid areas of Mexico, and widely planted elsewhere, generally east of the Continental Divide<ref name=Eckenwal/>

==Uses==

===Cultivation===
''P. fremontii'' is cultivated as an [[ornamental tree]] and [[riparian zone restoration]] tree. It is used in planting for: wildlife food and shelter [[habitat]]s and [[ecological restoration]]; larger [[native plant]] and [[wildlife garden]]s and [[natural landscaping]] projects,<ref name="ucjeps" /> windbreaks, [[erosion control]], and shade for recreation facilities, parks, and livestock.

Fremont cottonwood was used in the past by settlers and ranchers for fuel and fence posts.

===Native Americans===
;Traditional medicine
[[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] in the Western United States and Mexico used parts of the Fremont cottonwood variously for a medicine, in [[basket weaving]], tool making, and for [[musical instrument]]s. The inner bark of Fremont cottonwood contains [[vitamin C]] and was chewed as an [[Scurvy|antiscorbutic]], or treatment for vitamin C deficiency. The bark and leaves could be used to make [[poultice]]s to reduce [[Swelling (medical)|inflammation]] or to treat [[wound]]s.

;Art
The  [[Pima people]] of southern Arizona and northern Mexico lived along [[Sonoran Desert]] watercourses and used [[twig]]s from the tree in the fine and intricate baskets they wove. The [[Cahuilla people]] of southern California used the tree's wood for tool making, the [[Puebloan peoples|Pueblo peoples]] for [[drum]]s, and the [[Colorado River|Lower Colorado River]] [[Quechan people]] in ritual cremations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mojavedesert.net/trees/cottonwood|publisher=MojaveDesert.net|date=n.d.|title=Digital Desert: Mojave Desert}}</ref> The Hopi of Northeastern Arizona carve the root of the cottonwood to create kachina dolls.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Padgett|first1=Kenneth|title=Kachina Dolls|url=http://kachina.us/|website=Guide to Hopi Kachina (katsina) Dolls|accessdate=September 8, 2015}}</ref>

127.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Populus'' sect. ''Aigeiros''}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Populus'' sect. ''Aigeiros''
|image = Bosque del Apache National Wildlife Refuge (10440965175).jpg
|image_caption =''Populus fremontii''
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Malpighiales]]
|familia = [[Salicaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Populus]]''
|sectio = '''''Aigeiros'''''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/29498#page/9/mode/1up#page/923/mode/1up |title=Botanicon Gallicum; seu, Synopsis plantarum in flora Gallica descriptarum |first1=Augustin Pyramus |last1=de Candolle |first2=Jean Étienne |last2=Duby |edition=second |publisher=Desray, Paris |year=1828 |volume=1 |page=427}}</ref>
|sectio_authority = [[Jean Étienne Duby|Duby]]
|subdivision_ranks = Species
|subdivision = *''[[Populus deltoides]]'' [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]
*''[[Populus fremontii]]''
*''[[Populus nigra]]'' [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]
|}}
'''''Populus'' section ''Aigeiros''''' is a [[section (botany)|section]] of three species in the genus ''[[Populus]]'', the poplars. Like some other species in the genus ''Populus'', they are commonly known as [[cottonwood (disambiguation)|cottonwood]]s. The species are native to North America, Europe, and western Asia. In the past, as many as six species were recognized, but recent trends have been to accept just three species, treating the others as subspecies of ''P. deltoides''.


They are large, deciduous trees. they are 20–45f tall, distinguished by thick, deeply fissured bark and triangular-based to diamond-shaped leaves that are green on both sides (without the whitish wax on the undersides) and without any obvious balsam scent in spring. An important feature of the leaves is the [[Petiole (botany)petiole, which is flattened sideways so that the leaves have a particular type of movement in the wind.

Male and female flowers are in separate catkins, appearing before the leaves in spring.  The seeds are borne on cottony structures that allow them to be blown long distances in the air before settling to ground.

The cottonwoods are exceptionally tolerant of flooding, erosion, and flood deposits filling around the trunk.

Although each of the three cottonwood species has a different leaf pattern, they all have the same general diamond leaf shape.

==Species==
===''Populus deltoides''===
[[File:Cottonwood 20090521 083459 1.jpg|thumbnail|Seeds and seed hairs from an eastern cottonwood]]

[[Populus deltoides|Eastern cottonwood]] (''Populus deltoides'') is one of the largest North American [[hardwood]] trees, although the wood is rather soft. It is a [[riparian zone]] tree. It occurs throughout the eastern United States and in extreme southern Canada. The [[leaf|leaves]] are alternate and simple, with coarsely toothed (crenate/serrate) edges, and subcordate at the base. The leaf shape is roughly triangular, hence the species name, ''deltoides''.

In the typical subspecies ''P. d. deltoides'' ([[Vermont]] south to northern [[Florida]] and west to about [[Michigan]]), the leaves are broad and triangular, 7–15 cm across at the base. Further west ([[Minnesota]] south to eastern [[Texas]]), the subspecies ''P. d. monilifera'' (plains cottonwood; syn. ''P. sargentii'') has somewhat narrower leaves, 5–10 cm wide at the base. This is also the [[list of U.S. state trees|state tree]] of [[Nebraska]], [[Wyoming]], and [[Kansas]]. In West Texas, [[New Mexico]], and [[Colorado]], the subspecies ''P. d. wislizeni'' (Rio Grande cottonwood; syn. ''P. wislizeni'') occurs.

===''Populus fremontii''===
[[Populus fremontii|Fremont's cottonwood]] (''Populus fremontii'') is native to the southwestern United States and western Mexico.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.calflora.org/cgi-bin/species_query.cgi?where-taxon=Populus+fremontii|work=Calflora Database|title=''Populus fremontii'' (Fremont cottonwood)}}</ref> In the United States, the species can be found in [[California]], [[Nevada]], [[Utah]]. [[Arizona]], [[New Mexico]], [[Texas]] and [[Colorado]]. In Mexico, it can be found in the states of [[Baja California]], [[Baja California Sur]], [[Sonora]] , [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], [[Coahuila]], [[Nuevo León]], [[Mexico State]], and [[Puebla]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?404966|title=''Populus fremontii''|publisher=NPGS/GRIN}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://plants.usda.gov/core/profile?symbol=POFR2|work=USDA Plants Profile|title=''Populus fremontii'' (Fremont's cottonwood)}}</ref>  It differs from the eastern cottonwood mainly in the leaves having fewer, larger serrations on the edge, and small differences in the flower and seed pod structure. Some taxonomists formerly considered ''P. fremontii'' to be a subspecies of ''P. deltoides''.<ref>{{cite web|first=Al|last=Schneider|url=http://www.swcoloradowildflowers.com/Tree%20Enlarged%20Photo%20Pages/populus%20deltoides.htm|title=Populus deltoides|work=Wildflowers, Ferns, and Trees of Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona, and Utah}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bonap.org/BONAPmaps2010/Populus.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425154646/http://bonap.org/BONAPmaps2010/Populus.html|archivedate=2012-04-25|title=Populus|work=North American Plant Atlas|publisher=BONAP}}</ref>

===''Populus nigra''===
[[Populus nigra|Black poplar]] (''Populus nigra'') is native to Europe and Western Asia, is distinct in its much smaller leaves, {{convert|5|-|11|cm}} across, with a more rhombic (diamond) shape.

==Cultivation and uses==
Cottonwoods are widely grown for [[timber]] production along wet river banks, where their exceptional growth rate provides a large crop of wood within just 10–30 years. The wood is coarse and of fairly low value, used for pallet boxes, shipping crates, and similar purposes where a cheap but strong enough wood is suitable. They are also widely grown as screens and [[shelterbelt]]s. Many of the cottonwoods grown commercially are the [[Hybrid (biology)|hybrid]] of eastern cottonwood and black poplar, ''Populus × canadensis'' (hybrid black poplar or Carolina poplar).

Cottonwood bark is often a favorite medium for artisans. The bark, which is usually harvested in the fall after a tree's death, is generally very soft and easy to carve.

Cottonwood is one of the poorest [[wood fuel]]s; it does not dry well, and rots quickly. It splits poorly, because it is very fibrous. It produces a low level of energy per unit of volume of wood.<ref>[http://www.chimneysweeponline.com/howood.htm Sweep's Library: Firewood Comparison Charts] The Chimney Sweep.</ref>

Cottonwoods serve as food for the [[caterpillar]]s of several [[Lepidoptera]] ([[list of Lepidoptera that feed on poplars]]).

128.text:
{{italictitle}}
{{distinguish2|European aspen, ''[[Populus tremula]]'', which is also called quaking aspen}}
{{For|other trees called "white poplar"|White poplar}}
{{Taxobox
| name               = Quaking aspen
| image              = 2013-10-06 15 04 21 Aspens during autumn along the Changing Canyon Nature Trail in Lamoille Canyon, Nevada.jpg
| image_caption      = Quaking aspen grove in [[Lamoille Canyon]], [[Nevada]], U.S.
| regnum             = [[Plant]]ae
| unranked_divisio   = [[Angiosperms]]
| unranked_classis   = [[Eudicots]]
| unranked_ordo      = [[Rosids]]
| ordo               = [[Malpighiales]]
| familia            = [[Salicaceae]]
| genus              = ''[[Populus]]''
| sectio             = ''[[Aspen|Populus]]''
| species            = '''''P. tremuloides'''''
| binomial           = ''Populus tremuloides''
| binomial_authority = [[André Michaux|Michx.]]
| range_map          = Populus tremuloides range map 2.png
}}
'''''Populus tremuloides''''' is a [[deciduous]] tree native to cooler areas of [[North America]], one of several species referred to by the common name [[aspen]]. It is commonly called '''quaking aspen''',<ref name="NPS" /><ref name=GRIN>{{GRIN|29424|Populus tremuloides}}</ref><ref name="Silvics">{{Silvics |volume=2 |genus=Populus |species=tremuloides |first=D. A. |last=Perala}}</ref> '''trembling aspen''',<ref name="NPS" /><ref name=GRIN /> '''American aspen''',<ref name=GRIN /> '''Quakies''',<ref name="NPS" /> '''mountain''' or '''golden aspen''',<ref name=wood>{{cite web|url=http://www.fpl.fs.fed.us/documnts/TechSheets/HardwoodNA/pdf_files/popaspeneng.pdf|title=technology transfer fact sheet: ''Populus'' spp.|work=Forest Products Laboratory: R&D USDA |publisher=United States Department of Agriculture Forest Service, Center for Wood Anatomy Research|location=Madison, Wisconsin|date=|accessdate=20 September 2010}}</ref> '''trembling poplar''',<ref name=wood /> '''white poplar''',<ref name=wood /> '''popple''',<ref name=wood /> and even more names.<ref name=wood /> The trees have tall trunks, up to 25 meters (82 feet) tall, with smooth pale bark, scarred with black. The glossy green leaves, dull beneath, become golden to yellow, rarely red, in autumn. The species often propagates through its roots to form large clonal groves originating from a shared root system. These roots are not rhizomes, as new growth develops from advantitious buds on the parent root system (the ortet).

''Populus tremuloides'' is the most widely distributed tree in North America, being found from Canada to central Mexico.<ref name="Silvics" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arborday.org/treeguide/treedetail.cfm?id=122 |publisher=[[Arbor Day Foundation]] |title=Aspen, Quaking (Populus tremuloides)}}</ref> It is the defining species of the [[aspen parkland]] [[biome]] in the [[Prairie Provinces]] of Canada and extreme northwest [[Minnesota]].

== Name ==
The quaking or trembling of the leaves that is referred to in the common names is due to the flexible flattened [[Petiole (botany)|petioles]]. The specific epithet, ''tremuloides'', evokes this trembling behavior and can be literally translated as "like [[Populus tremula|''(Populus) tremula'']]", the European trembling aspen.

Some species of ''Populus'' have petioles flattened partially along their length, while the aspens and some other poplars have them flattened from side to side along the entire length of the petiole.

== Description ==
[[File:2015-03-16 12 22 15 Aspen catkins on Idaho Street (Interstate 80 Business) in Elko, Nevada.JPG|thumb|left|Aspen [[Catkin|catkins]] in spring]]
Quaking aspen is a tall, fast growing tree, usually {{convert|20|-|25|m|ft|round=5|abbr=on}} at maturity, with a trunk {{convert|20|to|80|cm|ftin|0|abbr=in}} in diameter; records are {{convert|36.5|m|ftin|abbr=on}} in height and {{convert|1.37|m|ftin|abbr=on}} in diameter.

The bark is relatively smooth, colored greenish-white to gray, and is marked by thick black horizontal scars and prominent black knots. Parallel vertical scars are tell-tale signs of elk, which strip off aspen bark with their front teeth.

The leaves on mature trees are nearly round, {{convert|4|–|8|cm|frac=4|sp=us|abbr=off}} in diameter with small rounded teeth, and a {{convert|3|–|7|cm|frac=4|adj=on|sp=us|abbr=off}} long, flattened petiole. Young trees and root sprouts have much larger ({{convert|10|–|20|cm|in|0|disp=comma|sp=us}} long) nearly triangular leaves.

Aspens are dioecious, with separate male and female clones. The flowers are catkins {{convert|4|–|6|cm|frac=4|sp=us}} long, produced in early spring before the leaves;  The fruit is a {{convert|10|cm|in|0|adj=mid|-long|abbr=off|sp=us}} pendulous string of {{convert|6|mm|in|frac=16|adj=on|abbr=off|sp=us}} capsules, each capsule containing about ten minute seeds embedded in cottony fluff, which aids wind dispersal of the seeds when they are mature in early summer.

The quaking aspen is the State Tree of Utah.<ref>{{cite web|title=S.B. 41 State Tree Change|url=http://le.utah.gov/~2014/bills/static/SB0041.html|work=Utah State Legislature}}</ref>

== Distribution ==
Quaking aspen occurs across [[Canada]] in all provinces and territories, with the possible exception of [[Nunavut]]. In the [[United States]], it can be found as far north as the northern foothills of the [[Brooks Range]] in [[Alaska]], where road margins and gravel pads provide islands of well-drained habitat in a region where soils are often waterlogged due to underlying [[permafrost]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ackerman|first=Daniel|last2=Breen|first2=Amy|date=2016-06-06|title=Infrastructure Development Accelerates Range Expansion of Trembling Aspen ( Populus tremuloides , Salicaceae) into the Arctic|url=http://arctic.journalhosting.ucalgary.ca/arctic/index.php/arctic/article/view/4560|journal=ARCTIC|language=en|volume=69|issue=2|pages=130–136|doi=10.14430/arctic4560|issn=1923-1245}}</ref> It occurs at low elevations as far south as northern [[Nebraska]] and central [[Indiana]]. In the western [[United States]], this tree rarely survives at elevations lower than {{convert|1500|ft|m}} due to hot summers experienced below that elevation, and is generally found at {{convert|5000|-|12000|ft|m}}. It grows at high altitudes as far south as [[Guanajuato]], Mexico.

Quaking aspen grows in a wide variety of climatic conditions. January and July average temperatures range from {{convert|-30|C|F}} and {{convert|16|C|F}} in the [[Alaska Interior]] to {{convert|-3|C|F}} and {{convert|23|C|F}} in [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]]. Average annual precipitation ranges from {{convert|1020|mm|in|abbr=in}} in [[Gander, Newfoundland and Labrador]] to as little as {{convert|180|mm|in|abbr=in}} in the Alaska Interior. The southern limit of the species' range roughly follows the {{convert|24|C|F}} mean July [[isotherm (contour line)|isotherm]].<ref name="Silvics" />

Shrub-like dwarf clones exist in marginal environments too cold and dry to be hospitable to full-size trees, for example at the species' upper elevation limits in the [[White Mountains (California)|White Mountains]].

[[File:Reflection of tree.JPG|thumb|Trembling aspen at sunset]]

== Ecology ==
[[File:Quakingfallcolors.JPG||thumb|left|Individual clonal colonies can be discerned during the autumn, as seen on this mountainside in the [[Matanuska Valley]] in [[Alaska]].]]
Quaking aspen propagates itself primarily through root sprouts, and extensive [[clonal colony|clonal colonies]] are common. Each colony is its own clone, and all trees in the clone have identical characteristics and share a single root structure. A clone may turn color earlier or later in the fall than its neighbouring aspen clones. Fall colors are usually bright tones of yellow; in some areas, red blushes may be occasionally seen. As all trees in a given clonal colony are considered part of the same organism, one clonal colony, named [[Pando (tree)|Pando]], is considered the heaviest<ref name="multiple1">Genetic Variation and the Natural History of Quaking Aspen, Jeffry B. Mitton; Michael C. Grant, ''BioScience'', Vol. 46, No. 1. (Jan., 1996), pp. 25-31.</ref> and oldest<ref name=NPS>[http://www.nps.gov/brca/naturescience/quakingaspen.htm Quaking Aspen] by the [[Bryce Canyon]] [[National Park Service]]</ref> living organism at six million kilograms and perhaps 80,000 years old. Aspens do produce seeds, but seldom grow from them. Pollination is inhibited by the fact that aspens are either male or female, and large stands are usually all clones of the same sex. Even if pollinated, the small seeds (three million per pound) are only viable a short time as they lack a stored food source or a protective coating.<ref name="Ewing, Susan 1996">Ewing, Susan. The Great Alaska Nature Factbook. Portland: Alaska Northwest Books, 1996.</ref>

=== Dieback ===
Beginning in 1996, individual North American scientists noticed an increase in dead or dying aspen trees. As this accelerated in 2004, word spread and a debate over causes began. No insect, disease, or environmental condition is yet specifically identified as a joint cause. Trees adjacent to one another are often stricken or not. In other instances, entire groves have died.

Many areas of the Western US have experienced increased diebacks which are often attributed to ungulate grazing and [[wildfire suppression]]. At high altitudes where grasses can be rare, [[ungulate]]s can browse young aspen sprouts and prevent those young trees from reaching maturity. As a result, some aspen groves close to cattle or other grazing animals, such as deer or elk, have very few young trees and can be invaded by [[conifers]], which are not typically browsed. Another possible deterrent to aspen regeneration is widespread wildfire suppression.  Aspens are vigorous [[resprouter]]s and even though the above-ground portion of the organism may die in a wild-fire, the roots, which are often protected from lethal temperatures during a fire, will sprout new trees soon after a fire.  Disturbances such as fires seem to be a necessary ecological event in order for aspens to compete with conifers, which tend to replace aspen over long, disturbance-free intervals.  The current dieback in the American West may have roots in the strict fire suppression policy in the United States.{{citation needed|date=June 2012}} On the other hand, the widespread decimation of conifer forests by the [[mountain pine beetle]] may provide increased opportunities for aspen groves to proliferate under the right conditions.<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0378112713000352 | doi=10.1016/j.foreco.2013.01.008 | volume=299 | title=How will aspen respond to mountain pine beetle? A review of literature and discussion of knowledge gaps | journal=Forest Ecology and Management | pages=60–69}}</ref>

Because of the vegetative regeneration method of reproduction used by the aspen, where an entire group of trees are essentially clones, there is a concern that something that hits one will eventually kill all of the trees, presuming they share the same vulnerability. A conference was held in Utah in September 2006 to share notes and consider investigative methodology.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/26/science/earth/26aspen.html | work=The New York Times | first=Katie | last=Kelley | title=Emblem of the West Is Dying, and No One Can Figure Out Why | date=26 September 2006}}</ref>
[[File:Populus tremuloides 8163.jpg|thumb|Typical yellow autumn foliage]]
[[File:2014-10-05 14 33 30 Aspens showing autumn foliage coloration in Lamoille Canyon, Nevada.JPG|thumb|right|Atypical orange and red autumn foliage]]

== Uses ==
Aspen bark contains a substance that was extracted by indigenous North Americans and European settlers of the western U.S. as a [[quinine]] substitute.<ref name="Ewing, Susan 1996" />

Like other poplars, aspens make poor [[fuel wood]], as they dry slowly, rot quickly, and do not give off much heat. Yet they are still widely used in campgrounds because they are cheap and plentiful and not widely used in building lumber. Pioneers in the North American west used them to create [[log cabins]] and [[dugout (shelter)|dugouts]], though they were not the preferred species.

The leaves of the quaking aspen and other species in the genus ''Populus'' serve as food for [[caterpillar]]s of various moths and butterflies. See [[List of Lepidoptera that feed on poplars]].

In Canada, quaking aspen wood is used mainly for pulp products such as books, newsprint, and fine printing paper. It is especially good for panel products such as [[oriented strand board]] and [[waferboard]]. It is light in weight and is used for furniture, boxes and crates, core stock in plywood, and wall panels.
