155.text:
{{taxobox
|status = EN
|status_system = IUCN
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Fagales]]
|familia = [[Fagaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Quercus]]''
|species = '''''Q. delgadoana'''''
|binomial = ''Quercus delgadoana''
|binomial_authority = S.Valencia, Nixon & L.M.Kelly
|range_map = Sierra_Madre_Oriental_Oak-Pine_Forests_map.svg
|range_map_caption = Natural range of ''Quercus delgadoana''
|range_map_alt = Map showing natural range of Quercus delgadoana
}}

'''''Quercus delgadoana''''' is an [[endangered species]] of [[oak]] in the family [[Fagaceae]], found in eastern [[Mexico]]. It was originally misidentified as other members of the genus ''[[Quercus]]'', but was determined as a new species in 2011.<ref name=Valencia>{{cite journal |author=Valencia Avalos, Susana, Kevin C. Nixon & Lawrence M. Kelly |year=2011 |title=''Quercus delgadoana'' (Fagaceae), a new species from the Sierra Madre Oriental, Mexico |journal=Novon |volume=21 |issue=2 |pages=274–277 |doi=10.3417/2009054}}</ref>

==Distribution==
''Quercus delgadoana'' is endemic to the [[Sierra Madre Oriental]], in the states of Hidalgo, Puebla, and Veracruz.<ref name=Valencia />

==Habitat and ecology==
''Quercus delgadoana'' has been found in [[cloud forest]] communities and humid forests at high altitudes of {{convert|1400|-|2210|m}}. This species is commonly found with many other species of the same genus ''[[Quercus]]'' such as ''Q. affinis'' and ''Q. lancifolia'', but is also found with members of different genera such as ''[[Fagus grandifolia]]'' (North American beech).<ref name=Valencia />

==Morphology==
Individuals of this species are oak trees that grow up to {{convert|25|m|ft|abbr=on}} tall and have trunks {{convert|0.5|-|1.2|m|ft|abbr=on}} in diameter.<ref name=Valencia /> These oaks are often among the tallest trees in the wet montane forests. They are characterized by their {{convert|1.8|-|4|mm|2|adj=on}} thick branchlets and lance-shaped leaves with revolute margins. They bear acorns as fruits and have pistillate flowers on a short {{convert|1.5|-|8|mm|2|adj=on}} stalk, which have 1 or 2 distal flowers.<ref name=Valencia />

''Quercus delgadoana'' was determined as a new species because, unlike ''Q. eugeniifolia'' with fruit with [[Annual plant|annual]] maturation, this species has fruit with [[Biennial plant|biennial]] maturation. In addition, this new species can be distinguished from other similar species such as ''[[Quercus laurina|Q. laurina]]'' and ''Q. affinis'' because it has more secondary veins, a revolute blade margin, and an adaxial leaf surface without stellate [[trichome]]s.<ref name=Valencia />

==Flowers and fruit==
Flowers of ''Quercus delgadoana'' may develop in March, but only pistillate flowers can be observed; fruits with biennial maturation can be found in October and November. The fruits take two years to mature and are presented on the terminal twigs.<ref name=Valencia />

==Conservation==
''Quercus delgadoana'' was given a preliminary classification of Endangered (EN) according to the [[IUCN Red List]] criteria of 2001.<ref>IUCN. 2001. IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria, Version 3.1. Prepared by the IUCN Species Survival Commission. IUCN, Gland, Switzerland, and Cambridge, United Kingdom.</ref> These forests are highly disturbed due to the extraction of firewood, the clearance of forest for pasture, and the establishment of coffee plantations. As a result, more than 50% of the population is expected to decline. In addition, the future loss of habitat is possible.<ref name=Valencia />

==Etymology==
''Quercus delgadoana'' is named after Alfonso Delgado Salinas, in recognition of his contributions to [[plant taxonomy]] and the encouragement and training he has given to many students in this field of study.<ref name=Valencia />

==External links==

* [http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2012/06/120605172021.htm New plant and fungus species discovered]

'''''Quercus deliquescens''''' is a species of [[Quercus|oak tree]] in the [[Fagaceae]] family, native to [[Northeast Mexico]]. 

==Distribution==
The tree is [[Endemism|endemic]] to [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]] state of [[Mexico]].  

It is known only from one population system in the valley of [[Rio Conchos|Río Conchos]] and north along the [[Río Grande]].  It grows in dry montane scrub habitats.

It is an [[IUCN Red List]] [[Vulnerable species]], threatened by [[habitat loss]].

==See also==
*{{C|Endemic flora of Mexico}}

'''''Quercus devia''''' is a species of [[Quercus|oak tree]] in the [[Fagaceae]] family, native to northwestern [[Mexico]]. 

The tree is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[Sierra de la Laguna]] range of the [[Peninsular Ranges]] system, located in northern [[Baja California]] state of [[Mexico]].  It grows in [[Sierra de la Laguna pine-oak forests]] habitats.

It is an [[IUCN Red List]] [[Vulnerable species]], threatened by [[habitat loss]].

'''''Quercus diversifolia''''' is an uncommon North American species of [[oak]] native to [[Mexico]]. It has been found in the States of [[Nuevo León]], [[Durango]], [[México State|México]], and [[Puebla]]. <ref>[http://www.tropicos.org/Name/50146377?tab=specimens Tropicos, ''Quercus diversifolia'' Née ]</ref>

''Quercus diversifolia'' is a shrub or small tree 10-14 feet (3.0-4.2 meters) tall. Leaves are green on the upper surface, yellow-brown on the underside, with wavy edges.<ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/8009572#page/271/mode/1up Née, Luis 1801.  Anales de Ciencias Naturales 3: 270-271] short diagnosis in Latin, description and commentary in Spanish</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/279195#page/118/mode/1up Bonpland, Aimé Jacques Alexandre 1809.  Plantae Aequinoctiales 2: 51-53] short diagnosis in Latin, description and commentary in French, as ''Quercus ambigua''</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/279195#page/120/mode/1up Bonpland, Aimé Jacques Alexandre 1809.  Plantae Aequinoctiales 2: plant 93] full-page drawing, as ''Quercus ambigua''</ref>

Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden 89(4): 551–593] in Spanish, with line drawings of each species</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/3/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium 12(1,3): 1–93]</ref>

''Quercus dysophylla'' is a tree up to 20 meters tall. Leaves are thick and leathery, up to 17 cm long, elliptical with no teeth or lobes.<ref name=evangelina/>

'''''Quercus elliptica''''' is a Mesoamerican species of oak tree in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It is widespread across central and southern Mexico and Central America from [[Sinaloa]] and [[Hidalgo (state)|Hidalgo]] south as far as [[Nicaragua]].<ref name=evangelina>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/87374#page/565/mode/1up Romero Rangel, S., E. C. Rojas Zenteno & M. L. Aguilar Enríquez. 2002. El género ''Quercus'' (Fagaceae) en el estado de México. Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden 89(4): 551–593] in Spanish, with line drawings of each species</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/3/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium 12(1,3): 1–93]</ref><ref>García-Mendoza, A. J. & J. A. Meave. 2011. Diversidad Florística de Oaxaca: de Musgos a Angispermas 1–351. Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Ciudad Universitaria</ref><ref>Nelson Sutherland, C. H. 2001. Plantas descritas originalmente de Honduras y sus nomenclaturas equivalentas actuales. Ceiba 42(1): 1–71. </ref>

''Quercus elliptica'' is a tree up to 15 meters tall with a trunk as much as 70 cm in diameter. Leaves are thick and leathery, up to 120 mm long, elliptical with wavy edges but no teeth or lobes.<ref name=evangelina/><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/8009580#page/279/mode/1up Née, Luis 1801. Anales de Ciencias Naturales 3(9): 278] short [[Diagnosis (taxonomy)|diagnosis]] in Latin, description in Spanish</ref>

'''''Quercus excelsa''''' is a Mexican species of [[tree]] in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It has a disjunct (discontinuous) distribution, having been found only in two states, [[Veracruz]] in eastern Mexico and [[Jalisco]] in western Mexico.<ref name=w>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/43/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium 12:39-40] in English with line drawing on page 39</ref><ref>Nixon, K. et al. 1998.  [http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/32871/all ''Quercus excelsa''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/32871/all |date=June 27, 2014 }}.   [http://www.iucnredlist.org 2006 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org |date=June 27, 2014 }}  Downloaded on 23 August 2007.</ref>

''Quercus excelsa'' is a large forest tree up to 30 meters tall with a trunk 100 cm or more in diameter. Leaves are up to 22 cm long, sometimes with no lobes or teeth but sometimes with undulations or sharp teeth, green on the top, whitish and waxy on the underside.<ref name=w/>

{{Commons category|Quercus frutex}}
'''''Quercus frutex''''' is a species of [[plant]] in the [[Fagaceae]] family. It is [[Endemism|endemic]] to central [[Mexico]], found in [[México State]], [[Distrito Federal de México|D.F.]], [[Tlaxcala]], [[Hidalgo (state)|Hidalgo]], [[Jalisco]], [[Puebla]], and [[Oaxaca]].<ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/3/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium 12(1,3): 1–93]</ref><ref name=evangelina>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/87374#page/565/mode/1up Romero Rangel, S., E. C. Rojas Zenteno & M. L. Aguilar Enríquez. 2002. El género ''Quercus'' (Fagaceae) en el estado de México. Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden 89(4): 551–593] in Spanish, with line drawings of each species</ref>

''Quercus frutex'' is a shrub up to 250 cm tall (very rarely attaining tree stature at 7 meters in height), spreading by means of underground rhizomes and thus forming sizable clonal colonies. Bark is dark gray. Leaves are oblong, with no teeth or with a few shallow teeth.<ref name=evangelina/>

'''''Quercus fulva''''' is a Mexican species of [[trees]] in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It is native to northern and western Mexico, found in [[Sinaloa]], [[Durango]], [[Nayarit]], [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], and [[Coahuila]].<ref>[http://www.tropicos.org/Name/13100517?tab=specimens Tropicos, ''Quercus fulva'' Liebm.]</ref><ref name=tammy>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/45/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. ''Quercus fulva'' is a tree up to 10 meters tall with a trunk as much as 30 cm in diameter.<ref name=tammy/>

'''''Quercus galeanensis''''' is a species of [[Quercus|oak tree]] in the [[Fagaceae]] family, native to Northeastern [[Mexico]].

The tree is [[Endemism|endemic]] to Mexico, restricted to two subpopulations occupying a narrow band (150 x 10–20 km) from Galeana in [[Nuevo León]] state, to the Miquihrana region in [[Tamaulipas]] state. 

It is an [[IUCN Red List]] [[Vulnerable species]], threatened by [[habitat loss]].

'''''Quercus gentryi''''' is a Mexican species of [[oak]] in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It is native to western and northwestern Mexico, from [[Sonora]] south to [[Michoacán]] and east as far as [[Guanajuato]].<ref name=tammy/>

==Description== 
''Quercus gentryi'' is a short evergreen tree up to 15 meters tall with a trunk as much as 50 cm in diameter. Leaves are thick and rigid, up to 18 cm long, with wavy edges but no teeth or lobes.<ref name=tammy>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/47/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium  12:43-45] in English, with line drawings on page 44</ref><ref>Muller, Cornelius Herman 1942.  American Midland Naturalist 27(2): 474</ref>

'''''Quercus germana''''', the '''Mexican royal oak''', is a species of [[Quercus|oak tree]] in the [[Fagaceae]] family. 

==Description==
The tree is [[Endemism|endemic]] to eastern and northeastern [[Mexico]], in the states (north to south) of [[Tamaulipas]], [[San Luis Potosí]], [[Querétaro]], [[Veracruz]], [[Hidalgo (state)|Hidalgo]], [[Puebla]], and [[Oaxaca]].

It grows in [[cloud forest]] habitats, at elevations of {{convert|800|-|1800|m|ft}}.

''Quercus germana'' can reach {{convert|25|m|ft}} in height.

;Conservation
It is an [[IUCN Red List]] [[Vulnerable species]], threatened by [[habitat loss]].

* Nixon, K. ''et al.'' 1998;  [http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/32763/0 IUCN Red List: ''Quercus germana''] . accessed 28 January 2017.

'''''Quercus glabrescens''''' is a species of [[trees]] in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It is [[Endemism|endemic]] to central [[Mexico]], found in [[México State]], [[Hidalgo (state)|Hidalgo]], [[Puebla]], [[Veracruz]], and [[Oaxaca]].<ref name=evangelina>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/87374#page/565/mode/1up Romero Rangel, S., E. C. Rojas Zenteno & M. L. Aguilar Enríquez. 2002. El género ''Quercus'' (Fagaceae) en el estado de México. Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden 89(4): 551–593] in Spanish, with line drawings of each species</ref><ref>[http://www.tropicos.org/Name/13100576?tab=specimens Tropicos, ''Quercus glabrescens'' Benth.]</ref>

''Quercus glabrescens'' is a tree up to 15 meters tall with thick leathery leaves up to 11 cm long, elliptical or egg-shaped with a few wavy lobes along the edges.<ref name=evangelina/>

170.text:
{{italic title}} {{taxobox |image=Quercus glaucoides.JPG |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]] |ordo = [[Fagales]] |familia = [[Fagaceae]] |genus = ''[[Oak|Quercus]]'' |sectio = ''[[List of Quercus species#Section Quercus|Quercus]]'' |species = '''''Q. glaucoides''''' |binomial = ''Quercus glaucoides'' |binomial_authority = [[Martin Martens|M.Martens]] & [[Henri Guillaume Galeotti|Galeotti]] 1843
not (Schottky) Koidz. 1916 |synonyms_ref=[http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-172947 The Plant List, ''Quercus glaucoides'' M.Martens & Galeotti ] |synonyms={{collapsible list|bullets = true |''Quercus baldoquinae'' Trel. |''Quercus cancellata'' Trel. |''Quercus conjugens'' Trel. |''Quercus cordata'' M.Martens & Galeotti |''Quercus glaucophylla'' Seemen ex Loes. |''Quercus glaucophylla'' f. ''lobata'' C.H.Mull. |''Quercus glaucophylla'' f. ''longifolia'' C.H.Mull. |''Quercus glaucophylla'' f. ''macropetiolata'' C.H.Mull. |''Quercus glaucophylla'' var. ''subrotundifolia'' C.H.Mull. |''Quercus glaucophylla'' f. ''tlacolulana'' Trel. |''Quercus harmsiana'' Trel. |''Quercus mixtecana'' Trel. |}}}} '''''Quercus glaucoides''''' is an oak [[species]] in the [[List of Quercus species#Section Quercus|white oak section]], ''Quercus'' section ''Quercus'', found in and [[endemism|endemic]] to eastern, central and southern [[Mexico]] (Guanajuato, [[Guerrero]], [[México State]], [[Hidalgo (state)|Hidalgo]], [[Jalisco]], [[Michoacán]], [[Oaxaca]], [[Puebla]]). [http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/87374#page/565/mode/1up Romero Rangel, S., E. C. Rojas Zenteno & M. L. Aguilar Enríquez. 2002. El género ''Quercus'' (Fagaceae) en el estado de México. Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden 89(4): 551–593] in Spanish, with line drawings of each species[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/3/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium 12(1,3): 1–93] ==Description== ''Quercus glaucoides'' is primarily a [[Canopy (ecology)|canopy]] [[tree]] in its native [[habitat]]. It is an evergreen tree up to 10 meters tall with a trunk diameter over 40 centimeters. Leaves are thick and leathery, up to 15 cm long, with a few shallow rounded lobes. Its scientific name is often misapplied to the NE Mexican and central [[Texas]] native Lacey Oak (''[[Quercus laceyi]]''), which has caused great confusion about the true identity of this species and the correct scientific name for the Lacey Oak. Although somewhat related, they do not share the same native range, with ''Q. glaucoides'' being endemic to Mexico, while ''Q. laceyi'' is native to both NE Mexico and central Texas, and ''Q. glaucoides'' is [[evergreen]], while ''Q. laceyi'' is [[deciduous]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080331105350/http://www.eoearth.org/article/Trans-Mexican_Volcanic_Belt_pine-oak_forests Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt Pine-Oak Forests containing ''Quercus glaucoides''] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120308074727/http://fm2.fieldmuseum.org/vrrc/max/FAGA-quer-glau-mex-2065950.jpg Mexican National Herbarium specimen of ''Quercus glaucoides''] [[Category:Quercus|glaucoides]] [[Category:Endemic flora of Mexico]] [[Category:Trees of Mexico]] [[Category:Plants described in 1843]] [[Category:Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt]]
170.title: Quercus glaucoides

'''''Quercus hintonii''''' is an rare Mexican species of [[tree]] in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[State of México]] in the central part of the [[Republic of Mexico]].<ref name=evangelina>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/87374#page/565/mode/1up Romero Rangel, S., E. C. Rojas Zenteno & M. L. Aguilar Enríquez. 2002. El género ''Quercus'' (Fagaceae) en el estado de México. Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden 89(4): 551–593] in Spanish, with line drawings of each species</ref>

''Quercus hintonii'' is a deciduous tree up to 15 meters tall with a trunk as much as 50 cm in diameter. Leaves are thick and leathery, up to 21 cm long, elliptical or egg-shaped, very often with no teeth or lobes but sometimes with a few pointed teeth.<ref name=evangelina/><ref>Warburg, Edmund Frederic 1939. Bulletin of Miscellaneous Information Kew 1939: 91</ref>

''Quercus hintonii'' is threatened by [[habitat loss]]. <ref>Nixon, K. ''et al.'' 1998.  [http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/30732/all ''Quercus hintonii''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/30732/all |date=June 27, 2014 }}.   [http://www.iucnredlist.org 2006 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org |date=June 27, 2014 }}  Downloaded on 23 August 2007.</ref>

'''''Quercus hintoniorum''''' is a Mexican species of [[trees]] in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It has been found only in the States of [[Coahuila]] and [[Nuevo León]] in northeastern Mexico.<ref> Nixon, Kevin C. Muller, Cornelius Herman 1993.  Brittonia 45: 147</ref><ref>Nixon, K. '''''Quercus insignis''''' is a Mesoamerican species of [[oak]] in the [[List of Quercus species#Section Quercus|white oak section]], ''Quercus'' section ''Quercus'' within the beech family. It is native to southern [[Mexico]] and [[Central America]], from [[Veracruz]] to [[Panamá]].

==Description== 
''Quercus insignis'' is a tree. It has leaves up to 15 cm long and 8 cm across. The acorns are large and distinctive, up to 8 cm in diameter, the cup covered with extended scales that give the cup a bur-like appearance.<ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/53660#page/235/mode/1up Martens, Martin Galeotti, & Henri Guillaume 1843.  Bulletin de l'Academie Royale des Sciences et Belles-lettres de Bruxelles 10(1): 219-220] description in Latin, commentary in French</ref>

{{Commons category|Quercus laeta}}
'''''Quercus laeta''''' is an oak [[species]] in the [[List of Quercus species#Section Quercus|white oak section]], ''Quercus'' section ''Quercus'' in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It is widespread across much of Mexico from [[Sinaloa]] and [[Nuevo León]] south as far as [[Oaxaca]].<ref name=evangelina>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/87374#page/565/mode/1up Romero Rangel, S., E. C. Rojas Zenteno & M. L. Aguilar Enríquez. 2002. El género ''Quercus'' (Fagaceae) en el estado de México. Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden 89(4): 551–593] in Spanish, with line drawings of each species</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/3/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium 12(1,3): 1–93]</ref>

==Description== 
''Quercus laeta'' is a tree up to 10 meters tall with a trunk up to 40 cm in diameter. Leaves are dark green, thick and leathery, up to 40 cm long with a few shallow teeth along the edges.<ref name=evangelina/>

'''''Quercus laurina''''' is a Mexican species of [[tree]]s in the [[Fagaceae]]. It is native primarily to Mexico (from [[Tamaulipas]] to [[Chiapas]]) and has also been found in [[Guatemala]] and [[El Salvador]].<ref name=evangelina>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/87374#page/565/mode/1up Romero Rangel, S., E. C. Rojas Zenteno & M. L. Aguilar Enríquez. 2002. El género ''Quercus'' (Fagaceae) en el estado de México. Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden 89(4): 551–593] in Spanish, with line drawings of each species</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/3/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium 12(1,3): 1–93]</ref><ref>[http://www.tropicos.org/Name/13100370?tab=specimens Tropicos, ''Quercus laurina'' Bonpl.]</ref><ref>Linares, J. L. 2003. Listado comentado de los árboles nativos y cultivados en la república de El Salvador. Ceiba 44(2): 105–268</ref>

''Quercus laurina'' is a tree up to 30 meters tall with a trunk as much as 50 cm or more in diameter. Leaves are thick and leathery, up to 155 mm long, elliptical sometimes with a few large teeth near the tip.<ref name=evangelina/>

''Quercus laurina'' forms [[hybrid (biology)|hybrids]] with ''[[Quercus affinis]]''.<ref name=Gonzalez2005>{{cite journal|vauthors=González-Rodríguez A, Arias DM, Oyama K |title=Genetic variation and differentiation of populations within the ''Quercus affinis'' – ''Quercus laurina'' (Fagaceae) complex analyzed with RAPD markers |journal=Canadian Journal of Botany |year=2005 |volume=83 |pages=155–62 |doi=10.1139/B04-162 |url=http://www.oikos.unam.mx/CIEco/gencon/images/stories/pdf_8.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref>

'''''Quercus macdougallii''''' is a species of [[plant]] in the [[Fagaceae]] family. 

==Distribution==
The tree is [[Endemism|endemic]] to [[Oaxaca]] state in southwestern [[Mexico]].  

It grows in [[Sierra Madre de Oaxaca pine-oak forests]] habitat in the [[Sierra de Juarez]], a subrange of the [[Sierra Madre de Oaxaca]].

It is threatened by [[habitat loss]].

==See also==
* {{C|Flora of Oaxaca}}
* [[Sierra Madre del Sur pine-oak forests]]

==Sources==
* Nixon, K. ''et al.'' 1998.  [http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/32765/0 IUCN Red List: ''Quercus macdougallii'']
*[http://www.iucnredlist.org/ Current IUCN Red List of all Threatened Species]

|''Quercus neoplatyphylla'' <small>A.Camus</small>

'''''Quercus magnoliifolia''''', also known as '''encino amarillo''', '''encino avellano''', '''encino bermejo''', '''encino blanco''', '''encino napis''', '''encino prieto''', and '''roble''',<ref name=INE>{{cite web|title=''Quercus magnoliifolia'' Née|url=http://www2.ine.gob.mx/publicaciones/libros/603/magnoliifolia.pdf|publisher=National Mexican Institute of Ecology|accessdate=16 April 2013}}</ref> is a Mexican [[species]] of [[oak]]. It is widespread along the [[Pacific Coast of Mexico|Pacific Coast]] of Mexico from [[Sinaloa]] to [[Chiapas]], and also found inland as far as [[Zacatecas]] and [[Puebla]].<ref name=INE /><ref>[http://www.tropicos.org/Name/50072426?tab=specimens Tropicos, specimen listing for ''Quercus magnoliifolia'' Née ]</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/87374#page/575/mode/1up Romero Rangel, S., E. C. Rojas Zenteno & M. L. Aguilar Enríquez. 2002. El género ''Quercus'' (Fagaceae) en el estado de México. Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden  89(4): 561–564] in Spanish; line drawing of ''Q. magnoliifolia'' on page 563</ref><ref>McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium 12(1,3): 1–93</ref>

It was classified and described in 1801 by the [[French people|French]]-[[Spanish people|Spanish]] botanist [[Luis Née]].<ref name="name index">{{cite web|title=Fagaceae ''Quercus magnoliifolia'' Née|url=http://www.ipni.org/ipni/idPlantNameSearch.do;jsessionid=9810889A22A5F9DA9FF1ED4B244B0F5B?id=325826-2&back_page=%2Fipni%2FeditSimplePlantNameSearch.do%3Bjsessionid%3D7FEB0FE5F934BA573951B8AF03F7BB06%3Ffind_wholeName%3DQuercus%2Bmagnoliifolia%26output_format%3Dnormal&show_history=true|publisher=The International Plants Name Index|accessdate=16 April 2013}}</ref><ref name=tabby>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/8009570#page/269/mode/1up Née, Luis 1801.  Anales de Ciencias Naturales 3: 268-269] short diagnosis in Latin, description and commentary in Spanish</ref>

''Quercus magnoliifolia'' is a deciduous tree up to 20 meters tall with a trunk as much as 60 cm in diameter. Leaves are thick and leathery, up to 22 cm long, widely egg-shaped, with wavy edges or sometimes shallow teeth, green on the top but covered with yellowish hairs on the underside.<ref name=tabby/>

==References==
{{reflist}}

==External links==

*[http://www.tropicos.org/Image/100136568 photo of herbarium specimen at Missouri Botanical Garden collected in Nayarit in 1849]

[[Category:Plants described in 1801]]

'''''Quercus martinezii''''' is a Mexican species of [[tree ]] in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It has been found in [[Jalisco]], [[Michoacán]], [[Oaxaca]], and [[Chiapas]].<ref>Breedlove, D.E. 1986. Flora de Chiapas. Listados Florísticos de México 4: i–v, 1–246</ref><ref>García-Mendoza, A. J. & J. A. Meave. 2011. Diversidad Florística de Oaxaca: de Musgos a Angispermas 1–351. Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Ciudad Universitaria</ref><ref name=tmmy>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/61/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium 12: 57-59] in English with line drawing on page 58</ref><ref>Nixon, K. ''et al.'' 1998.  [http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/30734/all ''Quercus martinezii''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/30734/all |date=June 27, 2014 }}.   [http://www.iucnredlist.org 2006 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org |date=June 27, 2014 }}  Downloaded on 23 August 2007.</ref>

Quercus martinezii is a tall forest tree up to 25 meters tall with a trunk 50 cm or more in diameter. Leaves are thick and stiff, gray-green on the upper surface, lighter on the underside, lance-shaped or egg-shaped with irregular teeth.<ref name=tmmy/>

'''''Quercus mexicana''''' is a Mexican species of [[tree]]s in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It is widespread from Chiapas to Tamaulipas.<ref name=evangelina>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/87374#page/565/mode/1up Romero Rangel, S., E. C. Rojas Zenteno & M. L. Aguilar Enríquez. 2002. El género ''Quercus'' (Fagaceae) en el estado de México. Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden 89(4): 551–593] in Spanish, with line drawings of each species</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/3/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium 12(1,3): 1–93]</ref>

''Quercus mexicana'' is a deciduous  tree up to 15 meters tall with gray bark. Leaves are thick and leathery, up to 120 mm long, oblong or lance-shaped with no teeth or lobes.<ref name=evangelina/><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/279155#page/78/mode/1up Bonpland, Aimé Jacques Alexandre 1809.  Plantae Aequinoctiales 2: 35-36] diagnosis in Latin, description and commentary in French</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/279155#page/80/mode/1up Bonpland, Aimé Jacques Alexandre 1809. '''''Quercus microphylla''''' is a Mexican species of [[oak]] in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It is widespread from [[Oaxaca]] as far north as [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], [[Coahuila]], and [[Tamaulipas]].<ref name=tammy/><ref>[http://www.tropicos.org/Name/50004714?tab=specimens Tropicos, ''Quercus microphylla'' Née ]</ref>

==Description== 
''Quercus microphylla'' is a shrub rarely more than 60 cm tall, forming dense mats several meters across. Leaves are tiny compared to most other species in the genus, usually less than 35 mm long.<ref name=tammy>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/63/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium  12:59-60] in English, with line drawing on page 59</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/8009566#page/265/mode/1up Née, Luis. 1801.  Anales de Ciencias Naturales 3: 264-265] short [[Diagnosis (taxonomy)|diagnosis]] in Latin, description and commentary in Spanish</ref>

184.text:
{{italic title}}
{{Taxobox
| name = Arizona blue oak
| image = 
| image_caption = 
| regnum = [[Plant]]ae
| unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
| unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
| unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
| ordo = [[Fagales]]
| familia = [[Fagaceae]]
| genus = ''[[Quercus]]''
| sectio = ''[[List of Quercus species#Section Quercus|Quercus]]''
| species = '''''Q. oblongifolia''''' 
| binomial = ''Quercus oblongifolia''
| binomial_authority = [[John Torrey|Torr.]] 1853 not R.Br.ter 1871
|range_map =  Quercus oblongifolia range map 1.png
|range_map_caption = Natural range of ''Quercus oblongifolia''
}}

'''Quercus oblongifolia''', commonly known as the '''Arizona blue oak''', '''Blue live oak''' ,'''Sonoran blue oak''' , is an [[evergreen]] small tree or large shrub in the [[List of Quercus species#Section Quercus|white oak group]].

==Distribution==
''Quercus oblongifolia'' grows in high [[grassland]]s, [[canyon]]s and [[mesa]]s in [[Texas]], [[Arizona]] and [[New Mexico]] and northwestern Mexico ([[Baja California Sur]], [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], [[Coahuila]], [[Sinaloa]] and [[Sonora]] in [[Mexico]].<ref name=FNA>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501068 Flora of North America, ''Quercus oblongifolia'']</ref><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20oblongifolia.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref><ref>[http://swbiodiversity.org/seinet/taxa/index.php?taxon=3243 SEINet, Southwestern Biodiversity, Arizona chapter]</ref>

==Description==
The Arizona blue oak is a small evergreen tree growing 5-8 meters (16-27 feet) tall with a rounded crown. At higher elevations it is typically a large shrub. The trunk is up to 50 cm (20 inches) in diameter and  the bark is light gray and densely furrowed. The twigs are yellowish brown and hairless with reddish brown buds. The leaves are small, alternate and oblong, with entire margins, leathery, bluish-green above and mid green below. The flowers appear in spring at the same time as the old leaves are being shed and new leaf growth starts. The male flowers form yellowish-green catkins and the female flowers are solitary or paired and grow in the leaf axils. The light brown acorns are ovoid or oblong, about 2 cm (0.8 inch) long and lodged in scaly, bowl-shaped cups about one third the length of the nut.<ref name=FNA/><ref>[http://www.dendro.cnre.vt.edu/dendrology/syllabus2/factsheet.cfm?ID=627 Virginia Tech: Mexican blue oak] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110509061003/http://www.dendro.cnre.vt.edu/dendrology/syllabus2/factsheet.cfm?ID=627 |date=May 9, 2011 }}</ref>

==Habitat==
This oak is common at elevations of 1200 to 1800 meters (4000-6000 feet). It is often found on thin sandy soils in semi-arid regions and is the dominant species in lower open oak woodland where it grows in association with Arizona white oak (''[[Quercus arizonica]]'') and Emory oak (''[[Quercus emoryi]]'').<ref name=Fire>[http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/tree/queobl/all.html United States Department of Agriculture, National Forest Service, Fire Ecology]</ref> It is an important constituent of [[Pinyon-juniper woodland|pinyon-juniper]] communities.<ref>Pieper, Rex D.; Wood, M. Karl; Buchanan, Bruce B. 1988. Pinyon-juniper woodlands of New Mexico: a biological and economic appraisal. Special Report 73. Las Cruces, NM: New Mexico State University, College of Agriculture and Home Economics: 1-11.[5258]</ref> where it grows in association with species of [[Pinus|pine]] and [[Juniperus|juniper]], Arizona rosewood (''[[Vauquelinia californica]]''), shrubby buckwheat (''[[Eriogonum wrightii]]''), catclaw mimosa (''[[Mimosa aculeaticarpa]]''), bullgrass (''[[Muhlenbergia emersleyi]]''), plains lovegrass (''[[Eragrostis intermedia]]''), fendlerbush (''[[Fendlera|Fendlera rupicola]]'') and wolftail (''[[Lycurus phleoides]]'').<ref name=Fire/>

{{Commons category|Quercus obtusata}}
'''''Quercus obtusata''''' is a species of [[plant]] in the [[Fagaceae]] family. It is [[Endemism|endemic]] to [[Mexico]], with a distribution ranging from [[San Luis Potosí]] and [[Nayarit]] south to [[Oaxaca]].<ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/3/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium 12(1,3): 1–93]</ref><ref name=evangelina>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/87374#page/565/mode/1up Romero Rangel, S., E. C. Rojas Zenteno & M. L. Aguilar Enríquez. 2002. El género ''Quercus'' (Fagaceae) en el estado de México. Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden 89(4): 551–593] in Spanish, with line drawings of each species</ref>

''Quercus obtusata'' is a tree up to 20 meters tall with a trunk sometimes more than 60 cm in diameter. Leaves are thick and leathery, up to 22 cm long, widely egg-shaped with 3-9 pairs of shallow rounded lobes or undulations.<ref name=evangelina/><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/279134#page/57/mode/1up Bonpland, Aimé Jacques Alexandre. 1809. Plantae Aequinoctiales 2: 26-27] diagnosis in Latin, description and commentary in French</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/279134#page/58/mode/1up Bonpland, Aimé Jacques Alexandre. 1809. Plantae Aequinoctiales 2: plate 76] drawing of ''Quercus obtusata''</ref>

'''''Quercus oocarpa''''' is a Mesoamerican species of [[oak]] in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It is native to Central America and eastern Mexico, with an isolated population in canyons of [[Jalisco]] in western Mexico.<ref name=tammy/><ref>Muller, C. H. 1942. The Central American species of ''Quercus''. United States Department of Agriculture. Bureau of Plant Industry. Miscellaneous Publication 477: 1–216</ref>

==Description== 
''Quercus oocarpa'' is a large forest tree frequently more than 25 meters tall, evergreen or deciduous, with a trunk as much as 100 cm in diameter. Leaves are sometimes as much as 45 cm long, broadly egg-shaped with numerous small pointed teeth along the edges.<ref name=tammy>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/67/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium  12:63-64] in English, with line drawing on page 64</ref>

'''''Quercus peduncularis''''' is a Mesoamerican species of [[plant]] in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It is native to Mexico and Central America, ranging from [[Jalisco]] to [[Honduras]].<ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/3/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium 12(1,3): 1–93]</ref><ref name=evangelina>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/87374#page/565/mode/1up Romero Rangel, S., E. C. Rojas Zenteno & M. L. Aguilar Enríquez. 2002. El género ''Quercus'' (Fagaceae) en el estado de México. Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden 89(4): 551–593] in Spanish, with line drawings of each species</ref><ref>Muller, C. H. 1942. The Central American species of ''Quercus''. United States Department of Agriculture. Bureau of Plant Industry. Miscellaneous Publication 477: 1–216</ref><ref>Berendsohn, W.G., A. K. Gruber & J. A. Monterrosa Salomón. 2009. Nova silva cuscatlanica. Árboles nativos e introducidos de El Salvador. Parte 1: Angiospermae - Familias A a L. Englera 29(1): 1–438. </ref><ref>Breedlove, D.E. 1986. Flora de Chiapas. Listados Florísticos de México 4: i–v, 1–246</ref>

''Quercus peduncularis'' is a small tree up to 4 meters tall. Leaves are thick and leathery, up to 10 cm long, lance-shaped or egg-shaped with 9-14 pairs of pointed teeth on the edges.<ref name=evangelina/>

'''''Quercus peninsularis''''', common name '''peninsular oak''', is a species of [[oak]] [[Endemism|endemic]] to [[Baja California]], [[Mexico]].<ref name="iucn">{{cite web |work=IUCN Red List of Threatened Species |author1=Nixon, K. |displayauthors=etal |date=1998 |url=http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/30735/all |title=''Quercus peninsularis'' |accessdate=2007-08-23}}</ref> It is a [[shrub]] or small [[tree]] to 10 m, occurring in mountain [[valley]]s and [[canyon]]s up to 3000 m. It is classified as a [[List of Quercus species#Section Lobatae|red oak (section ''Lobatae'')]]. [[Leaf|Leaves]] are 5–8 cm, flat, leathery and hairy, with pointed tips and 2-5 pairs of teeth. [[Flower]]s occur in 3 cm catkins. [[Fruit]]s are 1.5 cm [[acorn]]s, [[peduncle (botany)|stemless]], [[oval|ovoid]], with hairy [[Calybium and cupule|cupule]]s, maturing in a year. Mature [[bark]] is reddish; young [[twig]]s are thin and hairy.<ref name="world">{{cite web |author=Trel. 1924 |title=Oaks of the World. |url=http://oaks.of.the.world.free.fr/quercus_peninsularis.htm |accessdate=2013-11-28}}</ref>

'''''Quercus planipocula''''' is a Mexican species of [[trees]] in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It is native to western  [[Mexico]] in [[Sinaloa]], [[Nayarit]], and [[Guerrero]].<ref name=x>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/70/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium12:66-68] in English with line drawing on page 67</ref><ref>Nixon, K. ''et al.'' 1998.  [http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/30736/all ''Quercus planipocula''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/30736/all |date=June 27, 2014 }}.   [http://www.iucnredlist.org 2006 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org |date=June 27, 2014 }}  Downloaded on 23 August 2007.</ref>

''Quercus planipocula'' is a large forest tree up to 20 meters tall with a trunk often more than 60 cm in diameter. Leaves are as much as 27 cm long.<ref name=x/><ref>Trelease, William 1924.  Memoirs of the National Academy of Sciences 20: 136</ref>

'''''Quercus polymorpha''''', the '''Mexican white oak''', '''Monterrey oak''' or '''netleaf white oak''', is a North American species of [[oak]]. It is widespread in Mexico, Guatemala, and Honduras, and known from a single population in the United States (about 30 km north of the [[Río Grande]] in [[Val Verde County, Texas]]) but widely planted as an ornamental.<ref name=w/><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20polymorpha.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref><ref>Muller, C. H. 1942. The Central American species of ''Quercus''. United States Department of Agriculture. Bureau of Plant Industry. Miscellaneous Publication 477: 1–216</ref><ref>Breedlove, D.E. 1986. Flora de Chiapas. Listados Florísticos de México 4: i–v, 1–246. </ref><ref>[http://texastreeid.tamu.edu/content/TreeDetails/?id=105&t=O Texas A&M Forest Service, Trees of Texas]</ref>

''Quercus polymorpha'' is a subevergreen tree up to 20 meters (67 feet) tall. Bark is gray or brown. Leaves are elliptical or egg-shaped, up to 15 cm (6 inches) long, unlobed or with a few shallow rounded lobes.<ref name=w>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501074 Flora of North America, ''Quercus polymorpha'' Schlechtendal & Chamisso, 1830.  Net-leaf white oak ]</ref>

'''''Quercus potosina''''' is a Mesoamerican species of [[oak]] in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It is native to northern Mexico, from [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], [[Durango]], and [[Jalisco]] east as far as [[San Luis Potosí]].<ref name=tammy/>

==Description==
''Quercus potosina'' is a shrub or small tree up to 7 meters tall, drought-deciduous. Leaves round or egg-shaped, up to 9 cm long, numerous small pointed teeth along the edges.<ref name=tammy>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/67/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium  12:63-64] in English, with line drawing on page 64</ref>

'''''Quercus praeco''''' is a Mexican species of [[trees]] in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It is native to the States of [[Jalisco]] and [[Nayarit]] in western  [[Mexico]] and 	[[Nuevo León]] in northeastern Mexico.<ref name=tammy>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/74/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contr. Univ. Michigan Herb. 12:70-71] in English with line drawing on page 70</ref><ref>Nixon, K. ''et al.'' 1998.  [http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/34671/all ''Quercus praeco''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/34671/all |date=June 27, 2014 }}.   [http://www.iucnredlist.org 2006 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org |date=June 27, 2014 }}  Downloaded on 23 August 2007.</ref><ref>[http://www.tropicos.org/Name/50004731?tab=specimens Tropicos, ''Quercus praeco'' Trel.]</ref>

''Quercus praeco'' is a deciduous tree up to 7 meters tall with a trunk as much as 50 cm in diameter. Leaves are up to 14 cm long, broadly egg-shaped, with shallow lobes or teeth along the edges. Upper side of the leaves is green, the underside yellowish because of many hairs.<ref name=tammy/>

'''''Quercus resinosa''''' is a Mexican species of [[oak]] in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It is to central and western Mexico, from [[Nayarit]] south to [[Michoacán]] and east as far as [[San Luis Potosí]].<ref name=tammy/>

==Description==
''Quercus resinosa'' is a deciduous tree up to 15 meters tall with a trunk as much as 70 cm in diameter. Leaves are huge, as much as 50 cm long, thick and stiff, broadly egg-shaped with the widest part toward the tip.<ref name=tammy>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/77/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium  12:73-75] in English, with line drawing on page 74</ref>

|range_map_caption = Natural range of ''Quercus rugosa''
|synonyms_ref=<ref>[http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-174935 The Plant List, ''Quercus rugosa'' Née ]</ref>
|synonyms={{collapsible list|bullets = true
|''Quercus ariifolia'' <small>Trel.</small>

|''Quercus diversicolor'' <small>Trel.</small>

|''Quercus purpusii'' <small>Trel.</small>
|''Quercus reticulata'' <small>Bonpl.</small>
|''Quercus rhodophlebia'' <small>Trel.</small>

|''Quercus uhdeana'' <small>Trel.</small>
|''Quercus vellifera'' <small>Trel.</small>
|}}}}
'''''Quercus rugosa''''', commonly known as the '''netleaf oak''', is a [[broad-leaved tree]] in the [[beech]] and [[oak]] family [[Fagaceae]]. It is [[native plant|native]] to southern [[North America]].

==Name==
''Quercus rugosa'' is [[Latin]] for "wrinkled oak". In [[Spanish language|Spanish]] it has many common names like "encino negro" (black oak) or "encino quiebra hacha" (axe-breaking oak).

==Description==
''Quercus rugosa'' is an [[evergreen]] shrub or tree.<ref name="CONABIO">[http://www.conabio.gob.mx/conocimiento/info_especies/arboles/doctos/31-fagac10m.pdf CONABIO'', Quercus rugosa'']</ref> Bark is brown and scaly.  Leaves are thick and leathery, rarely flat, usually cupped, up to 15 cm (6 inches) long, dark green on the top but covered with a thick of reddish-brown hairs on the underside.<ref name="efloras">[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501080 Flora of North America'', Quercus rugosa'' Née, 1801.  Netleaf oak ]</ref><ref name="BDL">[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/8009577#page/276/mode/1up Née, Luis. 1801.  Anales de Ciencias Naturales 3(9): 275] short diagnosis in Latin, description and commentary in Spanish</ref> Young leaves are also very hairy and usually red or yellow.
[[File:Quercus rugosa (detail).jpg|thumb|Leaves and acorns]]

==Distribution==
It is widespread in [[Mexico]], [[Guatemala]] and the southwestern [[United States]] ([[Arizona]], [[New Mexico]], western [[Texas]]).<ref name="PLANT" /><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20rugosa.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref><ref>[http://swbiodiversity.org/seinet/taxa/index.php?taxon=3264&taxauthid=1 SEINet, Southwestern Biodiversity, arizona chapter]</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/3/mode/1up McVaugh, Rogers. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium 12(1,3): 1–93. ]</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/87374#page/565/mode/1up Romero Rangel, S., E. C. Rojas Zenteno & M. L. Aguilar Enríquez. 2002. El género ''Quercus'' (Fagaceae) en el estado de México. Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden  89(4): 551–593]</ref> It grows extensively in the [[Mexican Plateau|temperate highlands of central Mexico]], particularly on hillsides and in [[gully|narrow gorges]]. It is associated and usually coexists with other oaks, [[alder]]s, [[pine]]s and [[Arbutus xalapensis|Texas madrones]].

==See also==

* [[Madrean pine-oak woodlands]]
* [[Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt pine-oak forests]]

}}

'''''Quercus rysophylla''''', the '''loquat leaf oak''', is a Mexican species of [[oak]] in the [[Quercus species#Section Lobatae|red oak]] section (''Quercus'' section ''Lobatae''). It is native to the [[Sierra Madre Oriental]] in the States of [[Tamaulipas]], [[Nuevo León]], [[San Luis Potosí]], [[Veracruz]], and [[Hidalgo (state)|Hidalgo]] in northeastern Mexico.  <ref>[http://www.tropicos.org/Name/50007978?tab=specimens Tropicos, specimen listing for ''Quercus rysophylla'' Weath.]</ref><ref>Nixon, K. ''et al.'' 1998.  [http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/30738/all ''Quercus rysophylla''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/30738/all |date=June 27, 2014 }}.   [http://www.iucnredlist.org 2006 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org |date=June 27, 2014 }}  Downloaded on 23 August 2007.</ref>

The name is often incorrectly spelled ''Quercus rhysophylla''. 

''Quercus rysophylla'' is a large tree. Leaves are lanceolate, up to 21 cm long. <ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/8053146#page/435/mode/1up Weatherby, Charles Alfred 1924.  Proceedings of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences 45(17): 423–424] description in Latin, commentary in English</ref>

|''Quercus tahuasalana'' <small>Trel.</small>
|}}}}
'''''Quercus salicifolia''''' is a Mesoamerican species of [[oak]] in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It is native to Central America and to central and southern Mexico, from [[Jalisco]] to [[Panamá]].<ref name=tammy/><ref>Berendsohn, W.G., A. K. Gruber & J. A. Monterrosa Salomón. 2009. Nova silva cuscatlanica. Árboles nativos e introducidos de El Salvador. Parte 1: Angiospermae - Familias A a L. Englera 29(1): 1–438</ref><ref>Morales Quirós, J. F. 2015. Santalaceae. En: Manual de Plantas de Costa Rica. Vol. VIII. B.E. Hammel, M.H. Grayum, C. Herrera & N. Zamora (eds.). Monographs in Systematic Botany from the Missouri Botanical Garden 131: 13–36</ref><ref>Correa A., M.D., C. Galdames & M. Stapf. 2004. Catálogo de las Plantas Vasculares de Panamá 1–599. Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute, Panamá</ref>

==Description==
''Quercus salicifolia'' is a tree up to 25 meters tall, with a trunk up to 100 cm in diameter. Leaves narrowly lance-shaped, up to 20 cm long, with no teeth or lobes.<ref name=tammy>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/81/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium  12:77-80] in English, with line drawing on page 78</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/8009567#page/266/mode/1up Née, Luis 1801.  Anales de Ciencias Naturales 3: 265-267] short diagnosis in Latin, description and commentary in Spanish</ref>

The epithet ''"salicifolia"'' means "willow-leaved" alluding to the resemblance between the leaves of ''Q salicifolia'' and those of several species of ''[[Salix]].''

'''''Quercus sapotifolia''''' is a Mexican species of [[oak]] in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It is native to Central America and also to southern and western Mexico, as far north as [[Michoacán]].<ref>Muller, C. H. 1942. The Central American species of ''Quercus''. United States Department of Agriculture. Bureau of Plant Industry. Miscellaneous Publication 477: 1–216</ref><ref>Breedlove, D.E. 1986. Flora de Chiapas. Listados Florísticos de México 4: i–v, 1–246</ref>

'''''Quercus scytophylla ''''' is a Mexican species of [[tree]]s in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It is native to western and central Mexico from [[Sonora]] and [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]] to [[Chiapas]].<ref name=evangelina>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/87374#page/565/mode/1up Romero Rangel, S., E. Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden 89(4): 551–593] in Spanish, with line drawings of each species</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/3/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium 12(1,3): 1–93]</ref><ref>[http://swbiodiversity.org/seinet/taxa/index.php?taxon=28190&taxauthid=1 SEINet, Southwestern Biodiversity, Arizona chapter] distribution map and photos of herbarium specimens</ref>

''Quercus scytophylla '' is a deciduous  tree up to 20 meters tall with a trunk as much as 50 cm in diameter. Leaves are thick and leathery, up to 20 cm long, with a few tapering, pointed teeth along the edges.<ref name=evangelina/>

'''''Quercus sebifera''''' is a Mexican species of [[plant]] in the [[Fagaceae]] family. It grows in eastern and southern Mexico, in the States of [[Chiapas]], [[Oaxaca]], [[Puebla]], [[Hidalgo (state)|Hidalgo]], [[Querétaro]], [[Tamaulipas]], and [[Nuevo León]].<ref>[http://www.tropicos.org/Name/13100374?tab=specimens Tropicos, ''Quercus sebifera'' Trel.]</ref><ref>Muller, C. H. 1942. The Central American species of ''Quercus''. United States Department of Agriculture. Bureau of Plant Industry. Miscellaneous Publication 477: 1–216</ref><ref>García-Mendoza, A. J. & J. A. Meave. 2011. Diversidad Florística de Oaxaca: de Musgos a Angispermas 1–351. Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Ciudad Universitaria</ref><ref>Muller, C. H. 1942. Notes on the American flora, chiefly Mexican. American Midland Naturalist 27(2): 470–490, as ''Quercus trinidadensis''. </ref><ref>Nixon, K. ''et al.'' 1998.  [http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/32767/all ''Quercus sebifera''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/32767/all |date=June 27, 2014 }}.   [http://www.iucnredlist.org 2006 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org |date=June 27, 2014 }}  Downloaded on 23 August 2007.</ref>

|binomial_authority=[[Luis Née|Née]] 1801
|synonyms_ref=<ref>[http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-174935 The Plant List, ''Quercus rugosa'' Née ]</ref>
|synonyms={{collapsible list|bullets = true
|''Quercus crassifolia'' <small>Benth. 1840 not Bonpl. 1809</small>
|''[[Quercus sororia]]'' <small>Liebm.</small>
|}}}}
'''''Quercus splendens'''''  is a species of [[oak tree]] which is native to central [[Mexico]] ([[México State]], [[Guerrero]], [[Jalisco]], [[Nayarit]], [[Sinaloa]], [[Michoacán]], [[Oaxaca]]).<ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/3/mode/1up McVaugh, Rogers. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium 12(1,3): 1–93. ]</ref><ref name=lagertha>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/87374#page/565/mode/1up Romero Rangel, S., E. C. Rojas Zenteno & M. L. Aguilar Enríquez. 2002. El género ''Quercus'' (Fagaceae) en el estado de México. Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden  89(4): 551–593]</ref>

''Quercus splendens'' is a deciduous tree up to 15 meters tall, with gray bark and branching hairs the look like stars under the microscope. Leaves are thick and leathery, up to 18 cm long, with a few shallow lobes on the edges.<ref name=lagertha/><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/8009577#page/276/mode/1up Née, Luis. 1801. Anales de Ciencias Naturales 3(9): 275-276] short diagnosis in Latin, description and commentary in Spanish</ref>

'''''Quercus subspathulata''''' is a Mexican species of [[plant]] in the [[Fagaceae]] family. It is native to western [[Mexico]], found in the States of [[Durango]], [[Jalisco]], [[Nayarit]], and [[Sinaloa]].<ref name=tammy>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/89/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium 12:85-86] in English, line drawing on page 86</ref><ref>Nixon, K. ''et al.'' 1998.  [http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/32872/all ''Quercus subspathulata''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/32872/all |date=June 27, 2014 }}.   [http://www.iucnredlist.org 2006 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org |date=June 27, 2014 }}  Downloaded on 23 August 2007.</ref>

''Quercus subspathulata'' is a small tree up to 10 meters tall with a trunk as much as 40 cm in diameter. Leaves can be up to 22 cm long, green on the top but whitish on the underside.<ref name=tammy/><ref>Trelease, William. 1924.  Memoirs of the National Academy of Sciences 20: 56</ref>

|genus = ''[[Quercus]]''

|species = '''''Q. tarahumara'''''
|binomial = ''Quercus tarahumara''
|binomial_authority =[[Richard William Spellenberg|Spellenb.]], [[John Dudley Bacon|J.D.Bacon]] & [[Dennis E. Breedlove|Breedlove]] 1995

|}}
'''''Quercus tarahumara''''' (also called '''Tarahumara oak''') is a species of [[trees]] in the [[Fagaceae|beech]] family. It grows in the [[Sierra Madre Occidental]] in the Mexican States of [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], [[Sonora]], [[Durango]], and [[Sinaloa]]. Some of the populations lie within the territory occupied by the [[Tarahumara people|Tarahumara People]], after whom the species is named.<ref>[http://www.jstor.org/stable/41425044?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents Spellenberg, Richard William, Bacon, John Dudley, & Breedlove, Dennis E. 1995.  Madroño 42: 28]</ref><ref>[http://swbiodiversity.org/seinet/taxa/index.php?taxon=28194&taxauthid=1 SEINet, Southwestern Biodiversity, Arizona chapter] photos, distribution map</ref>

''Quercus tarahumara'' is a tree up to 10 meters (33 feet) tall. Leaves are rather large for the genus, up to 30 cm (1 foot) across, with the stiffness of cardboard, green on top but tan on the underside. It is sometimes called the '''"handbasin oak"''' because its size and shape suggest a bathroom sink.<ref>[https://www.desertmuseum.org/programs/alamos_trees_quetar.php Arizona-Sonoran Desert Museum, Tucson, Research and Conservation in Southern Sonora, Mexico,  ''Quercus tarahumara'' (handbasin oak, güeja) ]</ref>

|binomial_authority=[[Liebm.]] 1854
|synonyms_ref=<ref>[http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-175579 The Plant List, ''Quercus tuberculata'' Liebm. ]</ref>

|''Quercus standleyi'' <small>Trel.</small>
|''Quercus tuberculata'' f. ''latifolia'' <small>Martínez</small>
|}}}}
'''''Quercus tuberculata'''''  is a species of [[oak tree]] which is native to mountains of northeastern and northwestern [[Mexico]] ([[Baja California Sur]], [[Sonora]], [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], [[Sinaloa]], [[Michoacán]], [[Durango]], and [[Nuevo León]]).<ref name=tammy>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/91/mode/1up McVaugh, Rogers. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium 12: 86-88] in English, line drawing on page 87</ref><ref>[http://www.tropicos.org/Name/50007643?tab=specimens Tropicos, ''Quercus tuberculata'' Liebm.]</ref>

''Quercus tuberculata'' is a deciduous tree up to 12 meters tall, with a trunk up to 30 cm in diameter. Leaves are egg-shaped, thick and leathery, up to 15 cm long, with wavy edges but no teeth or lobes.<ref name=tammy/><ref>Liebmann, Frederik Michael. 1854.  Oversigt over det kongelige danske videnskabernes selskabs forhandlinger og dets medlemmers arbeider. 1854: 181</ref>

'''''Quercus urbanii''''' is a Mexican species of [[tree]]s in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It is native to western and central Mexico from [[Sinaloa]], [[Durango]], and [[Zacatecas]] to [[Oaxaca]].<ref name=evangelina>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/87374#page/565/mode/1up Romero Rangel, S., E. C. Rojas Zenteno & M. L. Aguilar Enríquez. 2002. El género ''Quercus'' (Fagaceae) en el estado de México. Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden 89(4): 551–593] in Spanish, with line drawings of each species</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/3/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium 12(1,3): 1–93]</ref>

''Quercus urbanii'' is a deciduous  tree up to 10 meters tall with a trunk as much as 30 cm in diameter. Leaves are thick and leathery, up to 30 cm long, broadly egg-shaped (almost round), with pointed teeth along the edges.<ref name=evangelina/><ref>Martínez Martínez, M. 1951. Los encinos de México y Centroamérica. Anales del instituto de Biología de la Universidad Nacional de México 22(2): 351–368</ref>

{{taxobox
|status = VU
|status_system = IUCN2.3

|binomial_authority = [[Rogers McVaugh|McVaugh]] 1972
|}}
'''''Quercus uxoris''''' is an uncommon Mexican species of [[Quercus|oak tree]] in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. 

The tree is [[Endemism|endemic]] to [[Mexico]].  It has been found in the States of [[Jalisco]], [[Colima]], [[Guerrero]], [[Michoacán]], and [[Oaxaca]] in western Mexico.<ref name=naomi>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/46657#page/94/mode/1up McVaugh, R. 1974. Flora Novo-Galiciana: Fagaceae. Contributions from the University of Michigan Herbarium 12:90-91] in English, with line drawings on page 90</ref><ref>García-Mendoza, A. J. & J. A. Meave. 2011. Diversidad Florística de Oaxaca: de Musgos a Angispermas  1–351. Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Ciudad Universitaria</ref><ref>Nixon, K. ''et al.'' 1998.  [http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/30739/all ''Quercus uxoris''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/30739/all |date=June 27, 2014 }}.   [http://www.iucnredlist.org 2006 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org |date=June 27, 2014 }}  Downloaded on 23 August 2007.</ref>

==Description==
''Quercus uxoris'' is a large deciduous tree up to 25 meters tall with a trunk often more than 100 cm in diameter. 

Leaves can be as much as 26 cm long, thick and leathery, broadly lance-shaped with numerous tapering teeth along the edges.<ref name=naomi/>

'''''Quercus vaseyana''''' (also called '''Vasey oak''') is a species of tree in the [[Fagaceae|beech]] family. It grows in northern Mexico  ([[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], [[Coahuila]], and [[Nuevo León]]) and in the US state of [[Texas]].<ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20vaseyana.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref><ref name=s/>

''Quercus vaseyana'' is a shrub or small tree up to 10 meters (33 feet) tall. Bark is brown. Leaves narrow, up to 9 cm (3.6 inches) long, thick and leathery, with a few teeth or shallow lobes.<ref name=s>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501094 Flora of North America, ''Quercus vaseyana'' Buckley, 1883. Vasey oak ]</ref>

Par F.s André-Michaux. Paris, L. Haussmann,1812-13. François André Michaux (book author), Henri-Joseph Redouté (illustrator), Gabriel (engraver)</ref>

'''''Quercus virginiana''''', also known as the '''southern live oak''', is an [[evergreen]] [[oak]] [[tree]] native to the [[Southeastern United States|southeastern]] [[United States]]. Though many other species are loosely called [[live oak]], the southern live oak is particularly iconic of the [[Old South]]. Many very large and old specimens of live oak can be found today in the deep southern United States.<ref name = southern>{{cite encyclopedia | title = Quercus virginiana | encyclopedia = The Southern Living Garden Book | editor-last = Bender | editor-first = Steve |date=January 2004 | edition = 2nd | ISBN = 0-376-03910-8 | publisher = Oxmoor House | location = Birmingham, Alabama}}</ref>

==Taxonomy==
A large number of common names are used for this tree, including "Virginia live oak", "bay live oak", "scrub live oak", "plateau oak", "plateau live oak", "escarpment live oak", and (in [[Spanish language|Spanish]]) "''roble''". It is also often just called "live oak" within its native area, but the full name "southern live oak" helps to distinguish it from other [[live oak]]s, a general term for any [[evergreen]] species of oak.<ref name=tammy>
{{cite web|url=http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501097|title=Quercus virginiana in Flora of North America @ efloras.org|publisher=www.efloras.org|accessdate=2008-11-01}}</ref>

This profusion of common names partly reflects an ongoing controversy about the classification of various live oaks, in particular its near relatives among the [[Lepidobalanus#Section Quercus|white oaks]] (''Quercus'' [[subgenus]] ''Quercus'', section ''Quercus''). Some authors recognize as distinct species the forms others consider to be varieties of ''Quercus virginiana''. Notably, the following two taxa, treated as species in the ''Flora of North America'', are treated as varieties of southern live oak by the [[United States Forest Service]]: the [[Escarpment live oak]], ''[[Quercus fusiformis]]'' (''Q. virginiana'' var. ''fusiformis'') and
the [[Quercus geminata|sand live oak, ''Quercus geminata'' (''Q. virginiana'' var. ''geminata'')]].

Matters are further complicated by southern live oaks [[Hybrid (biology)|hybridizing]] with both the above two species, and also with [[dwarf live oak]] (''Q. minima''), [[swamp white oak]] (''Q. bicolor''), [[Durand oak]] (''Q. durandii''), [[overcup oak]] (''Q. lyrata''), [[bur oak]] (''Q. macrocarpa''), and [[post oak]] (''Q. stellata'').

==Range==
Live oak can be found in the wild growing and reproducing on the lower coastal plain of the Gulf of Mexico and south Atlantic United States. Its native range begins on the extreme southeastern coast of Virginia, south in a narrow band along the ocean to the middle of the South Carolina coast, where its range begins to expand farther inland.  The range of live oak continues to expand inland as it moves south, growing across southern  Georgia and covering all of Florida south to the northernmost Florida Keys.  Live oak grows along the Florida panhandle to Mobile Bay, then westward across the southernmost two tiers of counties in Mississippi.  Live oak grows across the southern third of Louisiana, except for some barrier islands and scattered parts of the most southern parishes.  Live oak’s range continues into Texas and narrows to hug the coast until just past Port Lavaca, Texas.<ref name="Trees_Florida"/> The species reaches its northwestern limit in the granite [[massif]]s and canyons in [[Southwestern Oklahoma]], a rare remnant from the last [[glaciation]].

Along the coastal plain of the Gulf of Mexico and south Atlantic United States, live oak is found in both single and mixed species forests, dotting the savannas, and as occasional clumps in the grasslands along the lower coastal plain. Live oak grows in soils ranging from heavy textures (clay loams), to sands with layers of organic materials or fine particles.  Live oak can be found dominating some maritime forests, especially where fire periodicity and duration are limited.  Live oak is found on higher topographic sites as well as hammocks in marshes and swamps. In general, southern live oak hugs the coastline and is rarely found more than 300 feet above sea level. Live oaks grow across a wide range of sites with many moisture regimes  –  ranging from dry to moist. Live oak will survive well on both dry sites and in wet areas, effectively handling short duration flooding if water is moving and drainage is good.  Good soil drainage is a key resource component for sustained live oak growth. Required precipitation range is 40-65 inches of water per year, preferably in spring and summer.  Soil is usually acidic, ranging between pH of 5.5 and 6.5. The furthest north known live oak is in [[Annapolis, Maryland]] on Tyler Ave.

==Description==
[[File:Shingle-oak-leaves-acorns.jpg|thumb|left|Leaves and acorns of a southern live oak]] <!-- it is not really a shingle oak, the file was misnamed. -Phr -->
[[File:Century Tree.jpg|thumb|left|The Century Tree at [[Texas A&M University]] in [[College Station, Texas]]]]
Although live oaks retain their leaves nearly year-round, they are not true evergreens. Live oaks drop their leaves immediately before new leaves emerge in the spring. Occasionally, [[Senescence|senescing]] leaves may turn yellow or contain brown spots in the winter, leading to the mistaken belief that the tree has [[oak wilt]], whose symptoms typically occur in the summer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://plantclinic.tamu.edu/factsheets/live-oak/ |title=Live oak dropping leaves in early spring |work=Texas A&M AgriLife Extension |publisher=Texas A&M University |accessdate=April 14, 2015}}</ref> A live oak's defoliation may occur sooner in marginal climates or in dry or cold winters.<ref name=Trees_North_FL>{{Citation
|last1=Kurz
|first1=Herman
|last2=Godfrey
|first2=Robert K.
|year=1962
|title=Trees of Northern Florida
|publisher=University Press of Florida
|publication-place=Gainesville, Florida, USA
|ISBN=978-0-8130-0666-6 
|pages=103–104
}}</ref>

The bark is dark, thick, and furrowed longitudinally.  The leaves are stiff and leathery, with the tops shiny dark green and the bottoms pale gray and very tightly [[tomentose]], simple and typically flattish with bony-opaque margins, with a length of .75 - 6 inches (2 – 15 cm) and a width of .4 - 2 inches (1 – 5 cm), borne alternately.  The male flowers are green hanging [[catkin]]s with lengths of 3 - 4 inches (7.5 –10 cm).  The acorns are small, .4 - 1 inch (1 - 2.5 cm), oblong in shape (ovoid or oblong-ellipsoid), shiny and tan-brown to nearly black, often black at the tips, and borne singly or in clusters.<ref name=Trees_Florida>{{Citation
|last=Nelson
|first=Gil
|year=1994
|title=The Trees of Florida: A Reference and Field Guide
|publisher=Pineapple Press
|publication-place=Sarasota, Florida, USA
|ISBN=1-56164-055-7
|page=84
}}</ref><ref name=Trees_North_FL/>
[[File:Boone-hall-avenue-of-oaks-sc1.jpg|thumb|The avenue of live oaks at [[Boone Hall]] in [[Mount Pleasant, South Carolina]], planted in 1743.]]
[[File:Oak at the Protestant Children's Home Sept 2012.jpg|thumb|A specimen at the former [[Protestant Children's Home]] in [[Mobile, Alabama]].  It has a trunk circumference  of {{convert|23|ft|m}}, height of {{convert|63|ft|m}} and limb spread of {{convert|141|ft|m}}.]]
Depending on the growing conditions, live oaks vary from a shrub-size to large and spreading tree-size: typical open-grown trees reach 20 meters (65.5 feet) in height, with a limb spread of nearly 27 meters (88.5 feet).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://edis.ifas.ufl.edu/st564 |title= Quercus virginiana: Southern Live Oak |work=University of Florida IFAS Extension |publisher=University of Florida|accessdate= August 8, 2013}}</ref> Their lower limbs often sweep down towards the ground before curving up again. They can grow at severe angles, and [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] used to bend saplings over so that they would grow at extreme angles, to serve as trail markers.

The branches frequently support other plant species such as rounded clumps of [[ball moss]], thick drapings of [[Spanish moss]], [[Pleopeltis polypodioides|resurrection fern]], and parasitic [[mistletoe]].

The southern live oak has a deep tap-root that anchors it when young and eventually develops into an extensive and widespread root system.  This, along with its low center of gravity and other factors, makes the southern live oak extremely resistant to strong sustained winds, such as those seen in hurricanes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://edis.ifas.ufl.edu/pdffiles/FR/FR17500.pdf |title= Selecting Tropical and Subtropical Tree Species For Wind Resistance |work=University of Florida IFAS Extension |publisher=University of Florida|accessdate= November 13, 2012}}</ref>

The southern live oak responds "with vigorous growth to plentiful moisture on well-drained soil."<ref name=Trees_North_FL/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://plants.usda.gov/java/charProfile?symbol=QUVI |title=Quercus virginiana Mill. live oak |work=Natural Resources Conservation Service |publisher=US Department of Agriculture|accessdate= August 8, 2013}}</ref> They tend to survive fire, because often a fire will not reach their [[crown (botany)|crowns]]. Even if a tree is burned, its crowns and roots usually survive the fire and sprout vigorously. Furthermore, live oak forests discourage entry of fire from adjacent communities because they provide dense cover that discourages the growth of a flammable understory.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} They can withstand occasional floods and hurricanes, and are resistant to salt spray and moderate soil salinity.  Although they grow best in well-drained sandy soils and loams, they will also grow in clay.<ref name=Phenology>[http://www.usanpn.org/Quercus_virginiana] "The USA National Phenology Network — Quercus virginiana", Retrieved 2011-07-06</ref>

==Uses==
[[File:Oak alley - view from front.jpg|thumb|left|The avenue of live oaks at [[Oak Alley Plantation]] in [[Vacherie, Louisiana]], planted in the early 18th century.]]

Live oak wood is hard, heavy, and difficult to work with, but very strong.  In the days of wooden ships, live oaks were the preferred source of the framework timbers of the ship, using the natural trunk and branch angles for their strength. The frame of {{USS|Constitution}} was constructed from southern live oak wood harvested from [[St. Simons Island, Georgia]], and the density of the wood grain allowed it to survive cannonade, thus earning it the nickname "Old Ironsides".  Even today, the [[U.S. Navy]] continues to own extensive live oak tracts.<ref>
{{cite web
|url=http://www.cnr.vt.edu/dendro/LandownerFactsheets/detail.cfm?Genus=Quercus&Species=virginiana
|title=Landowner Fact Sheets - live oak
|publisher=www.cnr.vt.edu
|accessdate=2008-11-01}}
</ref>

The primary uses for southern live oaks today are providing food and shelter for wildlife. Among the animals for which live oak acorns are an important food source are the [[bobwhite quail]], the [[threatened]] [[Florida scrub jay]], the [[wood duck]], [[yellow-bellied sapsucker]], [[wild turkey]], [[American black bear|black bear]], various species of [[squirrel]], and the [[white-tailed deer]]. The tree crown is very dense, making it valuable for shade, and the species provides nest sites for many mammal species. [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] extracted a cooking oil from the acorns, used all parts of live oak for medicinal purposes, leaves for making rugs, and bark for dyes.<ref name=Phenology/><ref>[http://digitalcollections.fiu.edu/tequesta/files/1946/46_1_03.pdf] "Some Reflections on the South Florida
of Long Ago", Retrieved 2011-07-06</ref> The roots of seedlings sometimes form starchy, edible tubers.  People in past centuries harvested and fried these tubers for human consumption much as one might use a potato.<ref name=tammy/>

==Cultivation==
Southern live oak is cultivated in warmer climates as a specimen tree or for shade in the southern United States (zone 8 and south) and in the warmer parts of the United States, Europe, and Australia. Cultivation is relatively simple, as Southern live oak seedlings grow fast with ample soil moisture. After a few years live oak needs only occasional supplemental water. Southern live oak is very long lived, and there are many specimens that are more than 400 years old in the deep southern [[United States]].

==Famous specimens==
[[File:Angel Oak Tree in SC.jpg|thumb|The Angel Oak on Johns Island, South Carolina. The man standing under the tree is {{convert|5|ft|11|in|m}} tall.]]
[[File:Hampton University - Emancipation Oak.jpg|thumb|The Emancipation Oak in Hampton, Virginia]]
*The [[Seven Sisters Oak]], estimated to be as old as 1,500 years, is the largest certified southern live oak tree.
* The [[Angel Oak]] on [[Johns Island, South Carolina]], near [[Charleston, South Carolina|Charleston]] is estimated to be in excess of 700 years old.  It has a trunk circumference of  {{convert|28|ft|m}}, height of {{convert|66|ft|6|in|m}} and limb spread of {{convert|187|ft|m}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.angeloaktree.com|title=History of the Angel Oak}}</ref> It is the largest tree east of the [[Mississippi River]].
*[[The Big Tree, Rockport|The Big Tree]] is an estimated 1,000-year-old southern live oak located in [[Rockport, Texas]], the largest live oak in Texas.
*The [[Boyington Oak]], an approximately 180-year-old southern live oak in [[Mobile, Alabama]], that is known for the folklore surrounding its origin.<ref name="silence">{{cite book |last=Sledge |first=John S. |year =1982 |title=Cities of Silence |publisher=University of Alabama Press |location=Tuscaloosa, Alabama |pages=15, 19 |isbn=0-8173-1140-8 }}</ref><ref name="long">{{cite journal |last1=Pruitt |first1=Paul M. |last2=Higgins |first2=Robert Bond |year =1963 |title=Crime and Punishment in Antebellum Mobile: The Long Story of Charles R. S. Boyington |journal=Gulf Coast Historical Review |volume=11 |issue=Spring 1996 |pages=6–40 |accessdate=November 9, 2012}}</ref>
*The Cellon Oak, with a circumference 30 feet (9.1 m), a height of 85 feet (25.9 m), and an average crown spread of 160 feet (48.8 m), is the largest recorded live oak tree in Florida.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fun4gatorkids.com/intown/44 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=July 6, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725234147/http://fun4gatorkids.com/intown/44 |archivedate=July 25, 2011 }} "Fun 4 Gator Kids — Cellon Live Oak", Retrieved 2011-07-06</ref><ref>[http://www.alachuacounty.us/depts/pw/parksandrecreation/pages/parkslist.aspx?activity=11] "Cellon Oak Park", Retrieved 2011-07-06</ref> It is used as the logo of [[Alachua County, Florida]].<ref>[[:File:AlachuaCountyLogo.jpg]] "Alachua County Logo", Retrieved 2011-07-06</ref>
*The [[Duffie Oak]], a more than 300-year-old southern live oak in Mobile, Alabama, has a trunk circumference of {{convert|30|ft|11|in|m}}, height of {{convert|48|ft|m}} and limb spread of {{convert|126|ft|m}}.  It is the oldest living landmark in the city.<ref name="mobbaymag">{{cite web |last=Borland |first=Timothy  |title=Treehugger 4: Duffie Live Oak |work= Mobile Bay Magazine |publisher=PMT Publishing |date=July 22, 2011 |url=http://www.mobilebaymag.com/Mobile-Bay/Bay-Buzz/Blog-2011/Mobile-Tree-Hugger-Part-II/ |accessdate=November 13, 2012}}</ref>
*The [[Emancipation Oak]], on the campus of [[Hampton University]] in Virginia, is listed as one of the "Ten Great Trees of the World" by the [[National Geographic Society]].
*The Century Tree, planted in 1891<ref>http://www.aggienetwork.com/century-tree-125/</ref> on the campus of [[Texas A&M University]] in [[College Station, Texas]], is a campus landmark and has been declared a Famous Tree of Texas by the [[Texas Forest Service]].<ref>http://texasforestservice.tamu.edu/websites/FamousTreesOfTexas/TreeLayout.aspx?pageid=15847</ref>
*The Evangeline Oak in [[St. Martinville, Louisiana]]<ref>[http://www.stoppingpoints.com/louisiana/St.-Martin/Evangeline+Oak.html Evangeline Oak Louisiana Historical Marker]</ref>
*The [[Friendship Oak (Long Beach, Mississippi)|Friendship Oak]] is a 500-year-old southern live oak located on the Gulf Park campus of the [[University of Southern Mississippi]] in [[Long Beach, Mississippi]].
*The Lover's Oak in [[Brunswick, Georgia]], is estimated to be 900 years old.
*The [[Treaty Oak (Austin, Texas)|Treaty Oak]] in [[Austin, Texas]]
*The [[Treaty Oak (Jacksonville, Florida)|Treaty Oak]] in [[Jacksonville, Florida]]

'''''Quercus xalapensis''''', or '''xalapa oak''', is a species of [[oak]] in the [[List of Quercus species#Section Lobatae|red oak]] group (''Quercus'' section ''Lobatae''). It is native to Central America ([[Guatemala]], [[El Salvador]]. [[Honduras]], and [[Nicaragua]]) and to Mexico as far north as [[Hidalgo (state)|Hidalgo]] and [[Sinaloa]].<ref>Linares, J. L. 2003 [2005]. Listado comentado de los árboles nativos y cultivados en la república de El Salvador. Ceiba 44(2): 105–268</ref><ref>Nelson Sutherland, C. H. 2001 [2002]. Plantas descritas originalmente de Honduras y sus nomenclaturas equivalentas actuales. Ceiba 42(1): 1–71. </ref><ref>Breedlove, D.E. 1986. Flora de Chiapas. Listados Florísticos de México 4: i–v, 1–246</ref><ref>[http://www.tropicos.org/Name/13100375?tab=specimens Tropicos, ''Quercus xalapensis'' Bonpl.]</ref>

''Quercus xalapensis'' is a large tree with a trunk 40-80 cm in diameter. Leaves are lance-shaped, up to 10 cm long, with numerous teeth along the edge, each tooth tapering to a long, thin point.<ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/279130#page/53/mode/1up Bonpland, Aimé Jacques Alexandre. 1809.  Plantae Aequinoctiales 2: 24-26] short description in Latin, longer description plus commentary and figure captions in French</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/279130#page/54/mode/1up Bonpland, Aimé Jacques Alexandre. 1809.  Plantae Aequinoctiales 2: plate 75] drawing of ''Quercus xalapensis'' </ref>

The species is threatened by [[habitat loss]] in parts of its native range.<ref>Nixon, K. ''et al.'' 1998.  [http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/34686/all ''Quercus xalapensis''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/34686/all |date=June 27, 2014 }}.   [http://www.iucnredlist.org 2006 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org |date=June 27, 2014 }}  Downloaded on 23 August 2007.</ref>
